I would recommend this ASUS Zenbook because of the following The lid is made from brushed metal it can be opened easily with one hand and the case is made from metal as well so overall build quality. The display part flexes easily and the keyboard bends a little if you are hard typer. It is very light at 2.5 lbs it has 2 USB 3 one USB type C HDMI and micro SD. USB type C doesn't support Thunderbolt 3 or charging and it also doesn't support DisplayPort Alternate mode which means you can't connect external monitors using the port. The ram is not upgradeable so what you buy is what you get major con if 8 is not enough for your usage. Keyboard has four-stage backlight and page Up/Down Home and End keys don't have their own keys meaning you would need to use Fn keys to use them and Key travel is short and feedback is very mushy so it is not the best option if you are used to mechanical keyboard or fast/frequent typer. Touchpad very accurate and fast as it comes with Microsoft’s Precision and supports multitouch gestures. Touchpad has a glass surface which is very smooth and the buttons are firm. Screen doesn't have PWM-flickering which is a good thing and it is very bright. Color coverage is above average at 93% sRGB and 60.4 RGB. High brightness and the matte display makes it great for outside usage. Screen is IPS has great viewing angles. Because of how small and light the laptop is it does throttle under intensive work for long period of time over 30 mins in intensive work but in short bursts it works very well. Fan gets loud under heavy work but not to the point where it would be annoying. Sound quality is good but bass is minimal. Battery supports quick charge a big plus and Asus claims it can charge up to 60% in less than 50 mins. Battery life on average usage had from 7.5 to 9.5 hours. Since you asked about photo editing and video editing ignore the advice to get a gaming laptop. Those are NOT designed for photo editing. You want a laptop with decent thermals for sure but mostly you want a high-resolution color-accurate display that supports 100% Adobe SRGB and DP3 color space. Most gaming laptops are 1080p or 1440p at best and are not designed for color accuracy at all. They are designed for very fast refresh rates which are useless for photo and video editing. The Apple MacBook Pro line the HP Z line the HP Spectre x360 with OLED screen and the higher-end Dell XPS are all examples of laptops with a suitable screen for what you are trying to do. The MacBook Pro 13 is probably the only one available for under 1400 although the Spectre x360 OLED can be found under 1400 on sale. The MacBook Pro also has the T2 chip which dramatically accelerates video encoding and takes the load off the MacBook’s CPU. One alternative suggestion? iPad Pro 12.9 and the Apple Magic Keyboard and Pencil. This is a very good photo editing machine that can run Photoshop Procreate Adobe Fresco iMovie and others. iPad has an incredible high resolution bright LCD which suppports DP3 color gamut. Apple pencil is hands down the best drawing and stylus input available. And the Magic Keyboard makes iPad a real candidate for laptop replacement.

For the lower end of your budget I would recommend this ASUS Zenbook because of the following The lid is made from brushed metal it can be opened easily with one hand and the case is made from metal as well so overall build quality. The display part flexes easily and the keyboard bends a little if you are hard typer. It is very light at 2.5 lbs it has 2 USB 3 one USB type C HDMI and micro SD. USB type C doesn't support Thunderbolt 3 or charging and it also doesn't support DisplayPort Alternate mode which means you can't connect external monitors using the port. The ram is not upgradeable so what you buy is what you get major con if 8 is not enough for your usage. Keyboard has four-stage backlight and page Up/Down Home and End keys don't have their own keys meaning you would need to use Fn keys to use them and Key travel is short and feedback is very mushy so it is not the best option if you are used to mechanical keyboard or fast/frequent typer. Touchpad very accurate and fast as it comes with Microsoft’s Precision and supports multitouch gestures. Touchpad has a glass surface which is very smooth and the buttons are firm. Screen doesn't have PWM-flickering which is a good thing and it is very bright. Color coverage is above average at 93% sRGB and 60.4 RGB. High brightness and the matte display makes it great for outside usage. Screen is IPS has great viewing angles. Because of how small and light the laptop is it does throttle under intensive work for long period of time over 30 mins in intensive work but in short bursts it works very well. Fan gets loud under heavy work but not to the point where it would be annoying. Sound quality is good but bass is minimal. Battery supports quick charge a big plus and Asus claims it can charge up to 60% in less than 50 mins. Battery life on average usage had from 7.5 to 9.5 hours. Man that's a tough one. It really comes down to what is the most important to you gaming or productivity? The i7 will obviously run much better with programs like fusion due to it's faster speed and more cores but the i5 laptop will pump out more consistent and higher FPS on the games you want to play. For example both GPUs will definitely pump out 100 FPS on average for CS GO on low settings but the 1650 will do it at higher settings as well. The 1650 also has better lows which means you won't get as much frame dip jutter. Games like CS GO don't need a powerful CPU to get the most frames since it's an old game but obviously a decent GPU is needed for high FPS. Now for GTA 5 you definitely want the 1650. The 1050 will play it but you'll likely have to have the settings at somewhere between low/medium to get a 60FPS average while the 1650 could probably do it at a mix of medium/high.

I would recommend this ASUS Zenbook because of the following The lid is made from brushed metal it can be opened easily with one hand and the case is made from metal as well so overall build quality. The display part flexes easily and the keyboard bends a little if you are hard typer. It is very light at 2.5 lbs it has 2 USB 3 one USB type C HDMI and micro SD. USB type C doesn't support Thunderbolt 3 or charging and it also doesn't support DisplayPort Alternate mode which means you can't connect external monitors using the port. The ram is not upgradeable so what you buy is what you get major con if 8 is not enough for your usage. Keyboard has four-stage backlight and page Up/Down Home and End keys don't have their own keys meaning you would need to use Fn keys to use them and Key travel is short and feedback is very mushy so it is not the best option if you are used to mechanical keyboard or fast/frequent typer. Touchpad very accurate and fast as it comes with Microsoft’s Precision and supports multitouch gestures. Touchpad has a glass surface which is very smooth and the buttons are firm. Screen doesn't have PWM-flickering which is a good thing and it is very bright. Color coverage is above average at 93% sRGB and 60.4 RGB. High brightness and the matte display makes it great for outside usage. Screen is IPS has great viewing angles. Because of how small and light the laptop is it does throttle under intensive work for long period of time over 30 mins in intensive work but in short bursts it works very well. Fan gets loud under heavy work but not to the point where it would be annoying. Sound quality is good but bass is minimal. Battery supports quick charge a big plus and Asus claims it can charge up to 60% in less than 50 mins. Battery life on average usage had from 7.5 to 9.5 hours. 1 Buy a business class laptop like a Thinkpad. They start with better build quality than consumer grade devices especially low-end consumer devices. A used/refurb unit will be in your price range and should have plenty of life left. 2 Install an SSD if it doesn't come with one. 8GB RAM if you truly leave lots of tabs open. Upgrading thinkpads is usually easy so don't be afraid to DIY. You can also repaste the CPU/GPU with high-quality thermal compound for better thermal performance. 3 Install Linux. No seriously. If you're just streaming Linux tends to use less RAM in the background and doesn't usually slow down with time like Windows installs can. Linux Mint MATE or Linux Mint XFCE will use under 1GB. Bonus Linux is free and works well on Thinkpads. 4 My Thinkpad with an HD4000 iGPU can handle 1080p YouTube video fine and while you could get something more powerful you won't necessarily need to. My thinkpad also drives a pair of older cheap over-ear studio headphones without needing a DAC/amp so Spotify should sound pretty good.

Usually when a laptop slows down it’s because of what’s on it. Operating systems break down over time. But if it’s not being treated correctly it will slow down a lot faster. Budget laptops are not the way to go if you need speed. Maybe what you Already got could do if you reset it and look into ways to take care of the operating system for example not leaving it running all the time and keeping up with updates not filling the hard drive all the way make sure programs aren’t running the the background. Take it to a professional and ask their opinion also if you want something that doesn’t slow down quickly you will have good luck on getting a Ssd instead of a standard hard drive.

It depends on what you want the laptop for. The base 1.1 GHz speed is perfectly fine if you intend to use the laptop for general usage and don't have a ton of installed programs that will run in the background. I say this because laptops are generally designed to accommodate the TDP of the CPU and a a CPU with that low speed is generally placed on thin laptops. These laptops are generally meant to run quite and smooth so long as you use it for general stuff like school work office media web browsing and so on. HP Envy x360 has been recommended a lot on this forum so I would like to point out Some drawbacks for HP Envy x360 300 nits brightness and doesn’t have Intel WiFi connectivity. People on best-buy have reviews for this laptop and they seem to be experiencing fan issues. Apparently the fan is very loud. HP Envy series have a very poor battery life although I can’t confirmed on this one yet. Before someone says you can upgrade the screen and connectivity OP is from UK and there is no option for an upgrade. Now you may be thinking I like dell but I am NOT a FAN of Dell.
Definitely with HP Envy x360

With the HP Envy you will want to make sure you pick a good display. I think the base display has only 250 Nits of brightness... I think there is an option for a FHD 400 nits. That one will be the better one or 4K if you don't care about battery life .

If youre only doing Netflix and Youtube then why not just get an iPad pro refurb? The display is better and the iOS apps are way cleaner. A 2018 ipad pro has a pretty powerful 6 core 7 core technically chip. The older Dells have cooling issues and a plethora of other issues that many can attest to. I know people love the HP Envy here but I hate the build quality. While it might seem like I'm an Apple fan I am actually in the market to buy the new Dell xps but have been super impressed by the power of an ipad pro.

Have both of those exact models but the 13 4700U with 16GB. The Dell 9370 I have is the 4K touchscreen. The HP Envy actually fits in the same footprint at the Dell but is thicker. It feels very slightly heavier but is nice to use. The keys are wider and have good travel and the trackpad is good. I particularly like the hardware camera button and finger print sensor. It runs slick and responsive and the sound/speakers are miles better. As mentioned above biggest caveat is the screen which is dimmer. The screen is also FHD on envy Vs 4K but this doesn't make as significant a different as the brightness. You can crank up the brightness but I'd say the equivalent brightness at 50% on the Dell is about 70% on the Envy. Haven't tested batter yet but it is really nice to use so far.

It can’t run full version of Microsoft Office application like Word Excel PowerPoint. That’s a major disadvantage I can think of. If your sole purpose is note taking I would agree iPad and the Apple stylus are very superior and their screens are very good too.

I work for a fortune 500 company and alot of my executives wanted to get tablets as real computer replacements. They came back crawling after 1 week to traditional laptops. iPad is nice and is being used alot more but despite what Apple marketing tells you it is not a substitute for a really full fledged Mac or PC. Especially when you are paying the same price or even more than you could just buy a high end windows or low end Mac. With tablets you are at the mercy of apple for apps Your whole class uses a program not available on the apple store? You're screwed. I just don't see the need to limit yourself for the same price especially when the iPad with it's keyboard is now heavier and thicker than a regular laptop.
Watch this

No. If you had a desktop or a laptop iPad would make great secondary device but as the only device I wouldn't recommend it. I agree with you that touchscreen with pen support are pretty good for note taking. That's why i personally got a windows laptop which was capable of doing that. I don't know which courses you would have in your college but in my masters we had a couple of subjects which involved coding and there is absolutely no way of doing that on iPad.
I have been thinking of using that setup while travelling but I feel it is a little expensive it cost almost as good as this ASUS Zenbook which costs almost as much.

Before the Magic Keyboard I would have said “absolutely no way.” But the Magic Keyboard is transformative. I’m using one now on the 2018 iPad Pro to write this post. Incredible. Even so I’m going to say “maybe.” You didn’t list what your course of study is so that will have an impact on the answer to your question. But generally you’ll need to be sure that 1. There are no applications you will need that are either not available on iPad or very limited on iPad. For example yes Excel is available on iPad but it is not capable of opening more complex spreadsheets every iPadOS version gets closer but it won’t match the desktop versions for years if ever . Photoshop on iPad is also not as capable as desktop version. Etc. etc. 2. You can live with iPad multitasking which is really just 2-app-tasking with some app switching. This is also improving but iPad just doesn’t do more than a couple of tasks at once very well if at all. You could get frustrated if you are trying to participate in a Zoom lecture take notes and do research at the same time. 3. You don’t want an external monitor. Many college students get a cheap external LCD monitor for their apartment or dorm to come home and write papers and do research on while using a large screen. Almost any LCD tv can also act as an external monitor and do double duty that way. IPad can only mirror its screen not extend its screen so you’ll just end up looking at a copy of what’s on your iPad screen. Again this could change with future iPadOS releases but now it is an issue. Now as to the Good 1. Magic keyboard and trackpad is a game changer. It might actually be worth the price 2. With Apple Pencil the iPad becomes an excellent maybe the best digital note taker 3. Pull iPad off the keyboard and you have an excellent tablet for reading eBooks watching videos playing games etc. 4. iPadOS files app now gives iPad a legitimate file manager which works well with local files and cloud storage 5. Apple has done an excellent job of supporting iPads over time so you should expect a new 2020 iPad to get 5 years of OS updates 6. The LIDAR scanner in the new iPad Pros could be put to some really cool uses in the future 7. IPad will be a delight to carry around to class and back given its size and weight 8. IPad has plenty of CPU power so you won’t be lacking in that area. It is actually faster than the MacBook Air. 9. IPad applications are becoming more and more capable all the time and so in the future you should expect more and more equivalency to the desktop versions If I could afford an iPad Pro 12.9 Apple Pencil and Magic Keyboard or the MacBook Air 16/512 that would be a tough choice. Worst case get the iPad setup and see if it works. If it doesn’t get yourself a cheap PC laptop for 500 later and use it for whatever the iPad won’t do.

Yes. You should absolutely do this. The iPad Pro is essentially made for productivity. The iOS store has so many cool note-taking apps too. Google Paperlike - it's a screen protector that feels like paper when you write on it with the Apple Pencil. If you like to take written notes this is a game changer. If you like to draw it's a game changer. The 2020 iPad pro is extremely powerful - the newest chip is an 8 core processor - I have seen people editing 4k video with scrubbing and on it. I am not even an giant Apple fan I only have an iPhone and Airpods but really think the pro is a perfect device for a college kid and even post-college. Magic keyboard is also clutch.
I honestly believe that the surface pro 7 is very overpriced especially if you start buying the accessories. If money is no problem for you go for it!

I recommend Lenovo Yoga C740 14 inch. You’ll get so much more for your money. The stylus that come with it may be inferior to the one with Microsoft pro 7 but you’ll be spending 100 buck on the stylus anyway so you can always buy a better one for your Yoga.

I think the Surface Pro 7 is an excellent choice. There are decent sales and Costco usually offers the SP7 keyboard and pen for 1000. Put an Urban Armor Gear case on that thing and you’ll have a backpack-friendly tough little tablet and laptop. The biggest challenge may be the kickstand design takes up a lot of table space and may not work well on small writing desk in lecture halls. For taking notes though the Surface Pro is great. The other alternative is 2-in-1 style laptop like the HP Envy or HP Spectre x360. The 2-in-1s are better laptops and worse tablets than the Surface. I find for note taking with pen the thickness of the 2-in-1s is less than ideal and I personally don’t like the weight of them as a tablet nor do I like feeling the keyboard and trackpad on the bottom when the screen is folded over. On the Surface just pull off the type cover and you’ll have a more normal tablet. Cool trick on the surface pull off the type cover and reattach backwards so that it becomes the back of the surface. I saw that in a video and though “why don’t they make that more obvious?” Genius. You can likely get a bit more hardware for your money if you get something like the HP Envy but if you really want a tablet that can replace your laptop one that can be made durable for kicking around in a backpack and is great for note-taking then the SP7 is an excellent choice.

I would buy an iPad pro if you have the budget. I currently have a Surface Pro 5 with the highest configuration and it's great - however I think you get more out of an iPad. It is thin has an amazing display and super portable. It's even cheaper than a similar configured surface. My complaints with the Surface are that the alcantara keyboard will get torn and scratched if you carry it in a bag and it rubs against things. I have also had issues with the screen - if something gets stuck between the keyboard and screen in your bag somehow it will create screen burns quite easily. I really hated this. My girlfriend just bought the surface pro 7 decked out and has already developed 2 screen burns as well. The biggest game changer is this stuff called Paperlike - its a screen protector that makes your screen feel like youre writing on actual paper. This sounds like it's right up your alley. If you buy a new 12.9 ipad Pro with magic keyboard and apple pencil its about 1500 and I know the surface pro 7 is in that same range if not a bit more when it's highly configured. Also you don't have to buy the 350 dollar keyboard for the iPad - that takes the price down considerably.

How about this ASUS Zenbook because of the following The lid is made from brushed metal it can be opened easily with one hand and the case is made from metal as well so overall build quality. The display part flexes easily and the keyboard bends a little if you are hard typer. It is very light at 2.5 lbs it has 2 USB 3 one USB type C HDMI and micro SD. USB type C doesn't support Thunderbolt 3 or charging and it also doesn't support DisplayPort Alternate mode which means you can't connect external monitors using the port. The ram is not upgradeable so what you buy is what you get major con if 8 is not enough for your usage. Keyboard has four-stage backlight and page Up/Down Home and End keys don't have their own keys meaning you would need to use Fn keys to use them and Key travel is short and feedback is very mushy so it is not the best option if you are used to mechanical keyboard or fast/frequent typer. Touchpad very accurate and fast as it comes with Microsoft’s Precision and supports multitouch gestures. Touchpad has a glass surface which is very smooth and the buttons are firm. Screen doesn't have PWM-flickering which is a good thing and it is very bright. Color coverage is above average at 93% sRGB and 60.4 RGB. High brightness and the matte display makes it great for outside usage. Screen is IPS has great viewing angles. Because of how small and light the laptop is it does throttle under intensive work for long period of time over 30 mins in intensive work but in short bursts it works very well. Fan gets loud under heavy work but not to the point where it would be annoying. Sound quality is good but bass is minimal. Battery supports quick charge a big plus and Asus claims it can charge up to 60% in less than 50 mins. Battery life on average usage had from 7.5 to 9.5 hours. I have been suggesting the iPad pro a lot. I think it is your best option. While you are subject to iPad iOS this is not a huge problem at all. People tend to think there is only one way of going about computer software - look at the iPad as an alternative to that which may even be better. Do not go with a Macbook Air - the new ones are just rehoused older technology sold at a premium price. The new iPad has a new 8 core chip and is extremely capable of doing what your sister needs - especially photo editing.

I don’t know much about how prices are in Malaysia but in the USA for a 1200 budget you would have a lot of choices. You said your sister has a 2-in-1 but it doesn’t sound like she uses the touch screen or flip-around modes or pen much if at all . If true I’d suggest you stay away from the Surface line. Those are really designed for someone who wants a tablet-first experience and you’ll pay a lot for that design which may not be needed. They’re also lousy laptops meaning they are very hard to use in your lap. They are brilliant tablets though. Surface Pro 7 - good all around but by the time you price in the Type Cover and Pen you’re spending quite a bit for some fairly low specs . I owned a Surface Pro 3 and Surface Pro 4 and loved them both but I like the form factor. Surface Pro X - very intriguing and more modern design but may not be available in Malaysia and has performance and compatibility questions Surface Go 2 - well made small tablet but underpowered especially for the price and really would only recommend for someone who values extreme portability Source I owned a Surface Go for a year and loved it but I wanted something very small Another 2-in-1 like the HP Envy would be a good choice. But you will run into the same sorts of quality issues you have now. Still you should get 3 years out of it. MacBook Air. Don’t let the people who only measure a computer by its Geekbench score put you off. The Air is a fine computer for MOST people. It has a bright Retina display vs. the dim 1080p displays on many value PCs it has completely fine performance with one exception it has impeccable build quality it has the T2 chip for security and additional performance it has Touch ID and will last for many years. It will also hold its value way better than a comparably priced PC. Where the Air is NOT fine is for CPU-intensive tasks that persist like video rendering. It is fine for quick cpu spikes like applying a photoshop filter or rendering a quick transition. But it has poor thermal headroom so anything that creates heat buildup will result in the CPU downclocking to stay cool. Most people don’t actually do these kinds of tasks and so never notice. Now the iPad Pro is an intriguing choice. I’m writing this post on the iPad Pro with Magic Keyboard and I can tell you the combination of iPadOS 13.4 and the Magic Keyboard is transformative. It is absolutely capable of replacing a laptop for many people. The question for yoyour sister is whether the iPadOS version of Word is featured enough for her work. If she is just doing general writing it will be fine. If she is doing complex layouts tables of contents extensive footnoting then it might not be capable of what she needs. The IPad does meet most of your requirements. Bright screen great for movies good speakers light weight long battery life. You can get one with 512gb of storage although you likely don’t need that much.
I did an entire MBA on an ipad and use a pro a lot let me know if you have any particular questions.

I would recommend this ASUS Zenbook because of the following The lid is made from brushed metal it can be opened easily with one hand and the case is made from metal as well so overall build quality. The display part flexes easily and the keyboard bends a little if you are hard typer. It is very light at 2.5 lbs it has 2 USB 3 one USB type C HDMI and micro SD. USB type C doesn't support Thunderbolt 3 or charging and it also doesn't support DisplayPort Alternate mode which means you can't connect external monitors using the port. The ram is not upgradeable so what you buy is what you get major con if 8 is not enough for your usage. Keyboard has four-stage backlight and page Up/Down Home and End keys don't have their own keys meaning you would need to use Fn keys to use them and Key travel is short and feedback is very mushy so it is not the best option if you are used to mechanical keyboard or fast/frequent typer. Touchpad very accurate and fast as it comes with Microsoft’s Precision and supports multitouch gestures. Touchpad has a glass surface which is very smooth and the buttons are firm. Screen doesn't have PWM-flickering which is a good thing and it is very bright. Color coverage is above average at 93% sRGB and 60.4 RGB. High brightness and the matte display makes it great for outside usage. Screen is IPS has great viewing angles. Because of how small and light the laptop is it does throttle under intensive work for long period of time over 30 mins in intensive work but in short bursts it works very well. Fan gets loud under heavy work but not to the point where it would be annoying. Sound quality is good but bass is minimal. Battery supports quick charge a big plus and Asus claims it can charge up to 60% in less than 50 mins. Battery life on average usage had from 7.5 to 9.5 hours. Pixelbook Go runs on ChromeOs - a dekstop/mobile os where you can't run your normal apps like on windows or macos. You can install android apps on it and lately it got support for running linux apps not sure what distro is based on but the whole process is overhwelming and i wouldn't consider this Chromebook for your work at all. Even as a Chromebook is very expensive the point of chromebooks is to be as cheap as possible and to have access to a browser now android apps but not to cost 600 . At that pricepoint you have to consider laptops with true desktop OSes. I'm a senior Cs student and a software dev wanna be. I'm familiar with web dev but you said that you're just starting out as a web dev. Maybe you know by now that not just software development but specifically web development is a very broad aspect has a lot of different technologies etc. Are you trying to become a backend dev? A front-ent? Backend and DevOps engineer? A full stack dev a.k.a software engineer usually frontend backend devops all together ? For all of these positions you don't need a laptop with a good gpu or dedicated gpu at all well depending on the project you're working on over 90% of the time you won't need a good gpu. Unfortunately you cannot install any IDEs frameworks etc directly on chromeos you have to do that through that linux-support alternative which isn't that good on this regard and also not every dev-related app or whatever has linux support. I just wanted to first clarify that there is no such thing as mAcOs iS sO mUcH bEtTer fOr sOftWaRe dEvElOpmEnT . That's not true at all. Depending on what you do as a software dev windows and gnlinux have advantages over macOs because of support. And vice versa macOs over the 2 f.e for ios app development. You can dual boot windows or gnlinux with macos but there is hardware compatibility issues and you won't get the full macOs app support also nvidia gpu driver support is officialy non existent since 2014 or something there are fan made driver support but that's not an issue since you won't need a dedicated gpu for you work at all as i mentioned earlier. Also don't trust people who say macOs' terminal is soo much better bcz macos is unix based and you can run commands on it and bla bla bla guess what? You have the equivalent terminal commands on window's cmd/powershell. Now that it has linux support you can write the same terminal commands as you would in a gnlinux distro. Also those macOs commands that most talk about those people usually just navigate through directories and brag about the terminal lol . I know it sound overhwelming but at least now you have necessery info about what you'll really need for your work. So you mentioned 2000Cad. For that price you can get a laptop with excellent build quality very good screen quality great batterylife and cpu performance for the most part while having a small body overall. Since weight is important for you a laptop with a screen under 15.6 diagonally might be ideal. If you want a 13.3-14 screen i wouldn't recommend the standard 16 9 ratio since for smaller screens 16 9 seems very short. More vertical space is highly appreciated for the work you're doing but we will get narrower display. F.E if we compare a 13.3 16 9 screen and a 13.3 16 10 screen macbook pro 13's or xps 13 9300's that 16 10 screen is bigger even though diagonally they're the same in area that 16 10 is a bit bigger but it is narrower horizontaly but taller vertically. There are also 3 2 screens which are even taller but more narrow f.e Surface Laptop 3 either 13 which is 13.5 diagonally or the 15 Surface Book 3 13/15 Huawei Matebook X Pro a new Acer 13 that just got released etc although there aren't a lot of 3 2 screen laptops on the market. On to cpus at least a quadcore cpu is necessery. Intel's 10 gen either comet lake or ice lake are the most common for that 2000cad price. An Ice Lake i5 is very similar in performance to an Ice Lake i7 search on google for these similarities so getting an i7 is not necessary. On the other hand a comet lake i5 i5 10210U is a quadcore cpu and an i7 10710U like on my Prestige 15 in a 6 core/12 thread cpu which works around 80-100% better than that i5 depending on how laptop manufacturers configure those cpus. Just because there is a U at the end of the cpu instead of an H doesn't mean that the U series cpu is weaker than the H series. Msi configured that 10710u to perform to its limits so its performance is the same as an i7 9750H that you would find in a Macbook Pro 16 i can confirm this . Unfortunately that i7 10710u doesn't perform the same on smaller laptops like it does in my Prestige 15 because of the cooling f.E in a last gen Dell Xps 13 9380 and Lenovo X1 Carbon 7th gen i guess the 10710u performs around 20% worse. Anyway there are the new Amd ryzen 4th gen mobile cpus that perform better than all intel cpus for a lower price. Also they perform better while pulling less wattage or the same depending on the cpu . Because the work you will do doesn't cause any issues from the cpu amd cpus don't work well with android studio it will throw a bsod when trying to run android studio's emulator that's my experience since i work with it . The problem is that there aren't any laptops with a 16 10 or 3 2 display and a ryzen 4th gen cpu. There is a 13.3 Hp envy with a 4th gen ryzen cpu which is overall very great for its price but is has a 16 9 screen which i don't recommend to anyone who need a 13-14 display. There is a gaming laptop - a 14 16 9 Asus rog g14 with ryzen 4th gen that for 2000 cad has the best mobile cpu in any laptop at the moment and is overall the best performing laptop for its category its batterylife is quite long for a gaming laptop but the problem is that it is a bit too heavy for you maybe it looks like a gaming laptop although overall muted 16 9 screen it has a dgpu which tou won't need. What it would highly suggest you is either one of these laptops This Dell Xps 13 9300 config you should get a matte screen protector for it search amazon or this config which already comes with a matte screen but it isn't touchscreen. I know that the first config is slightly above your budget but at this pricepoint it is worth considering. This config of the 2020 base MacBook Pro 13 with a quadcore i5 and 16gb of ram is very good. I wouldn't recommend 8gb of ram anymore you'll end up having opened a couple of apps tabs on browser which will use a big protion of your ram. Also if you endup getting this please consider buying a matte screenprotector Apple advertises their screens as anti reflective and while they have a layer on top they are still glossy and very distractive when you're working in a brightly lit environment. Dell also has an anriglare layer on that first config xps 13 above. Surface Laptop 3 13 is also very nice with an i5 10th gen and 16gb ram you're getting a very nice laptop overall. That Hp Envy x360 with ryzen 4th gen is also prerty good we have to wait for proper reviews to see how it performs how's batterylife screen quality etc.

I've seen ASUS mentioned a lot here. For my two cents while it's not the most obnoxious model on their catalog I have the GA502 and it's kind of a hot potato. The Mothership might be better but after dealing with their horrible 'Armoury Crate' software the awful cooling system in the GA502 and the genuinely dismissive and decidedly unhelpful support system the company has I wouldn't go ASUS. Their motherboards for desktops are pretty great and their laptops used to be incredible but it just doesn't feel that way anymore. The Alienware M15 R3 just launched and it has a neat vapor chamber cooling system that supposedly improves thermals by a significant margin. Reviews aren't out yet though so we'll see if that hold true. The Area 51M is just a beast and absolutely fits the 'Onnoxious' criteria though I'm not sure about thermals which should be among the most important things you look for when you select a PC. Outside of Dell's swanky Alienware series MSI has some neat designs and Razer Blade has some slightly subdued aesthetic language but looks and feels just as gamer-y as you would hope. Happy searching!

Intel used to be better but was in the lead for so long they got lazy and got leapped frogged by AMD who was almost bankrupt and needed to innovate its way out of it. They took a gamble on their Ryzen chips in 2016 and the 7nm process node last year and they have been killing Intel across the desktop workstation server and now finally laptops with their Ryzen 4000 series. The reason is they are using TSMC'S 7nm process and chiplets design for it's CPU basically they can glue chips together to make higher skus. They are all the same just with glued cores. Intel is still on 14nm because they design their own chips and saw no need to push innovation as they were ahead so much. So now they have been at 14nm since 2014. And they still can't just shrink their node because of their monolithic design to their chips and issues with trying to shrink down to 10nm. Basically Intel will be behind till at least 2023 and by then AMD will be on 5nm. Long story short AMD is the better option. Cheaper more performance more cores better battery more secure. intel is popular and they are a massive company so it's gonna take time for people to really see how ahead AMD is. For video editors the majority use AMD now because of the high core count CPUs they offer for fairly cheap 3900x is a 12 core CPU for 389 They even offer a 64 core monster if you can afford a 4000 chip. Either way Intel is still bigger but it really is a David and Goliath story.

You need a desktop with a high core count CPU and tons of RAM OR clean up your workflow. Use bookmarks and close tabs. Any computer regardless of specs will choke if you are just running a million things at the same time for no reason.

Really? You cannot physically do all of those things at the same time but as Chewy said get a desktop. One with 32GB of ram a 16 core XEON cpu and dual 4k monitors. Shouldn’t cost you more than about 5000 or so. But if you really want to TRY and do all of that at the same time you will most likely be RAM-bound more than CPU or Storage limited. So find a machine that allows 32GB of ram. If you really are running all that stuff you’ll want a 4k monitor of at least 15.6 inches or larger. You will also want at least an 8 core CPU. There aren’t a lot of laptops that support 32GB of ram but on the list would be MacBook Pro 16 HP Z line HP Spectre x360 15 Dell XPS Dell Inspiron But if you can tighten up your workflow a bit any high-end laptop with gobs of ram will work.

I tried to do this myself and have used the Surface Pro and the HP Spectre x360. A few things to consider 1. You aren't just changing hardware you are changing entire ecosystems. Take stock of how many of Apple's ecosystem features you are using. I'm not just talking about iMessage although that one alone can be a deal-breaker for many people but Keychain Notes News iPhoto iMovie iCloud Drive ApplePay AppleTV etc. You can get close to reproducing this on Windows but it will be more of pain and you'll have to lean heavily on the Google cloud to help you. This applies to iPadOS apps that you might using which may not be available on Windows 10. 2. Decide if you want a tablet that can replace your laptop Surface Pro or a laptop that can replace your tablet 2-in-1 . 2-in-1s are great laptops that can act as a tablet in a pinch but they are 90% Laptop. even taking notes on one vs. the iPad will be a disappointment. Windows 10 is a very good desktop and laptop OS although you may be surprised how much time you spend tweaking it vs. what you are used to on the Mac that can do just about anything you need. The size and thickness make them cumbersome tablets and anything above 13 inches is pretty impossible to use as a tablet. The Surface is much more akin to a tablet that can replace a laptop. Windows 10 is not a great tablet OS so you may miss your iPad. However the Surface hardware is very nice as a tablet and you can generally use a surface like a tablet in a way you can't easily use a 2-in-1. The surface screen is smaller than virtually all 2-in-1s and using a Surface on a lap is an exercise in futility. You could also consider selling the Air and getting the Apple Magic Keyboard for your iPad Pro. yes it is expensive but it absolutely makes the iPad much more viable as a laptop replacement. x200B For 2-in-1s I generally suggest HP Envy Chewy will tell you all about this HP Spectre x360 Lenovo Yoga C740 cheaper or Lenovo c940 more expensive For Surface I suggest Surface Pro 7 Costco has a great bundle usually which includes keyboard pen The Surface Pro X looks great but you are taking a big gamble with that ARM processor and why risk adding a bunch of compatibility issues just for thinner bezels?

I would assume laptops with gpus tend to produce more heat and more heat leads to higher rates of failure. and thats what I think is probably the cause of all those Razer laptops with defects. Louis Rossmann once invited a repair guy specializing in Razer repairs to explain the internal designs. IRC the cooling system was generally not very good. combined with a thin chassis leads to a shorter life span I think those that are super thick and heavy such as those Clevo laptops probably last longer comparatively. this is just my guess

As with any product . More parts means more failure points. I'm not surprised about the toughbook. They are over engineered with the focus on being durable. So it would be fair to assume they would outlive most other models. But I'd assume as a whole the integrated systems are more prone to failure for the simple fact that most of the low end market and budget models are made as cheap as possible. I'd think it be more interesting to compair pricepoint with failure rate. On a purely anecdotal note I've bought and owned many laptops over the years with many brands Dell budget tier are the ones I've had the most trouble with. So much so I've tended to avoid them for the last 8 or so years so no idea how they are now. Also my longest lasting laptop was a core 2 based Sony Vaio I think the person that inherited it still used it up until last year. So almost 11 years .

Only the hardware makers know the actual failure rates and even then they would need an identical model where the primary difference is GPU/no-GPU. But anecdotally according to the ever-accurate Internet chat rooms laptops with dedicated graphics cards DO fail quite a bit more. It is very plausible for 3 related reasons 1. More heat overall as another heat-generating component is squashed into a small area 2. Users who buy these laptops tend to use them for more intensive sustained tasks leading to .... more heat 3. GPU makers overestimated their components abilities to deal with heat NVIDIA was famous for a run of GPUs failing Thin laptops and hot components are in conflict. Having ample airflow and big fans is not what most laptop buyers want - they want thin and quiet. Microsoft Surface Book is the rare exception with the CPU in the tablet lid and the GPU in the base which enabled both components to heat up independently and indeed it punches above its weight on sustained tasks vs most ultrabook-type devices as it can isolate each heat producing element in a different part of the device. I would guess big clunky gaming laptops would do better since they are designed to handle the heat HOWEVER gaming laptops fall into trap 2 above and run the heat-producing games for long periods of time under pretty heavy loads. Even more of a challenge is that the CPU and GPU in most laptops are quite close together often sharing the same heat pipe meaning heat from one can actually be quickly passed to the other.
I’m curious to hear what people say. lurk

I dont think its a video card thing more than the product family. The gaming lines are always better build quality than the budget or mainstream lines. Normally a laptop with a separate GPU is better because it has the better battery motherboard power supply case hinges monitor panels and those are the biggest points of failure. IE HP Omen will fail less than the Envy which fail less than a Pavillion which will fail less than the HP no name family The fairest comparison I can make is the budget garbage Acer Aspire 5 family. You can get the same specs with a non-gaming/light gaming gpu like the MX250 or the same exact specs without the gpu for 75-100 less. I've gotten 3 with gpus. all 3 got fried mother boards in under 2 years. Meanwhile only a quarter of the non-gpu aspires have had major issues usually failed fan screen or power adaptor only the gpu version have had complete mobo power failures. but thats aspire 200- 600 slapdash disposable laptops. My oldest laptop Alienware Area 51 with an 8800m card from 2007-ish has almost no battery life but still runs perfectly but was almost 2000

Can confirm that the ENVY x360 15 with Ryzen 7 4700U is a beast. I work professionally with Blender with light gaming on the side with down time. Blender runs quite well handling over 9 million polys quite easily. The RAM SSD and Wifi are all upgradable. Though to be honest the RAM will be the only thing you would want to upgrade. I am currently on the hunt for a 32gb kit. But since the pandemic that is proving hard. The added touch screen and NTrig Pen Digitizer was a big selling point for me. A lot of my blender work these days is in sculpting. So not having to carry around my XP Pen 15.6 Pro Pen display with me to the office is nice. Note that you do have to buy a pen/stylus separately. But the Wacom Bamboo Ink V2 works really well and it's a third of the cost of a Apple Pencil. So big bonus. As for the 4700U in the ENVY. It's insane. 8 Physical cores... In a laptop... I don't even care that it doesn't have SMT/Hyper Threading. What I find nuts is that this low wattage ultrabook convertible laptop CPU renders blender scenes as fast as my Ryzen 3600 Desktop with 6 Cores/12 Threads. That blows my mind. But yeah. If you want something that is nice to look at with solid performance and that checks a lot of boxes. Then I can't recommend it enough. Also this reminds me that I was going to do a little write up and review for this thing on here...

Since you said you wanted to get hyped up I'll tell you about my experiences with my Dell XPS 13! To put it simply it's incredible don't have any affiliation with Dell in any way and have pretty neutral opinions about the company if you were wondering - The build quality is quite impressive as I was coming from a MacBook Air Early 2015 model and was expecting really poor build quality in comparison but the XPS holds up really nicely. - A more subtle feature of this laptop that people don't talk about or hype up enough is the carbon fiber palm rest. It's soft to the touch and honestly makes my typing experience so much more enjoyable in general. It's nice that Dell put in this much thought when they could have followed the trend that every other laptop was setting and just left us with a regular metal palm rest and no one would have ever complained. - Seeing as you're getting the XPS 15 and I have the 13 I imagine the power is going to be absolutely amazing on your device. For me and my purposes the my XPS has shown to be a power-house. It performs all the tasks I ask it to quickly and I've even been able to do light gaming on it even though I have an integrated graphics chip. - The thermals are pretty good on my machine. It only ever gets hot when I play some games on it Sims 4 and COD mainly which is expected since I don't have a discrete graphics chip. Even when it does get hot though it does so towards the back of the machine so it shouldn't ever be uncomfortable. People are right when they say it gets really hot but for the average person someone who doesn't game a whole lot or do much photo/video editing or CAD work it shouldn't get to those points on a regular basis. Dell does this to get maximum performance because by letting the machine hit a high temperature it's allowing for peak performance to happen for a longer time and then the laptop will thermal throttle and come down. - Now the part that you seem most hyped about -- the screen! I have the 4K version as well I have a 2-in-1 so the configuration I got forced me to get the 4K display and it's so good! I really enjoy watching YouTube videos and shows or movies on Netflix with this. It's such a game-changer because everything and I mean everything looks absolutely gorgeous on it. I even started to appreciate typing on Google Docs and just browsing websites more because the colors are so vivid and I don't know how to describe the display other than crisp. Everything just packs a little punch even the font on this post looks nice. I hope this helped hype you up and feel free to ask me any questions!

No that's not what it's about. A graphics card contains a GPU graphical processing unit which is a processor that is specialized in doing calculations that graphical applications such as games need. It can be also useful for other purposes and can accelerate other things because a GPU is well suited for carrying out the same instructions over a large data set in parallel. The graphics card has its own memory because it makes the system faster if there is memory that the GPU can directly access and exclusively use. If you don't have a dedicated graphics card that means that you have to make do with the processing power of the integrated graphics inside your CPU. You can put as much memory in the system as you like but it will still lack the processing power of the dedicated graphics card. Depending on what kind of applications you run this might be just fine for your use case.

The AMD 4000 processors are absolutely legit They offer more cores for less money and less power consumption. The only issue is that since Intel is so big and established they are able to be in alot if different laptops AMD is slowly starting to be added to better and better models but still limited in options. I recommend the Ryzen 4000 series over pretty much all Intel chips because it literally is a plus at almost every front to go ryzen. Intel i3 starts at 2 cores Ryzen 3 starts at 4 cores Intel i5 is typically 4 cores Ryzen 5 is now 6 cores. Intel i7 is typically 4 cores for most and 8 cores at the crazy high end Ryzen 7 has 8 cores at very low power consumption. Linus did a test where a Ryzen 9 4900H was more powerful than the massive laptops with 8 core Intel chips using 90W of power while the 8 core Ryzen was using about 35W. I'll link it here. So in terms of CPU Ryzen 4000 absolutely smokes almost the entire Intel lineup but since it's new there are limited laptop options still.

While the surface book is a really interesting design with the 2 in 1 form factor its really expensive for the hardware specs it offers. Unless you really use the tablet mode often with your current surface book I’d spend your money on other features in another laptop. The surface laptop is a solid ultrabook laptop and looks great and is super portable but not really that powerful. Compared to the surface book you’re missing that GPU power that comes in the keyboard dock. If you’re just going to be reading and writing papers using excel and prism with a little R and Matlab then the surface laptop would work fine. I’d stick to whatever OS your PI uses because sharing documents is sometimes a pain if you’re not using the same software. That being said having more power wouldn’t hurt. I’m a protein biochemist and for the first 4 years of my PhD all I used my laptop for was reading and writing and excel. But in my last year I’ve started doing some mathematical modeling of the enzymes I work with and that has been very taxing on my computer. Thankfully I have a gaming desktop that can handle the workload. TLDR I’d recommend something with a little more power. Like the new Ryzen 4700U and 16GB RAM. If Chewy hasn’t filled you in I’m sure he will soon. Or I can give you a couple of recs.

You will get a hundred opinions on this question and they are all right. All wrong too. The Mac-vs-PC question has been raging for almost 4 decades. Here is what advice I usually give. Go for Windows 10 if you want Gaming especially the latest AAA games Touch screen 2-in-1 and/or active stylus support You need hardware that isn’t available on MacBook without using a dongle USB-A HDMI SD card slot Ethernet port etc or a really large or really small screen. The most powerful hardware specs for the least amount of money You use an application which is unavailable on MacOS Your budget is less than 1000 Get a MacOS laptop if you want Impeccable hardware design and quality and when Apple does screw up they are more likely to launch a repair campaign or warranty extension than PC manufacturers Top notch support online and via local Apple stores Way better included software like iPhoto iMovie Notes GarageBand etc. High quality screens well suited for photo video editing MacBook Pros support DP3 color gamut for example Benfits of the MacOS ecosystem Especially if you use an iPhone including iMessage Keychain App Store Handoff iCloud Apple Pay Apple TV etc. You have more than 1000 budget Macs hold their value WAY better than PCs so some of the higher upfront cost is recovered years later on resale So which is best for you? Hard to say without knowing more. Generally you’ll find that comparing like-for-like specs you will pay a bit more for a Macintosh but not as much as you might think and you get a LOT of great free benefits like the software above and the better resale. I think most typical users find a Mac to be the more satisfying choice especially if they use an iPhone. For gamers or people on a tight budget Windows 10 is the clear winner. Flame suit on -

Part 2 on what system specs you need? Again varies a lot by use case. For most people 8/256 is the bare minimum in 2020. That should be sufficient for typical tasks on both MacOS and Windows10. I generally advise people to get more RAM and then more storage because You can always add external storage but you can’t add external RAM Applications and OSs released in the future will require more RAM than today so RAM helps with longevity RAM in most laptops and all MacBooks is not upgradeable so you get what you get forever The cloud makes local storage less critical if you do get tight on space However buying MORE RAM than you need will provide exactly zero speed improvements. So overbuying is just a waste of money. 8GB is sufficient for most users in 2020 but 16 GB provides more future proofing. If you like keeping 20 Chrome tabs open your mail app music player video conferencing then 16gb is probably a good choice now. IF you are working with massive photo files that have lots of layers or very complex video editing you’ll know if this is you then you might need more than 16GB. Again if you need more than 16gb you probably know that very well. x200B Based on what you’ve said I think you should look at 1 2020 MacBook Pro 10th Gen i5 / 16/ 512. 1799 2 2020 MacBook Pro 8th gen i5 /16 /512 1599 3 2020 MacBook Air 10th gen i5 16/256 1299 4 2020 MacBook Air 10th gen i5 8/256 1099

For the lower end of your budget Copying from another comment I just made for under 500 you got 2 great options either this off brand from walmart or This Lenovo Ideapad both offer very similar specs but personally I like the one from Walmart more because according to reviews the build quality is much better and it is also very light at 2.55 lbs iirc. For the higher end I would recommend this ASUS Zenbook because of the following The lid is made from brushed metal it can be opened easily with one hand and the case is made from metal as well so overall build quality. The display part flexes easily and the keyboard bends a little if you are hard typer. It is very light at 2.5 lbs it has 2 USB 3 one USB type C HDMI and micro SD. USB type C doesn't support Thunderbolt 3 or charging and it also doesn't support DisplayPort Alternate mode which means you can't connect external monitors using the port. The ram is not upgradeable so what you buy is what you get major con if 8 is not enough for your usage. Keyboard has four-stage backlight and page Up/Down Home and End keys don't have their own keys meaning you would need to use Fn keys to use them and Key travel is short and feedback is very mushy so it is not the best option if you are used to mechanical keyboard or fast/frequent typer. Touchpad very accurate and fast as it comes with Microsoft’s Precision and supports multitouch gestures. Touchpad has a glass surface which is very smooth and the buttons are firm. Screen doesn't have PWM-flickering which is a good thing and it is very bright. Color coverage is above average at 93% sRGB and 60.4 RGB. High brightness and the matte display makes it great for outside usage. Screen is IPS has great viewing angles. Because of how small and light the laptop is it does throttle under intensive work for long period of time over 30 mins in intensive work but in short bursts it works very well. Fan gets loud under heavy work but not to the point where it would be annoying. Sound quality is good but bass is minimal. Battery supports quick charge a big plus and Asus claims it can charge up to 60% in less than 50 mins. Battery life on average usage had from 7.5 to 9.5 hours. In fact Witcher 3 can do a mix of high and Ultra at 60fps. Idk about rdr2 I've heard it's really punishing on hardware but as a general rule I've found the 1650 to do a solid job for the price. If an Xbox one s or a PS4 runs a game at 30fps you can expect the 1650 to run it at 60fps with a little better graphics settings. Honestly most games run great. Crysis 3 does 60fps without even stressing the machine. If it's not known for being especially graphically intensive like Witcher 3 or RDR2 then you can probably run it on high or Ultra if it's a couple years old. But even the heavy hitters like the above mentioned will run 60fps with some settings compromises.

Highly dependent on your main priorities. The blade comes in various different models some of which are designed for gaming and other for productivity. The 1650 Ti model comes with a 120hz display while the regular 1650 model comes with a 60hz display. If you are very picky about your refresh rate then your only choice is the 120hz model. The surface book 2 is a great machine the ergonomics of the tablet to laptop design is great especially for media consumption. However the display is high resolution almost 4k I believe which means most games will look a little blurry when playing at 1080p and the GPU just won't handle anything very well if you try to set the gaming resolution to the native screen resolution. In my opinion id choose depending on this order of priorities 1. Productivity Gaming Media --- go for the blade. 2. Productivity Media Gaming --- go for the surface book.

I would recommend this Acer Swift 3 because of the following it weighs 2.9lbs which is light like you want. The casing made of brushed aluminum and looks very premium. The keyboard is a chiclet keyboard typing on it feels spongy but you get used to it quickly. Drag and drop sometimes doesn't work as intended but that is easily fixed with software. Screen is glossy Full HD IPS with very good viewing angles the screen flickers at 200 Hz in a brightness level of 20%. if you have sensitive eyes might find this unpleasant or you can get a headache if you are really sensitive . The main and maybe only con about this laptop is how dim the screen can get as it is not usable in direct sunlight. Has very good heat management and it doesn't throttle. Speakers provide very clear sounds and the maximum volume is pretty loud. Battery life is very good at around 9-11 hours of usage on light to medium usage. Hi! So you have chosen three amazing products that will definitely satisfy all that you're looking for however you should know that gaming laptops generally don't focus on good quality speakers so I'm afraid most of your chosen products will have around the same bad-average quality speakers. Since you're looking for a light thin and 15-inch laptop with a great display the ASUS Gephyrus 14 is an amazing laptop with the best battery life of ALL gaming laptops in the market right now. It's lightweight and powerful enough to play any game now and upcoming games in the future as well the sound quality is not going to be as impressive as a Macbook so don't get your hopes up on that part. On the Youtube review of the ASUS Gephyrus 14 linked HERE Austin Evans mentions that he doesn't like the keyboard as much so keep that in mind. As for the Gigabyte 15 I personally have the Gigabyte Aero 15 with GTX 1070 Max-Q and although Gigabyte laptops aren't that popular I can tell you that the display to the laptop is amazing and I feel comfortable typing on it's keyboard right now although it's not without it's flaws I'm not a fan of the dedicated numpad that shifts the entire alphabetic keyboard to the left the sound quality is horrible so invest in good headphones. The fan noise of my laptop is very loud and I have to wear noise-cancelling headphones whenever I play games but honestly the fan noise is gonna be loud on all gaming laptops . The temperatures average around 50-60C undervolted and the battery lasts about 6-7 hours. But other than that I love my Gigabyte Aero 15. I'm sure that whichever product you choose it's gonna be a dang good laptop. So if you can't make a choice then choose whichever device that can fill your needs and like the look of the laptop the most.

I would recommend this ASUS Zenbook because of the following The lid is made from brushed metal it can be opened easily with one hand and the case is made from metal as well so overall build quality. The display part flexes easily and the keyboard bends a little if you are hard typer. It is very light at 2.5 lbs it has 2 USB 3 one USB type C HDMI and micro SD. USB type C doesn't support Thunderbolt 3 or charging and it also doesn't support DisplayPort Alternate mode which means you can't connect external monitors using the port. The ram is not upgradeable so what you buy is what you get major con if 8 is not enough for your usage. Keyboard has four-stage backlight and page Up/Down Home and End keys don't have their own keys meaning you would need to use Fn keys to use them and Key travel is short and feedback is very mushy so it is not the best option if you are used to mechanical keyboard or fast/frequent typer. Touchpad very accurate and fast as it comes with Microsoft’s Precision and supports multitouch gestures. Touchpad has a glass surface which is very smooth and the buttons are firm. Screen doesn't have PWM-flickering which is a good thing and it is very bright. Color coverage is above average at 93% sRGB and 60.4 RGB. High brightness and the matte display makes it great for outside usage. Screen is IPS has great viewing angles. Because of how small and light the laptop is it does throttle under intensive work for long period of time over 30 mins in intensive work but in short bursts it works very well. Fan gets loud under heavy work but not to the point where it would be annoying. Sound quality is good but bass is minimal. Battery supports quick charge a big plus and Asus claims it can charge up to 60% in less than 50 mins. Battery life on average usage had from 7.5 to 9.5 hours. I would recommend a 13 inch Ultrabook with either Ryzen 4000U series processors or Intel Icelake 10th gen . These devices are thin and light and will help you greatly as a student Since battery is most important to you when not gaming at 1200 you can get an amazing Ultrabook with 8-9 hours of battery life. The obvious choices for Intel would be a Dell XPS 13 personal recommendation based on your needs XPS 13 2-in-1 HP Envy HP Spectre and Razer Blade Stealth runner up recommendation . DO NOT I REPEAT GET AN LG GRAM. THEY ARE THROTTLING NIGHTMARES. The choices for AMD would be a HP Envy x360 personal recommendation lenovo IdeaPad S540 runner up or a Surface laptop. If you wanna save a quick buck the older Ryzen based APUs Ryzen 3000U are still okay for LoL. 60 fps at 1080p with low-mid settings The Core i7-1065G7 4 core 8 thread is close to a core i5-6500 desktop chip! at 25w you'll be able to game really well on it even if it's igpu slightly higher than a 940mx but slightly below a mx150 is a few tiers lower than the AMD one due to it's mostly strong single core performance. Multitasking may take a hit BUT it supports higher memory clocks 3733 vs 3600 and performs on average better than ryzen in a single channel configuration. The Ryzen 4700U 8 core 8 thread is a multitasking beast goes head to head with a great iGPU on par with the MX150 1D12 but for single core workloads may fall behind depending on if your laptop has dual channel memory. Memory means a lot for ryzen apus. The added benefit is these devices are modern and will last you 4 years. They all have biometric security built in as well.

You want dGPU for those applications. No MBA have them. At a similar price point you can try lower end gaming laptops like the new ASUS TUF A15. dGPU will help a lot in these applications.

Will those apps run on the base i3? Yes. For sure. Will those apps run with performance acceptable to you? Maybe. In the USA upgrading from the i3 to the i5 is only 100 and doubles the number of available cores which will provide a HUGE jump in short-term multicore performance. That is likely a no-brainer upgrade for most people. Why do I say short term? Because any lengthy processor-intensive task which heat-loads the CPU will run right into the MacBook Air’s weak thermal headroom and begin to downshift the CPU frequency. At some point with a sustained heavy load the 4 core i5 and the 2-core i3 end up performing about the same as the limitation becomes how much heat the MacBook Air can dissipate spoiler alert not much . The MacBook Air is really designed for ‘typical’ workloads which just tax the CPU for small bursts. The MBA is more than capable of handling this type of load. Sustained tasks like rendering on the other hand are not well suited to the MBA as it cannot keep its CPU cool enough over longer periods of time. One of my most ongoing head-scratching questions is why Apple does not connect the CPU to the cooling fan with a heat pipe on the 2018-2020 MacBook Airs. Crazy. The prior MacBook Air and all of the MacBook Pros have heat pipes as do virtually all mainstream PC laptops. Is the Base 2020 MBA better than the 2019 MBP? No. The MBA is worse in all but 2 areas. 2019 MacBook Pro is better 4 core 8th gen 25watt CPU vs. 2 core 10th gen 9 watt CPU Higher resolution screen DP3 color space suppport vs. not 100 Nits brighter screen backlight Much better thermal headroom Better speakers 2020 MacBook Air better .25 pound lighter and slightly thinner on one side WAY WAY better keyboard The biggest downside of the 2019 MacBook Pro is the butterfly keyboard but it comes with a 4 year extended warranty.

You'll have a bad time with a dual core MacBook air in 2020.
AVOID the MacBook Airs. Buy the 2020 MacBook Pros instead.

I have a G2-mech 15 which I’m assuming is similar. Fan speed and noise for me for typical use is fine and would be appropriate for a classroom setting. However it does get hot and max out temps around 90C under heavy load gaming. My screen failed and needed to be replaced just after my one year warranty ran out which i suspect was just from heat cooking internal components. After replacing screen the issue appeared again but intermittently. I was able to undervolt my cpu and gpu to lower temps significantly and the issue has subsided. I also game with the fan maxed out which is pretty loud. Max temps were 90C pre undervolt and 75-80C now.
Are you referring to this Eluktronics MAG-15 Slim ?

I have the Eluktronics MAG-15 with 2070 max-q gpu option I bought it when it was released. It has a button for 3 settings power saver gaming and gaming eluktroboost. It also let's you choose between different fan options for each power setting. In the power saver mode there's near-zero fan noise I don't notice it at all. Now when you have either of the gaming power settings on and load up an intensive game the fans ramp up for sure. That being said there's not many options out there that have comparable weight/size that do not make noise when put under load with the same/similar performance. The laptop never overheats it always stays at a normal temperature. It is a great laptop for taking to class because of it's light weight and size. it's less than five pounds which is great. Also since the bezels are quite thin it's footprint is much smaller than other 15.6 in screen laptops I've had in the past which makes it easy to put in/out of a backpack. Also the battery life is great it will last at least a couple of hours if you're gaming. But for just light web browsing/homework assignments/notes it will last around 9 hours which is great if you're going to be in class/on campus for several hours. The power brick is 230w and a pretty big pain if you need to carry it with you but I usually don't need to because the battery life is very good.

Keyboard is quite trackpad is smooth accurate and with dedicated buttons the Audio is also average. Comes with HDMI port 3 USB 3.1 1 USB C combo mich and headspeakers port. Hi for both a good display and good performance within budget I'd go with the Acer Predator Helios 300 It is a very well known and well reviewed device. It comes with a 4-core i5 processor GTX 1660 Ti graphics and a 1080p 15.6 120Hz IPS display. This combination can run modern games as well as photo editing well. The display should have 90% sRGB coverage.

Only the laptop screen determines the 4k and refresh rate. An external screen will have its own color specification and refresh rate. Go to a store and try them out or at least something comparable. For editing you want to focus on RAM and CPU as opposed to video. Honestly the refresh rate is more for gaming but most laptops can't support the screen they come with. At high settings most mobile cards can not push 144hz last time I checked. Be sure you aren't just buying something that you can't utilize.

If you're going to be using an external monitor then splurging for a 4k display on the laptop isn't worth the money and battery life cost and like the other comment says most mobile GPUs can't push above 100 fps on AAA titles anyway so a 144 or 300 Hz screen is a bit of a waste. The most important qualities I'd say are panel brightness and color accuracy so that you don't end up looking at a shit display every time you use your laptop - but again if you're using external monitors then you don't need the absolute best display on the laptop itself per se

The choice really depends on what you are doing. If you are a gamer the high refresh rate panel will be a plus IF you have a graphics card that supports the high refresh rate. And even then most of the time you won’t really notice the difference. On the other hand you will notice the 4K resolution all the time and if you have OLED you will love the color saturation. So for gaming - get 1080p or 1440p and high refresh rate For photo work - get 4k OLED For lots of coding - get 4K LCD

I don't know that much myself but from what I've gathered recently looking to buy one myself a very important metric is screen quality. It's the thing you're going to be staring at all the time so be sure to get a decent one especially because that's where budget laptops tend to cut corners. Make sure your brightness is at least 300 nits Make sure it's not a TN screen Get a decent color gamut and accuracy 70% or better I believe Most other things are dependent on your specific needs. Good luck!

Laptops are usually alot about balance. Sure 4k is nice but your battery will suffer. A 2080 is nice but your battery will suffer. Screen- screen quality should be an IPS screen with 300nit and above being acceptable. As color accurate as possible. 4K screens are pretty but pull too much battery power so it's not usually worth it in such a small screen. 1080p is fine with 60hz if you are not gaming. CPU- Get a capable CPU. AMD Ryzen offers 8 cores for the same power usage as Intel's 4 cores? Get the Ryzen. RAM- 8GB MINIMUM preferably in a dual channel configuration. This will give more bandwidth from the RAM to the CPU. 16GB or above is ideal. GPU- most gamers love high framerates for smooth gameplay especially in first person shooters.amd and Intel both have integrated graphics which are tiny chips that can run the display and play games. At least the Vega iGPU can game. The Intel iGPU is a joke you can't game for the most part. Those are low powered basic iGPU. Dedicated GPU are additional bigger graphics chips that are more powerful and push alot of frames. For gamers and content creatovideo editors. A dedicated GPU is a must because the software uses the graphics card to help do the work. If you don't game hard or don't due heavy video editing you can get by with an integrated GPU. Storage laptops should only have SSDs nowadays. HDD have mechanical moving parts and use alot more power to make those parts move than an SSD which is just a chip. Typically 256GB should be the minimum. Build quality- this is up to the consumer typically you want a metal or aluminum body as it's more sturdy but usually more expensive. Plastic sturdy laptop chassis can work too but will feel cheaper BUT they are more cost effective. Some users care about the plastic feeling? Others not but either way it should be sturdy and not flex too much. Ports- should have as many ports as they can give you usually high end models have multiple USBC or thunderbolt ports but medium ones are now using USBC along with USB A and HDMI ports. Try to have at least 1 USBC and 1 USBA 3.1 and up port.

I've heard that this is a really good gaming laptop that should last you a long time as Lenovo has pretty good build quality and the Legion is reasonably priced for the specs. Throttling is when your laptop basically forces the CPU to slow down to conserve battery and keep the laptop cool as well as keep the laptop as quiet as possible. Throttling issues happen when the laptop unsuccessfully throttles causing a loss in performance or does it too much that it's noticeable and doesn't offer a good experience. Most reviews don't say anything about throttling issues but if you hear a lot about it then I would say that it's not a great thing to have in a laptop so steer clear. As far as the fans go I'm pretty sure reviewers said that the fans would turn on noticeably for short periods of time but then would stay quiet for the most part so I guess you could say it's like a regular laptop for today's standards. Really depends on what you’re looking for. The processor is going to be your main workhorse for most tasks. The i5/Ryzen 5 should be good for the most part but if you’re doing more intensive stuff and want to future proof yourself the i7/Ryzen 7 would be a better choice. Also for Ryzen I would definitely get the 4000 series huge step up from the 3000 series. Intel hasn’t really changed much since the 8th gen currently in 10th GPU is what you’re going to need for games or any graphic intensive stuff. If you’re really trying to game I would look at the 1660ti minimum and the RTX series 2060-2060 would all run current AAA games at a good frame rate. If yo don’t need that much gaming power then maybe a q640 or 1050 would be good or lower if it’s just basic games you want to run. Most dedicated GPUs will be able to run most creative software so you could get a less powerful one than I listed above. although if it gets more intensive you may need a better GPU like one for the games Neither the GPU or CPU can be upgraded on laptops save for like the Alienware a51 which runs for like 4k Ram is going to be crucial in order to run intensive games and more intensive software/big data sets. You could get away with 8 but I would recommend at least 16 to give yourself some wiggle room and future proof yourself. Dual channel ram 2 stocks gives better performance than single channel so be on the lookout for that when purchasing. Ram is relatively cheap though so if you find a steal of a deal for a laptop without your desired amount of ram you can get 2 8gb sticks of ram for like 70 and it’s easy to upgrade. Also cheaper for you to do yourself than it is to upgrade Storage is important for speed too. NVMe is the fastest. SSd still fast but not quite as fast as the NVMe. HDD is slow and I would recommend against it unless your laptop also has a ssd that it can use for your operating system so it boots up quick. A lot of laptops have extra storage bays though and storage is also cheap 1tb SSD can be found for around 100 little more or less depending on brand. Screen is the last real important conponent and it’s important because you’re going to be staring at it all the time. 1080p is pretty much minimum and you can go up to 1440p if your budget allows. 4K is cool too but I feel that 4K and even 1440p isn’t that important on a laptop because the screens are pretty small. 1440p would be great to have though although it may be pricier than it’s worth. Higher resolutions also drain your battery faster too so keep that in mind. Next is screen refresh. 60hz is ok if you get a lower end graphics card as you might not push that boundary much anyway. I would recommend a 120 or 144hz screen instead though as it makes your display look great and you can play less intensive games at higher fame rates and high end games as well if the GPU is strong enough. Battery life isn’t always great on gaming laptops but most manufacturers post the typical battery life so you can see what you prefer. I like to have more battery in case I’m not near an outlet but if you want to game you won’t really be able to on battery for more than an hour or 2 even with the high capacity battery laptops. Thermals are important but you can usually fix that with software and lotions run warm for the most part anyway compared to desktops. I would recommend getting a laptop with some fan control but that is pretty typica in gaming laptops and not so much on other types Then it’s pretty much preference. Metal builds last longer and are more premium. Keyboards aren’t necessarily subjective but it is still up to your preference. Most trackpads have the windows drovers so they’ll act pretty much the same but some are better than others. Pretty easy fix with a mouse though. Weight/form factor is whatever you want it to be.

Fun story about those remotes I worked in a college IT department and kept getting called down to a classroom for an issue with the classroom lighting system. The lights could be turned on and off with a touch panel on the “smart cart” combination of computer document camera dvd/vcr and for some reason the lights would turn on and off in the middle of class. No other room had ever had that problem. No one could figure out what was going on until one of our interns realized that the classroom was the only one with a Mac. We decided to try to investigate other things that might be different about that room. Our intern came to my office one day and said “Hey I know this is going to sound crazy but the lighting issue is caused by this Mac remote.” Sure enough that remote used the same signal that the touch panel used to control the lights. Mystery solved. We threw that damn thing in the garbage. TLDR That Mac remote was interfering with our classroom lighting system.
When I opened the box and saw that I thought “why am I ever gonna need that?” It’s amazing how much I used it after that.
