A white screen with a question mark might mean that the boot drive cannot be found. What is the year and model of the mac?

Hmmm there are ways you could do that but I think it would over-complicate things for no real gain. If it hangs when it boots from USB you've probably got a bigger issue - could it be that the hard drive is dead altogether? What year and model are we looking at? Target disk mode would help a lot but then again you'd need another Mac to use it usefully.

The hard drive is probably a potato at this point and an iMac from 2007 would be considered obsolete and this will not get any support from Apple. The best thing you can do at this point is buy a repair toolkit open it up to replace the HDD and put snow leopard or lion on it.

For reference Catalina runs on 2012 MacBook Airs so from that one could expect upgrades for at least 7-8 years after release. There’s a much rumored ARM transition being discussed and if it’s a full transition it could cut that lifespan short by a year or two. But getting rid of Intel entirely doesn’t seem likely since there aren’t exactly ARM equivalents to Mac Pro and iMac Pro CPUs. So I think you’ll get a minimum of 3 more years of updates your machine but likely more.

Depending on what you use it for it might give you good service even after the OS stops getting updates. I have a 2012 Mac Pro that stops at Mojave. Mojave still gets security patches but nothing else. That machine still pulls it’s weight regardless in its role as a media server vm server etc. I have a 2003 iMac that’s stops at Leopard. It still has uses besides just being fun and running old games. It’s better although slower than my newer Macs at certain tasks. If having only 8GB doesn’t make your computer seem slow now chances are your use case may be well served even beyond the 8 year updateable life.

The 15” 2015 with dedicated GPU might be a good options for better graphics but I wouldn’t consider it much of a gaming machine. I think most people install Windows to use for gaming but it wouldn’t play today’s AAA titles on high settings like a gaming laptop would. Your air is very portable. A 15” retina is quite a bit bigger and heavier. If you want something for gaming I recommend a windows machine.

I gotcha about saving money. I went with the 16GB and then returned it after I found out that Final Cut Pro needs 32GB for optimal performance. Depends on your use case. Do you need an i9? You'll need to list your use case for anyone to give you proper advice.

To add to everyone else’s comments which I agree with you are doing Uni work? Does that mean Safari web browsing Microsoft Word PDF reading and annotation? If so then any computer can do that. 8GB RAM is enough but I would keep it safe at 16GB RAM. If you’re pushing a lot of data video data or RAW photo data and you do it daily then you’ll want 32GB RAM. 16GB is enough but 32GB will give your CPU more overhead for those kinds of tasks. If you only do the occasional photo or video project 16GB is enough. If you do only occasional video/photo projects the 6-core i7 is enough. Basically start with the the base configuration i7/16GB RAM/512GB/Storage/5300 GPU. This is overkill for Uni work but a fine computer none the less. Now ask yourself what daily task necessitates upgrades and go from there.

The main big excuse to get 10th gen is gaming capabilities. 2nd would be video editing. The 8th gen is otherwise just as capable for a massive price savings. This guy recently did a comparison that might have the info you are looking for.

A common misconception is that the MBA has the better processor for being 10th gen. This is because of Intel's horrible branding. The MacBook Air uses Intel's low power Y-series chips that run at 7W-15W and lower clocks. The MacBook Pro although they are 8th gen use U-series chips that run at 15-25W and will outperform the 10th Gen Air except in Graphics performance where any 10th gen chip blows previous chips out of the water thanks to the new Gen11 GPU . Also thermals matter a lot in real world performance and a properly cooled 8th gen will outperform a 10th gen where the heatsink isn't connected to the fan.
MBP all the way. The new air is garbage with the i7 it absolutely cannot cool itself and will throttle and ramp the fan all the way up if you start to multitask or so demanding tasks.

Depends on what it did. That includes what apps were running before you close the lid what are the external devices connected to it how frequently do you receive internet based messages whether there are software updates and how good is your internet connection. MacBooks will keep active after its lid closes. It's called Standby mode and will only fall sleep after a certain amount of time. Even during sleep it will keep doing regular maintenance tasks and internet syncing. It's a feature called Power Nap On a new machine it can easily get a lot of works done during standby since it needs time to finish things like cache and log cleanup VM paging file system check spotlight index app updating photo music syncing Time Machine backup etc etc. If you're suspecting that your battery is malfunction turn off Power Nap and change the sleep mode and standby delay

Technically it shouldn't happen. 1. Browsers will always notify user when something is downloaded even it's automatically triggering download from the Javascript codes. 2. Even you accidentally downloaded malware it's only a bulk of file on the disk and will do nothing without activating it. 3. There is no known way for Javascript codes in a web page to launch processes outside of the browser. However in real world people can always find undiscovered bugs and glitches in OS and apps and sometimes these will be used to exploit against the security defense of your computer. We called these type of attacks Zero-day attack which means the rest of us will only know the existence of this vulnerability after being attacked. And since these vulnerabilities is previously unknown it's almost impossible to defend these attacks from nowhere. That's why the security measure of a computer system is shifting from install anti-virus setup firewall to how fast can you patch the security hole in the past decade. It's very crucial to keep your system update-to-date. Attackers and software venders are playing the cat-and-mouse game eternally and consumers can only catch up with them.

Since the mid 2000’s Apple renamed their line to “notebooks” or “portables”. As cpu’s can and will get upwards of 80-90 Celsius under load. Hi First idea I've had similar issues with my mac having worse and worse wifi reception over the past 2-3 years. Turns out the flats around me are upgrading routers and wifi interference is getting worse as more people have powerful routers blasting wifi into my flat. Is your wifi network 2 4 or 5 ghz? If possible use a 5ghz network to avoid excessive interference. You can check this by holding alt and hovering over the wifi icon in the top right of your mac desktop. Here click open wireless diagnostics then when a window pops up go to the top left and click window. You should see an option to Scan. Click this and do a scan. How many networks do you see? If you sort by RSSI is your network showing the lowest negative number? -30 means better signal than -80 for example. Let me know! If you see networks here that have similar RSSI numbers to your network they're on the same channel and frequency then you might need to adjust your wifi through your router. My tactic is to narrow the channel width of my wifi if there's lots of interference. Say the default width is 40Mhz but this means that you might overlap with other wifi networks and get bad signal stability. Lower it to 20 Mhz and you'll lose some connection speed but gain stability. Second idea Not sure about the air but macbooks usually have wifi antennas in their displays with a small coax cable connecting the antenna to the logic board. This cable run through the hinge of the display and has a change to slowly degrade as you open/close your laptop. I'd unscrew the bottom of the laptop and see if it looks worn. I have similarly bad reception with my retina macbook. I have a few spots in the house where the wifi works great due to low interference narrow channel width I set up in my router. However if I go farther interference from other wifi networks will throw me off my wifi. Ultimate solution wire up. Get an ethernet cable and run it from your router to your desk and get an ethernet to mini-displayport or ethernet to thunderbolt adapter depending on which connector your air has .

are you using a single router? or a mesh network? and is the house a single level multi level brick? as those can cause interference at longer ranges. while 5Ghz is a faster connection interference due to environmental factors can be more prevelent on 5ghz 2.4 has a little easier time going longer distance. the issue sound 2 fold. since you're having wifi connection issue with MULTIPLE devices you at least know its THE NETWORK and not your MBA for that issue. since you said yours was having trouble connecting to hotspots provided they were in close proximity you could have issues with wifi SETTINGS. x200B

I am faster on the Mac with multiple screen plus terminal plus docker. I used Mac Windows Linux plus other OSes MacOS vs Windows - On a foundational level MacOS is more stable from UI quirks point of view. Unix foundation is solid uptime is rock solid similar to SunOS. - Windows still have issue with multiple screen scaling. A lot depends on hardware you pick - Windows is moving toward the MacOS route with Linux subsystem winget package manager kinda like apt-get and recently Windows terminal lol - looks like a wrapper of PowerShell DOS prompt and Linux terminal - PowerShell has a good feature of passing objects instead of string - MacOS can be locked pretty tight with the available encryption you can argue Windows too but Windows is a patchwork of security app which is hard to be certain. Window custom build - not sure if this refers to Hackintosh. If so Cost is pretty close to the real thing once you get all the nice parts. Then you’ll appreciate what goes in in designing a good system. Easy to make things go fast if speed is what you are after it’s harder to make them work well together. I was never completely satisfied with my build. If you are after a build with ECC memory for example your choices are pretty limited. - down side is software upgrade when apple upgrade the OS they sometime throws a curve ball to the Hackintosh community which they hit fine the community is great in that respect. From my experience it’s a matter of your times do you want to fidgit with it or are you on the “done that moving on” mode. Ultimately MacOS save time for me and doesn’t have UI peeves. Windows is getting there multi touch still lags behind on smoothness UI still lag behind etc. personally Windows is at least 5 years behind. Microsoft commitment to a tighter release schedules is good. New features are heading in a better direction. Although they have more options to customize i feel you get more control on Mac. —- good GUI Unix under — done

I JUST made this similar switch a few days ago. And let me put the TL DR upfront TL DR OS X is a drastically less mature and capable desktop experience vs Windows 10. Ok so with that bombshell out of the way. I sold both my gaming laptop and desktop and grabbed a new Macbook Pro 16 Larger screen and better gaming on 5500m Debating returning it for a base 2020 MBP 13 as I do not really need the extra power cause I will game with Shadow and Stadia. Anyways overall learning mac stuff has been fun and interesting. The VMware fusion experience is DRASTICALLY cleaner than anything I have used on Windows. BUT not as capable in some areas. Like you can't present 16 threads to the VM as 16 cores. WHY? . Now to be clear I got this mainly for the MUCH better laptop experience Apple hardware and features offer. The track pad and Battery handling is SO much better than any Windows PC. Like playing games on the trackpad is not just possible I did it for an hour and it was a pretty 'not shit' experience in Destiny2! Stadia . Here are the things OS X totally FAIL at vs the Win10. - Multi Display handling - Connecting and disconnecting displays. - Updates and patches. - Arranging windows. - Swapping out windows. - Swapping between 2 windows. - Waking from sleep. - Re-installing the OS. - Re-paring a bad patch. - Apps crash and it is a PAIN to deal with vs a Win10 crash. - over zealous security preventing you from doing lots of little things. Remember the early days of Vista UAC... that but even worse. We are talking 20 minutes of OS adjustments and BIOS changes to do something as simple as apply an image to an SD card for a raspberry pi. and then you get to undo all of those things to re-secure it. And those are just my issues in 4 days. - So lets start with multi screen. You cannot turn off extra displays unless you power them down or unplug them. - Connecting a display can take a long time to recognize if ever. - Updates are like the Windows XP days. Forever to download and 40 minutes to apply. - Arranging windows is a horrid experience Microsoft patented the tech and the solution in OS X is horrendous if you are used to it in 10. - Working between multiple windows is a joke as you need to click to interact with the window vs Windows 10 which is aware of what window you want to work on most of the time by simply mousing over it. Something as simple as pausing a youtube video in another window requires 2-3 clicks. small but HYPER unnecessary! I can take a 10 year old garbage PC and have windows 10 up and running on it in about 20-30 minutes. a High end PC can be up and running from a blank disk in 10-15 minutes A clean install on a top end mac takes 1-2 hours! - Waking from sleep is a crap shoot. It forgets what is plugged in changes main display loses displays loses the mouse. It is a NIGHTMARE! I just told it to NEVER sleep except in laptop only mode. - It has failed to install updates TWICE! and took an hour to repair both times. resulting in some apps failing to launch and thus how I discovered how bad the clean install process is. Aaaaaaaand. None of these are stopping me from wanting to keep going. Using windows in a VM in unity mode gives me a DRASTICALLY improved desktop experience. And bootcamping into windows for other usability issues. is fine. If you do go mac. Save your receipt / get it from a place with a friendly return policy. Cause OS X is no where near as smooth as Windows 10 in MANY areas. Sadly. when it comes to the basic desktop experience. Windows 10 just works. EDIT Yes so far the Laptop experience has been totally worth all of these issues and learning experiences. IF I was desktop only though.... I would not go mac.

usability of machines will ALWAYS be based on YOUR usage. if your workload does not require newer machines with more cores or large amounts of RAM faster ram than you can get away with older models with lower specs for a longer period of time . that would be anything related to the average person specs internet word/presentation creation watching videos online light h.264 video editing or photo editing. that can be done on Macs that are 10 years old with little slow down. friends and clients I know who buy MacBook airs are literally buying it for portability not for speed power throughput or longevity. they buy it with AppleCare and WITHIN that 3 years of warranty they're going to be selling that MBA and getting the latest one. so they always have a device that can be dropped off to Apple under warranty for repair if needed MBA cooling is something of a joke I believe the fan on the latest one isn't even attached to a heat pipe for the cpu. so if thermals ARE a concern long rendering at max load or longevity in having the Mac for 5-7 years id lean towards the 13 with the 10th Gen cpus x200B to get you a MORE specific answer we'll need to know your workload usage types and if portability is a priority over properly powered device. or if its just budget constraints

A higher-specced system is always more future proof in a sense in that it will perform to somewhat modern standards for a longer span of time. From my experience MBP 2017 cooling isn't exactly satisfactory anyways so I wouldn't worry about the MBA being worse - I literally cannot imagine it being worse unless it's just no cooling .

I have a 7 yo mba and it is still very useable. It depends on how you treat your machines and what you try to do on them. Anything that needs a lot of power will streSs an mba more than an mbp leading to risks of early failure. Applecare can help with the uncertainty but is only for three years.

Had the keyboard lying around a bit because i couldn't use it. Wanted to connect to my Mac and wouldn't turn on. Wanted to check for the batteries but can't open the lid. It's stuck because some acid leaked an now clogs up the thread. Scratched some of it off the lid. Already tried to open by force but only damaged the lid. Has anyone got some ideas to remove the driedup acid? You can't imagine how thankful I'd be!!!
Tried heating with hair dryer and cooling with „blade ice“. Didn‘t work yet. All I got is a bent coin. Lacking some hard plastic I’ll keep on trying.
Mix a little baking soda with water and drip it onto the threads. It should dissolve the battery acid
Try spraying a small amount of WD40 into the cracks and wait 10-15 seconds for it to seep in.
A coin and brute force
Try heating it up first with a hair dryer to loosen up the thread. Good luck!
Here’s a similar but opposite idea from one above try freezing it to shrink the metal maybe that’ll shrink and separate the cap/plug from shell/body.

You could try to get small amount of something on a cotton swab that will dissolve the spill and let tiny drip into that thread. Also don’t use metal objects to open that - aluminum is very soft so you’ll dent it. Use plastic instead.
A friend gave me a number pad with the same design that had this problem. I tried all sorts of things and never succeeded in opening it.
I removed the small plastic panel underneath and managed to pull the batteries out after removing the internal electronics.
I would look for an adjustable spanner wrench for the best leverage on it. More torque to the cap better grip on the slot.
OP don’t forget this isn’t a typical screw type thread in there. There’s also a loaded ball “lock” that may be frozen as well.

I got a used wireless apple keyboard for 5 online and ended up taking the automotive approach on that battery door. That is after attempting to heat it with a small torch and then I tried some penetrating oil more heat that stuff removes corrosion really well and frees of threads . Put a quarter in the slot and used pliers to get some leverage. None of that worked so I just took a big drill bit and attempted to drill out the battery door with the idea I’d order another then I hammered a bolt extractor into the hole and attempted to pry it open. Did nothing except bend the keyboard and wear out the end of my bolt extractor. That thing was stuck and nothing on earth was ever going to make it come out. The acid probably melted the two materials together or something. I’ll probably pry all the keys and sell them on eBay for a few dollars

Working in IT with many many Macs over the years this is how these keyboards die. I’ve never been able to properly clean a fully leaked battery out without damaging the keyboard. I have a tall pile of these keyboards and the matching trackpads with this situation.

You need to find something stationary to fit in the slot and turn the keyboard on that instead of turning a coin and holding the keyboard still. Like put a nickel in a vice put the slot down on it and turn the keyboard.

Hey guys! Thank you so much for your support! Meanwhile I could remove the second battery from the keyboard. I let it sit with some vinegar on top for one night changed it couple times during the day. Then for last night I put some WD-40 on it and again let it sit for the night. Now I can see the lid from the inside. All clogged up by the remains. Will fill with vinegar again and wait what’s gonna happen!

Use vinegar to slowly soak in you need to give it time to loosen hours even . Soak a cloth with the vinegar and leave it on the case with the case turned up so the vinegar soaks downwards into the screw thread. Find a tool/coin/key that is a really snug fit to slot and you can grip really well. Then instead of trying to open it fully just try and get it to move a little wiggle it back and forth with short motions and just work at it. Hope you get it open. When you do give it a really good soak inside with vinegar to neutralise the leaked acid it will stop fizzing when there is no more reaction .

In 2019 Apple decided to remove/replace the .kext files from operating system and use instead .dext files to communicate to usb. But the applications using usb should be modified to allow .dext files instead. Such .dext are already present in Catalina. The reason for such move is enhanced security and the reliability of the operating system - the driver is removed from the kernel where it can crash and instead only the application which needs that must use it. Bluetooth operates at frequencies between 2.402 and 2.480 GHz or 2.400 and 2.4835 GHz which is in the same range for 2.4GHZ wifi devices. issue could be environmental meaning existing wifi networks are fighting for the same frequency. that Is the most common issue especially in cities/ apartment buildings. you can attempt bluetooth reset that may help. How to Reset Your Mac's Bluetooth Module 1. Holding the Shift Option Alt keys on your Mac's keyboard click the Bluetooth symbol in the top-right corner of the macOS menu bar. ... 2. Locate the revealed Debug submenu and hover your mouse cursor over it. 3. Click Reset the Bluetooth module. 4. Now restart your Mac .

The main difference is that Macs don’t have a walled garden. You can install whatever you like as long as macOS binaries exist or you can compile the code yourself. With iPads you’re limited to the App Store. You also have the ability to dual boot Windows 10 Linux or whatever OS you want to use. Also you can actually multitask on Macs while this is much more limited on iPads. Even though the iPad Pro has much more RAM today and multitasking has improved Macs still have a huge advantage in this regard.

Nothing compares to a full 27” screen and window based multitasking. Illustration is a great reason to have an iPad Pro but an iMac is vastly more productive for some of the other tasks you mentioned. Not just by a little. A LOT.

Hi! Start by checking her iCloud Drive. Often files are backed up there form desktop documents and other folders on your Mac. A similar issue I came across here was solved by the files being backed up and being recovered from there. One thing you can do If you boot the Mac into recovery mode is open disk utility instead of reinstall macOS. Here you have the option to select your hard drive and run first aid. This can remedy software based hard drive issues and might diagnose some hardware ones. If you can’t find your files first air doesn’t help and your data is sensitive take it to a professional data recovery business. Unfortunately I can’t recommend one / If indeed your HDD Is the source of the issue replacing it with an SSD and adding some Ram to the Mac will give it a lot more usability. Did it to my 2011 Mac a few years ago still works great. You can do this at home with the right tools and patience but if you’re not handy with electronics Apple or a local repair shop can probably also help. It’s certainly not difficult and perfectly doable so don’t be intimidated if DIY is your only option. The SSD you linked is from a brand I’m not familiar with. I’d recommend Western Digital Seagate or Kingston drives from personal experience.

I can get you part of the way there. Open spotlight Cmd-Space or hit the magnifying glass icon top-right on the menu bar and search for Screen Sharing . It should show up as the top hit. Drag the icon to a blank space in the dock to the left of the separator line. Or in the Finder you can hit the Go menu Go to Folder... and go to the folder /System/Library/CoreServices/Applications and drag the icon from there to the dock. You can launch previous screen sharing sessions by Control-Clicking the dock icon and they should be listed there by host name.
You have to turn it on in System Preferences Mouse. Mac mouses are single button by default since 1984.
Open spotlight by clicking CMD-spacebar. Then type “mouse” and click return. Check the “Secondary click” box and you’re good to go.
Go into system preferences and click mouse. Then set right click
Go into settings and you can configure it how you want from there.

Well I think you should get the Intel Core i5 because the i7 and i5 won’t have too many differences the performance is mostly the same. On the other hand I’d buy the 16 gigs of ram instead of the i7. It’s way more future proof and it’s good to have more performance. In my knowledge the SSD size doesn’t affect the performance at all.

No a 256GB SSD won't give different performance than a 512GB SSD unless one SSD is faster than the other. The amount of secondary SSD storage only affects how much you can store on your internal SSD not the performance. I do agree on going with the i5 since you're not going to see a difference in performance with an i7 unless you are doing compute bound tasks like video editing. You will get more heat and higher power usage with an i7 though which isn't as good for battery or component life...more heat is not a good thing for electronics. Also causes your fans to run more and make more noise which isn't great either. For me my Mac has a 250GB internal SSD that's really fast. And I have an external 512GB Samsung X5 SSD NVMe that's also very fast. So lots of fast storage. Great system. And get the 16GB of RAM memory if you can afford it that's really useful these days. I find that when I'm just running a browser the memory runs at about 10 GB in use. Of course I like to have lots of browser tabs open all the time rather than opening and closing browser tabs all the time.

In short yes in the long term there is a penalty. Buy 256 if you are really sure you will never be close to its limit capacity. SSDs have a specific amount of times that each block can be written before becoming an unusable block. SSDs internal controllers try to balance this by writing into the blocks that have less amount of writes count they do this to try to maintain an uniform wear of all blocks. Bigger SSD drives have higher expectancy lifetime because they have more blocks to distribute data into and wear less individual blocks. Also as an SSD goes full it speed goes down because of an extra effort needed by the controller to do its job when writing. Personally my 256GB “died” during an MacOS update I suspect because was almost full most of the time and blocks wear too much. 512 is doing better for my professional needs.

I answered a very similar question about this on Ask Different recently. You oversubscribed the power on the USB bus. Those bus powered “hubs” use the cheapest components read that as most inefficient and they’re being asked to be a converter from DisplayPort to HDMI an ethernet port and whatever else USB device that gets plugged into it. My recommendation since that many peripheral devices were needed was to go with the CalDigit TS3 Thunderbolt dock. Yes. You’re referring to it as a USB-C dock which is incorrect. USB-C is just the physical port type not the actual connection. This is a Thunderbolt dock connected to the Thunderbolt/USB-C port. Being that it’s thunderbolt you’re now connecting over the PCIe bus and using a totally separate source of power. Those little hubs are great for quickly attaching a device here and there. They’re not meant to act as a replacement for a bona fide dock that turns your laptop into a desktop.

I'm an Apple authorised service technician and I've just probably seen too many hard disks going bad. And I also knew that the HD failing will take down the Fusion Drive completely no chance of data recovery. So when I got my iMac in 2014 it had FD but I immediately reformatted it with separate disks. I installed the system apps and my profile on the Flash Storage and stored big data such as iTunes photo libraries videos and DVD rips on the large HD. I saved up and a year later I replaced the 1 TB HD with 2 TB SSD and upgraded memory to 32 GB . It still goes well and now I use the Flash as a temporary drive i.e. for Downloads folder. Now 2014 models had 128 GB flash. It is not the case any more - 1 TB FD has only 32 GB. I assume it would work OK for a while with the most often used system parts applications and user files such as caches fitted to the SSD partition. But you will soon experience the slowdowns. I would just try to avoid that last century tech spinning generation vibrations noise and extra heat but if I had to choose between 2 TB Fusion for 200 or 256 GB SSD for 100 I would probably go for ... 512 GB SSD for 300 🙂 especially if it's going to be a shared Mac where eventually family pictures and videos will be. Avoid hard disks avoid FD go full in SSD. BTW there are cheaper external SSDs today on USB-C such as Samsung T5.

It's a little bit confusing but things basically work out like this The physical MacBook connector is USB-C. This port support both the USB 3.1 10 Gbit/s and Thunderbolt 3 40 Gbit/s protocols protocol how data is sent over the wire . Other PCs may or may not support both USB and Thunderbolt on their USB-C connectors. Your external HD uses USB 3.0 so should work just fine with a regular USB 3.0 cable. Also note that it seems to be a HDD rather than SSD so the USB 3.0 speed is more than enough to use the HD at its full speed. Thunderbolt 3 cables are more expensive but also support higher speeds this is useful for things like eGPUs and some Thunderbolt based external SSDs. USB-C - USC-A adapters if needed should be cheap but ensure that they support USB 3.0/3.1.
The amazon basic cable should be fine. You don’t need thunderbolt speed for that drive.

If you look at the legal copy at the bottom of MacBook’s and every other product technical specifications listing it says that the actual formatted capacity is less. “1GB 1 billion bytes and 1TB 1 trillion bytes actual formatted capacity less.”
The file system itself takes up space. The same is true for any formatted drive.
It will never show the exact GB as system files OS will allocate space and recovery partition. It is also the same for windows machine. So it is normal.
Discrepancies in sizing is often to do with the unit of measurement. A Megabyte is not the same as a Mebibyte. Etc etc.
Yes because when you allow for the way it’s worked in bytes and it’s actually 512gb in bytes

You're trying to boot to Internet Recovery. My first question would be why are you booting it this way or does the Mac automatically boot to this? If you're trying to boot this way intentionally and if you have a newer Mac with the T2 security chip and if an Apple ID is signed in to the iCloud prefs with Find My turned on internet Recovery can be blocked. Or the network you're using isn't acceptable for this type of boot like a captive wifi network or one that uses open or WEP security. If you're not trying to boot this way intentionally then there's a problem preventing the Mac from booting even the local Recovery from the internal drive. What events led up to this point beforehand?

I have some of those small scratches on my macbook. Nearly all of them are on the bottom of my mac. I finally figured out that because the aluminum is so close to touching whatever surface you put it on it scratches very easily. I first figured this out when I moved my macbook across a table and a very loud screeching noise occurred. Really pissed me off and now I have a really big scratch on the bottom. Only solution is to set you mac down on a mat maybe a leather case when you use it or have a clean surface. I think I have zero scratches on the keyboard area. Rest of them are on the side because I hit it a bunch of times by accident over the years.

I don’t know why no one is providing a possible reason but I have a few similar scratches on my MacBook as well one of them is on a fairly similar spot to yours. I’m not sure about your situation but I found that dust and small particles get trapped in the speaker holes and from used of opening and closing they can become dislodged and scratch the aluminium during the process of closing the screen. My solution I have been using for a couple of months is to get one of these micro fibre covers
scratches don’t pop out of nowhere something scratched your computer.

Ice lake 10th gen 10nm has lower base and boost clocks than whiskey lake 8th gen 14nm because intel has a semi-broken 10nm process which they've been unable to scale to high clock speeds. However because 10nm needs less power to get the same work done it can boost for longer within the same thermal envelope so in practice it does actually perform better unless you're keeping the CPU's pegged with a sustained workload and cause it to clock down to base clocks which is hard to do with any real world workload . And because it is 10nm it has more room for additional transistors which intel has used to beef up the on-chip graphics. That's why the gpu is a lot faster on ice lake than whiskey lake. You can compare the benchmarks between the 2019 and 2020 models

Oh damn - that's a tricky one because it depends on what Boot Camp did and then on specifically what your mate did. If he deleted the MacOS partition doesn't necessarily mean he deleted the recovery partition if OS X creates them for this model? so it might worth holding the Apple key and R as you start up and praying. Other than that you'll need to flash a bootable image of the OS X Installer from Windows to a USB stick. I have never had to do that but surely someone on this forum has! Finally depending on what your mate did exactly you mightl want to reformat the whole disk again reinstall OS X and then carefully try the whole Bootcamp shabang again from the top. This is because on these earlier models my understanding is that Boot-Camp creates a very funky work-around hybrid partition table to that both OS X and Windows can understand it. If anything other than X's partitioning tools have been used to modify that drive it will have messed with it.

Your question needs a bit more elaboration in my honest opinion. How long do you plan to use it years ? What is it that you study? More directly under what workloads are you going to put the computer? What lineup are you considering? Airs or Pros? With that out of the way I want to give my two cents to this hopefully going-to-be-thriving discussion based on what information you have already given . If you ask me you can do three things i save up more money and buy a more recent MacBook I would strictly go for pros . ii You can buy a decent MBP 13 2015 for €500 which is a decent option in the MacBook lineup. iii I do not know whether or not you considered Windows PC laptops but you may could give those a go. Now hear me out about the third option before you smash a downvote. I am fully aware that you specifically came to the Mac subbreddit with this question from which I can infer that you only considered MacBooks. The only reason why I am brining up PC laptops is simply to make sure that you truly evaluated every option you have at you disposal and came to the conclusion that a MacBook is your best bet. MBs are good if not very good laptops in my opinion but depending on you location and budget they might be a less optimal/riskier choice. Repair cost/availability as a prime example . If you considered all of this than simply ignore the third option I brought up and let's continue with the former two. Personally if I was in a similar situation - in dire need of a laptop with a €500 budget and commited to buying a MacBook - I would go with a 2015 MBP 13 . Those machines will get a year or two of support before becoming vintage and can still hold up just fine to today's standards. Their screens also blew that of the pre2018 MBAs' straight out of the water. The reason why I wouldn't necessarily choose to wait save up more is simply that on the MBA lineup which I don't recommend the first real choice is the current 2020 model - 2018 and 2019 models have butterfly keyboards and apart form the better screen don't really offer anything more than the 2017 or older models - but they do cost more. The Pro lineup is similar - 2016-2017 models have flexgate problem and the 1st gen butterfly keyboards. The 2018 and 2019 models are more solid in that regard but still rock the same KBs. All in all if you were to choose to save up the first modell I could recommend was a 2018 MBP but not with a warm heart - but they go around double your budget. Two words about the butterfly keyboard they are not 100% to fail. But the presence of this type of keyboard is still a risk factor that I would avoid if I was the spend the money the go around for. To sum it all up I would probably buy a 2015 MacBook Pro 13 based on the info you gave. x200B EDIT added and commited to buying a MacBook

Are you asking the antique EDID no recognized problem ? Basically if you can set to native resolution in Display settings you won't have blur text. Problem is computer recognize external display model by EDID which is acquired when you plugged it in if the EDID of that monitor is not listed in macOS supported device data list it wouldn't recognize the device model and some special resolution won't be listed in the options. So it's not the problem of 24 inch monitors in general but each individual model. You should search using the model codename and check its macOS compatibility. If you don't even know the model or not willing to do that buy a 3rd party driver tool called SwitchResX And if it still no works unlikely you can still generate a custom display profile following this instruction

Leave MacOS on the SSD. There is absolutely zero benefit to moving it to the hard drive. Go into Disk Utility select the hard drive itself not any partitions that may be underneath it then hit Erase. It should bring you to a pop-up menu and it will ask what format you want to set the drive as. Select either APFS or Mac OS Extended Journaled. Erase the drive and that should activate it as a secondary drive for you to store additional apps/documents/photos/whatever on.

Man it's a 2012 machine 4K resolution is not existed at that time. The industrial standard was finalized after this machine was released and the world's first 4K monitor was shipped in end 2013. What can you expect ?

1. Screenshots mechanism is changed. Now a screenshot will delay for 5 seconds before it's actually saved as a file so that you can interact with the capture data to annotate on it or transfer to other apps without saving as a file. And after it's actually saved as a file sometimes it will have another random delay before it shows un on the desktop. Read 2 for explanation why the delay. 2. It's normal that a newly created file will take several seconds before it shows on the desktop because each individual file icon on desktop is not just a plain data block but a dynamically changing window . Each single file will be monitored as a individual tracking handler in WindowServer system service. So it's actually not a good practice to have a lot of files on desktop because each file will takes up some system resources both memory and CPU. 3. Recent Finder window is the result of Spotlight search. It won't change until the spotlight index is updated. It's designed for you to search for files quickly not a tool for managing files. You should go the exact path that store these files instead. 4. As explained in 2 there will be an inevitable delay before the icon shows up on desktop. Sometimes the delay would be quite long. If you want to force Finder update desktop press Shift CMD N to create a new folder on desktop.

Firstly which Macbook do you have year and specs? Catalina should run very well on a more recent Mac. Now here's the bad news. You cannot simply downgrade an OS. It requires a full erase of the drive. Apple's server has your Mac listed under Catalina now so in order to reinstall High Sierra it may take a lot of steps. I could provide you links but it's best to contact Apple Support so they remove Catalina off the server for you and put you back to the OS your Mac shipped with. They may charge you for the phone call if you don't have Applecare Plus. If you don't want to do that then you may go through these long steps from this link. Honestly I would recommend if you ever want try out a new OS it's best to create a partition on your drive and install it there so you can test it with your apps. It's a very bad idea to blindly upgrade to a new OS version over your current setup. BTW the Time Machine restore will only bring you back to a previous version of Catalina. For example if your original install was Catalina 10.15.3 and you upgraded to 10.15.4 then Time Machine can restore you back to 10.15.3 but it does not backup an entire OS only the files.

Honestly it’s a preference thing. Apple care is basically limited warranty for three years plus two accidental coverages... Limited warranty portion will cover you for three years in case of any hardware failure and as long as there is no physical or liquid damage you do not pay anything get it fixed. Accidental coverage has two tiers screen damage and any other damage... meaning if you physically/liquid damage your screen you have to pay a deductible 129 in Canada to get a new screen. If ANY other physical/liquid damage no matter how small or big Apple care will limit the cost 320 in Canada . For example you spilled water on you Mac and now it needs new top case screen battery and motherboard ... without Apple care you are looking at easily over 1k in cost but with Apple care the maximum you pay is 320 again in Canada To sum up keep two things in mind 1 Are you careful with your device or clumsy? If clumsy Apple care is good value 2 Remember at the end of the day no matter who makes the product. It’s an electric product and there is always a chance of failure. If there is a hardware failure after the first year you are responsible for the cost you will have to look up the deductible cost for accidental damage where you are Hope this kinda clears it up a bit and helps you make a decision.

It's not asking you about the instruction set to use which will be fixed at 64-bit - what it's asking you is about bit precision. 64-bit computers are capable of 64-bit precision and so it is possible to have the audio processing chain do the arithmetic to that degree. The thing is most VSTs aren't actually capable of that and so you end up with 24 or 32 bit precision with a bunch of zeros tacked on the end. If you don't hear a difference don't use it - it's unnecessary slower especially on an old machine and will fill the buffers up quicker for no good reason.

I'm pretty sure you don't understand how to use the 16 in terms of battery. It has a dedicated GPU and when it's activated by certain apps it will drain the battery because it's in high performance mode. I have the 16 and I get the full quoted 11 hours battery when used properly. There are only 2 major things that are causing the battery drain and possibly a 3rd one. I have a 16 MBP with the AMD 5500 8GB card. 1 issue is the AMD dGPU. It drains battery. Period. 2 issue are the apps being used that activate the dGPU. Here is my short list of apps that are doing this. Chrome. Until recently it activated the dGPU but has been fixed but it’s still a major resource hog and drains battery. Final Cut Pro X activates the dGPU. Apple's Photos app activates the dGPU. Adobe's Creative Suite . Resource hog and activates the dGPU. Pixelmator photo editor. Activates the dGPU. Connecting the MacBook to any external monitor activates the dGPU. iMovie activates the dGPU. Bootcamp. Running Bootcamp'd Windows works only on the dGPU and there's no way to switch it to the Integrated Graphics. Playing most games activates the dGPU. These apps cannot run smoothly using the Intel Integrated Graphics because MacBooks with dedicated graphics like the AMD 5000 series ship with lower grade Intel Integrated Graphics. 13 MacBooks come with better Intel Integrated Graphics to run these apps since they don't ship with a more powerful dGPU. Lastly the 3rd reason for battery drain but not as major as the dGPU is keeping the screen brightness above 70%. If you're using the auto brightness control then this may not affect the battery unless you're using it outside or in uncontrolled lighting. Without fail I get 11 hours of battery on my 16 MBP when I'm using apps that don't activated dGPU such as Safari and Apple Music. It's best for people to verify if the dGPU is activated. Apple Menu-About this Mac. If the Intel UHD Graphics 630 and the AMD Radeon 5000 Series GPU are listed then the app you are using will drain your battery. If you're unsure which ones then close all your apps and launch each one and verify if the dGPU is activated. Lastly if you leave these apps open and just shrink them into the dock or close their windows they are still keeping the dGPU activated so you will still experience battery drain even when you're using basic apps like Apple's office suite. There is nothing wrong with your 16 MBP's battery or the computer or the system management controller. These battery complaints have been going on for several years with MacBooks that have dGPU's. More apps today are using the dGPU so it's not always easy to achieve the advertised battery life. If you absolutely need to use these apps at a constant it's best to plug in the Mac for long sessions

I just seen the error you received. Try these steps to trouble shoot. Go to Utilities and click Terminal. Opening Terminal from macOS Utilities Type the following command and hit Enter. Type date This command will result in the display of date to which the system currently has been set to. It might be reset to 2001 for some arbitrary reason therefore we need to set it to the right date. To do this type the following command and hit Enter. Type date -u month day hour minute year Two-digit numbers based on UTC should be replaced with every bracket. You can see below how the command should look like according to your current time and date – October 30th 2019 01 15. UTC is used instead of other timezones to avoid trouble. Just enter it exactly like this Type date -u 1030011519f Check the set date and time by running the first command again. The error should be fixed now. Copy and paste these commands to avoid typos.

To avoid any problems when using cables keep in mind one simple rule the bending radius should be minimum 10x the cable's diameter. This is recommended by many cable manufacturers and also in various textbooks or technological encyclopedias. This is also needed since Apple cables are composed internally of several wires deserving different purposes - e.g. we find out some wires for data exchange along with the two supply wires and those are smaller diametethin isolation making them more vulnerable to bending issues.

TLDR I'd wait for iMac refresh hopefully later this year. but here's a breakdown for all models relevant . x200B 21.5 models either have 7th or 8th gen intel processors 3 and 2 year old CPUS respectively the BASE 1099 model DOES NOT have a dedicated GPU 27 iMacs either have 8th gen on the good and better models 9th gen only on the BEST 2299 model with either 6 or 8 cores. 13 models either have 8th or 10th gen CPUS 10th gen ONLY on 1799 model. NO 13 has a dedicated GPU 16 models are running 9th gen CPUS and dedicated GPU ALL thunderbolt 3 Macs have the option of using an eGPU with some benefits and shortfalls a Dedicated graphics card will give you a good bump in FCPX and After effects performance pending workload and codecs used If this is a work related machine I'd get the best imac you can afford at least the 1499 best 21.5 . that gives you 6 cores a decent gpu you WILL want to do any RAM and SSD upgrades when you order as they're a PITA to upgrade after the fact 27 has USER upgradeable RAM which could help with buying a better iMac and then upgrade ram down the road still wont be able to swap the internal SSD easily x200B and you can use apps like Splashtop Desktop or screen share natively and control your iMac from your current AIR. Make sure your ssd support Triming for Mac not all ssd behave well on Mac. Also you can trim it manually from terminal and see if it recovers the speed after. SSDs become slower as they have less free space available because they move data internally all the time. I recently upgraded a Late 2012 iMac i.e. the first of the really thin iMacs where the screen is held with glue instead of magnets . The old hard drive had gotten so slow it was nigh unusable. I thought opening it up and putting it back together would be the hard part. That turned out to be relatively easy. Instead the hard part was restoring my data from my Time Machine backup. First I tried to restore from Time Machine via Recovery Mode but that resulted in a system that froze during startup. Then I tried to recover directly from the old HDD via USB but that didn't work at all. So to anyone who wants to upgrade to an SSD and then recover your data from Time Machine the way I finally got it working was by reinstalling Mac OS on the SSD and then running Migration Assistant.

If you are only looking at the BASE model iMac Pro another machine to consider is a maxed out i9 iMac. You would be able to upgrade RAM on that machine and if you get a pure maxed out SSD not a fusion drive there would be a left over SATA port on that machine for future SSDs that you could put in since they are not crypto locked to the motherboard. A maxed out i9 iMac is performance competitive with the BASE model iMac Pro. I’ll link the thread that I started last year when I was trying to decide between a maxed out iMac vs a base model iMac Pro. I ultimately decided to go for the Vega48 GPU with a 2TB SSD. And it was 1000 cheaper than the base iMac Pro The base Mac Pro is not good value. Even a maxed out iMac i9 can out performance wise. The Vega 48 can outstrip the Radeon 580x base GPU of the Mac Pro. The intel Core i9 9900K has better per thread performance than a Xeon. The Mac Pro only starts making sense when you look toward the higher end models Now so late in the product cycle I would look in the Used market or refurbs for iMac Pro’s that are 10 core or better. If you were going for an 8 core machine the i9 iMac wins as far as value per dollar. But you may get good deals for 10 core or 14 core models. But I will say that I have been happy with the i9 iMac. It is slightly more noisier than the iMac Pro but it is still a pretty quiet machine and it still has the user accessible RAM hatch on the back. This makes it the only other Mac other than the Mac Pro that can be RAM upgraded. and the Core i9 iMac can be upgraded to 128Gb of RAM. And the 8 Core i9 can outperform an 8 Core Xeon in the Geekbench stats.

That's normal. Batteries fluctuate. The percentage is just your current max battery charge divided by the rated max battery charge.
It's likely just calibrating over time. It'll plateau then eventually start to drop as the months/years go by.

Yes you’re right. All the battery related values you’ve ever seen are only estimations. There isn’t really a gage on the battery telling you the percentage number of remaining charges. Device keeps tracking the battery usage including voltage changes temperature current usage and lifetime since it’s first powered and calculate the approximate value of remaining charges and max capacity based on a chart which is derived from spec and statistics. That’s why you’ll see battery stuck at 100% for hours and drops like free fall after it hits 99%. That’s why fast charging will be slowed down when battery is 80% full. And that’s why iPhone will enable low power mode when the battery is aging. Because we can’t get the accurate situation of battery.

Agree with everyone suggesting SnazzyLabs on Youtube. Some very helpful videos! Some things I wish I’d have known when I first switched 1. People will recommend a lot of add-on tools for improving gesture control window management etc. Ignore that for now! Most people will benefit from these but explore what Mac offers first. Play around with gestures hot corners and mission control and find some settings that feel good and work well for you. After a couple of weeks when you really know what your Mac can’t do out of the box there are a ton of good tools out there to fill in the gaps. 2. Command Space pulls up Spotlight and lets you search your Mac easily open apps etc. If you find yourself using it but also find it limited check out Alfred for a search bar you can customize and program functions to. 3. If you work with audio you might eventually find someone recommending SoundFlower as a way to solve a problem with recording / rerouting system audio. Do not do it unless you absolutely have to — it can be a mess to remove from your system and is notorious for causing more problems than it solves. 4. Install AppTrap it’s available by Homebrew — it’s a simple utility that ensures all relevant files are deleted when you remove an application. 5. Command Delete will let you delete files. Function Delete behaves like Delete on a PC reverse backspace . 6. The options for Keyboard in System Preferences are robust as hell. You can set text replacements customize shortcuts and even create new shortcuts for any app. This is often overlooked but one of my favorite native features in macOS. It is also where you can toggle autocorrect if you have any issues with it. 7. If you find yourself frustrated with the way the media keys work aka you expect it to pause your music so you can watch a YouTube video but instead it is play/pausing the YouTube video and not your music install Mac Media Key Forwarder. You can set it to prioritize iTunes or Spotify instead of controlling whatever media is active on screen. 8. At some point you will find yourself running out of storage and you may find that “System Storage” is taking up way more space than you feel it should. If this happens go straight to SnazzyLabs — he has a great video on this and honestly I don’t know a MacBook user who hasn’t run into this problem over the course of years of use.

This issue very commonly affects the MacBook Pro 13” 2015 and when I see the same issue on MacBook Airs 2013-2017 the first thing I check is the IPD cable cable between the logic board and trackpad especially at the trackpad end. A lot of customers get a tiny bit of liquid in the gap at the top of the trackpad even one drop will do it and right under that is the IPD cable connector on the trackpad the contacts get corroded and can cause the symptoms you describe. Open the Mac up using iFixit.com guides check for corrosion on the IPD cable contacts clean with isopropyl 99% if corrosion found. If issue not solved replace IPD cable and if it’s still not working replace the trackpad.

The Mac Pro 5 1 is still a really powerful Mac and it has some great upgrade options and you can get some really great specs for the price in 2020. If you want 12 Cores at 3.46GHz that would be 2x Xeon X5690s and in terms of multi-core performance you'd be looking at around 6 000 - 7 000 in Geekbench 5 which is comparable to an 8-Core i9 MacBook Pro 16 or an 8-Core Mac Pro 2013 Trashcan. 128GB is a lot of Ram and it's 1333MHz DDR3 ECC coming from a 2015 MacBook Pro you probably don't need 128GB and should be fine with about 32GB because the most you'll have now is 16GB. The RX 580 is a powerful Graphics Card and Apple still uses the Radeon Pro 580X in the baseMac Pro 2019 which is just ridiculous and they use the 580X in the high end 27 iMac so you'll be fine with the graphics. The good thing is that you can always upgrade it down the line to a Vega 64 or a Radeon VII in a few years if the machines still performing well. Personally I wouldn't buy a 5 1 Mac Pro if you're wanting to spend under 2 700 even though it's really powerful just because it's a 10-year-old Mac Pro that isn't supported anymore with the latest version of macOS. At that price I would buy a brand new 27 iMac straight from Apple or a 16 MacBook Pro. The only reason I would buy one is if it was under 1 000 and was fully loaded with 12-Cores and 128GB of Ram with a few Terabytes of storage. You could probably buy a 2010 Mac Pro now and keep using it for another 10 years if you really wanted to if you kept upgrading the graphics and storage on it but you'd be stuck on Mojave forever and with a 10-year-old computer there's only so much performance you can get out of it. I have a 20-year-old PowerMac G4 Cube which still works perfectly fine but I wouldn't be able to use it as my main computer because I'd be limited by a 500MHz G4 Processor and it's PowerPC so there's pretty much no more software support and it can only run up to Mac OS X Tiger natively which is 15 years old. It would be usable for basic stuff but it would be very slow.

USB adapters can be daisy-chained. There is a limit to the number of devices you can connect. Where you might have a problem is power and data transfer rates. USB A ports only provide 5.25v. If you connect to many devices some may not work. You can get around this by using powered hubs. You can also connect additional USB C hubs. They will provide more power for devices and bandwidth for data. This would be your best option. If you google usb daisy chain you should get some good info

MacOS has run through a number of name variants starting with Mac OS X similar to classic Mac OS 8 and Mac OS 9 . Even with a maxed out top of the line couldn't get anymore expensive Mac there's no such thing as Future Proofing Small example. The iPhone has had the Hey Siri function for years. Apple didn't introduce the Hey Siri feature in Macs until the iMac Pro in 2017 and the MacBook Pro in 2018. Anyone who bought a 2017 MacBook Pro thinking they got the best of the and future proofed were fooled. Even the 2019 iMacs don't have the Apple T2 Security Chip so they don't get the Hey Siri feature either. So no matter how you spec your Mac you cannot future proof it as Apple will come out with new features in the next version that don't work with the new Mac you just bought.

Generally yes There are various modes of sleep a Mac can go into. At this point your question only describes the fact your laptop screen goes to sleep but this is different from your computer actually going to sleep. Regardless of your settings and assuming your MacBook Pro has a continuous power source then a system event such as copying a large amount of data will continue to occur even if various parts of your Mac go to sleep.1 This is because if your Mac is in the middle of an action such as copying files it will not go entirely into sleep mode e.g. your display may go to sleep but your drives are still fully powered up for read/write purposes . In terms of the speed at which data is transferred this can be affected by a number of factors but in your scenario the transfer rate should not be impacted. Of course if you're copying a large amount of data it is recommended you have your MacBook Pro plugged into an AC power source. For more information on your Mac's sleep capabilities you may want to refer to the following content Use the Energy Saver settings on your Mac macOS Sierra Optimize energy settings for portable computers About Wake on Demand and Bonjour Sleep Proxy

I have a 2019 27 iMac and it's great! Here's what I would recommend in order of importance SSD - So many people try to save a few bucks with a Fusion Drive but it really hinders performance. SSD is the way to go even if you choose a low capacity you can always use external SSDs for archived projects and resources. CPU - The CPU is the core of the computer. The CPU you pick will be with you for the life of the computer unless you want to void your warranty and break into your iMac . I would recommend getting the best CPU you can reasonably afford. I personally got the i9 but even the i5s should be good for most purposes. GPU - Every 27 iMac comes with a discrete graphics card which already puts it above the 13 MacBook Pro you have since only the 16 get discrete GPUs afaik . The Vega 48 is overkill unless you do heavy 4K editing. Besides you can always add an eGPU down the line as prices drop in the future. RAM - You got this one down. Upgrading yourself saves a ton of money. Just be sure you get the right spec from a reputable brand like Crucial or OWC . x200B I got my iMac last year with the same mindset. I currently have a working 13 MacBook Pro which is fine for most purposes. However I wanted some extra overhead for audio production Logic Pro X video production Final Cut Pro X and graphic design Affinity suite . Just like you I chose an iMac because I want something that lasts a long time. I wish you the best!

You start with three 2TB drives. Put all your photos on Drive 1. Sync Drive 1 to Drive 2 so your photos are also on Drive 2. Sync Drive 1 to Drive 3 so all your photos are also on Drive 3. Put Drive 2 in the safe-deposit box in the bank. Continue adding photos to drive 1. Continue syncing Drive 1 to Drive 2. Every 2 weeks to 1 month swap Drive 2 and Drive 3 at the bank and keep syncing Drive 1 to whichever of the other two you have on hand. This way you always have an offsite backup and are never more than 2 weeks to a month behind should you lose BOTH of your on-site drives. And THEN sync everything to a cloud service anyway.

Try to analyze this question yourself how can your Mac knowing where your iPad is ? A computer system is not a creature. It doesn't not have sensing organ and can not know what is going on outside of the case unless you install sensors to it. So the question would be what kind of sensor do you need and how can you extract the information of relative location of your iPad ? Visual information could be the easiest way to solve this problem. And that means you'll need to set up a camera on the ceiling over your head that will monitor your device arrangement all the time. It would cost you roughly 200 USD and it will eat up a chunk of your WiFi bandwidth not to mention that all the privacy concerns somebody is crying aloud. It is impossible to track precise location based on WiFi or Bluetooth signals. The human technology can only tell you an approximate circular area that is about 10 to 20 feels in diameter. At least not without extra add-ons like an antenna array. If you want inch-level locating using AoA angle of arrival or ToF time of flight method you will need to set up at least 3 full sized antenna around your room and all antenna must connect to your computer using zero-impedance antenna cable and you need to input the precise relative position of the antenna to your computer. Magnetic sensor could be a potential solution but it has limitations. The distance between edge must be within 1 inch and external speakers may interfere it because speakers have magnetic inside. In engineering it can be hard to explain the difference between the easy and the virtually impossible.

Plugged in power all day long No . Too lazy or too stingy to repair your laptop Yes . Lithium ion rechargeable battery generate power from chemical reaction. When the battery degrades chemical reaction can no longer maintain in consistent level which can result in the creation of gas called outgassing leading to a swollen battery. Swollen battery will cause twists in the enclosure and other components and in some rare cases it may explode or catch on fire. It is recommended to call Apple Support for battery change. Batteries are disposables. They're not supposed to last indefinitely.

So macOS will purposely grab “stuff” and toss it into RAM. It will cache in RAM all kinds of data so that you can quickly access it. It will also take some and allocate it for itself - this will show up as “used” even though it’s just technically being reserved for whatever needs it next. This way the millisecond it’s needed macOS already has it allocated and ready to go. That’s just how it’s designed. In the “Activity Monitor” app there’s a chart at the bottom labeled “Memory Pressure” - this is where you need to look. As long as that’s green you’re all good. There are highly technical articles on the subject if you’re curious to read.

Check activity Monitor. Its under Applications Utilities

I'm going to quote an answer I posted from a similar question. What you’re probably referring to is inactive memory which is memory in RAM that was once needed but not anymore. Say in the case you opened Microsoft Word did a few things and then closed the app. MacOS can predict the likelihood you may use this application again within a certain timeframe. This concept is known as ‘temporal locality’ and so the application can start quickly again because the data still exists in memory. As there is a competition for memory resources by other applications MacOS can allocate resources by removing some of the inactive memory to allow memory to be stored in active memory memory currently being used by applications . This is a fairly old article but it’s a good read based on the topic Keep in mind too that you shouldn't really pay attention to the memory usage provided by CleanMyMac. Instead look at Activity Monitor's Memory Pressure. This memory pressure shows how efficiently resources are being provided to your processing needs. Green is good. Amber is okay. Red is bed. The red should indicate that memory resources are scarce.

Look at your activity monitor. Sort it by Memory so it will show the most greedy at the top. Is there something or multiple things that are using the bulk of it? I have found that some tasks stay open running even though I think they're closed. You can end the task from the activity monitor. kernel task Is the one that kills me. It doesn't take that many apps if there's just one that's greedy.

That's exactly how a modern operating system should do in memory management. Because unused RAM is wasted RAM . All modern operating systems have implement dynamic virtual memory that will use all the physical RAM AND hard drive at the same time as memory space for user application. The guidance of such design demands OS to do two things 1. Fill up the physical RAM as much as possible. 2. Avoid unnecessary changes to memory allocation. Since a modern application will frequently request and release memory from the system it's waste of time to rearrange overall memory allocation every time. OS will tend to keep the released memory still associated with the original application that requested it as a cache space so that when the application requests for memory again you bet it will it can be allocated in no time. OS will dynamically estimate the activity of each application and determine when these preserved memory will be released. In macOS this estimation is called Memory Pressure measured from various factors. Generally most people will find a system kernel processes called WindowServer takes a lot of CPU and memory process. That's because WindowServer is the bridge between application and graphics hardware. When an app wants to draw something on screen WindowServer is the one that takes the demands from app and tells the graphics card what where and how to draw it. So when you have multiple apps with many windows on screen or you have a lot of files on the desktop WindowServer will stay in busy state all the time.

That gasket is probably part of the glass panel that goes over the lcd assembly. You may have to replace the entire glass panel to fix the gasket. For those who didn't see my original post on May 5th LINK I am spray painting a 13 Unibody MacBook Pro in Satin Black. The Journey so far Completely gutted the shell Then the prep work begins. I sanded down all the parts started with 120grit then moved on to 240 and finished with 400. I then filled in all the scratches and dents as best I could Then I sanded it down with 240 then 400grit and it is basically ready for the primer I decided the best way to paint them would be to hang them from the ceiling that way I could paint both sides of them at the same time. So I used my loft space to paint them I gave them 4 light coats of Etch Primer leaving 30mins between coats It was halfway through priming the top case that I suddenly had the idea to remove the DVD drive slot and Kensington lock as I was planning on using a 2nd hard drive in place of the DVD drive anyway and I would regret it if I didn't do it. So I took it down and filled in the slots While I was waiting to repaint the top case I waited 24 hours for the etch primer to harden on the other two parts then very lightly wet sanded it with 400grit sandpaper to give it a smooth finish. This is how I hung the pieces from the ceiling with Masking tape and string I also masked the areas where the logic board makes ground with the bottom case I then proceeded to paint the Satin Black with 4 light coats The paint looked really patchy because of the light coats and I was worried it was going to look crap but I held out hope that the Satin clear coat would fix that. While the Black was hardening I finished the priming of the top case and it looked so much nicer with the DVD slot delete 24 hours later the Black was ready to clear coat and the top case was ready to sand. Top case primer sanded down 3 light coats of Satin clear coat followed by a single heavier coat to finish it off The Satin clear coat made all the difference and really made the final finish so much better. The insides look crap but you're never going to look at them anyway The final results for the top and bottom panels There are a few imperfections and some dust that settled on the paint but I'm pretty happy with the final finish. It turned out much better than I was expecting if I'm honest! It goes to show that if you put in the prep the results speak for them selves. The top case is currently in the loft after having 4 coats of Satin Black. 12pm tomorrow I will be applying the Satin Clear coat. Then 24 hours after that the painting will be finished. I'm currently waiting for a White Macbook Keyboard in the mail which I will be taking the Key caps from and transferring them to the keyboard for this laptop. Which I think will look awesome! I will post the next update when it is all complete!

You need an installer cd/dvd to wipe the hard drive and reinstall system software

You need a Mac OS install CD / DVD. Luckily you can readily find the images on sites like Macintosh Garden or Macintosh Repository. Don’t try booting off USB as it won’t work without some extra tinkering and I never had much luck with that personally. Burn the image / images onto their disc / discs put the disc in the drive refresh the boot picker the screen pictured and you should see a disc icon with the OS X logo. Click on that then the arrow and you should have the Mac OS X Installer starting up. Images larger than 4.7GB must be burned to a dual layer DVD-R. They won’t fit on a CD-R or a single layer DVD-R. Edit The 02 iMac G4s support Mac OS X 10.1.3 Puma all the way to 10.4.11 Tiger depending on the model. Don’t try installing 10.5 Leopard unless it’s one of the later machines. You also need to enter Disk Utility and wipe the hard drive before reinstalling Mac OS. There should be an option in the menu bar which brings up Disk Utility - it’s name varies depending on the version of Mac OS X you’re installing though I think. Make sure you’re formatting it as Mac OS Extended Journaled .
That's an iMac G4. You'll need a disc to reinstall it. It will support anything from Mac OS X 10.2 Jaguar to 10.4 Tiger.

I have plenty of issues with Mac OS as well and the prices Apple charges. Your first issue though is easy. The Preview app button has a markup function. Open a PDF inside it and click the markup icon hover over the icons near the search box on the right side of 5e top ribbon menu . I think it looks like a pencil tip within a circle. Once clicked a bunch of markup icons will show up look towards the left side. You’ll notice a handwritten letter A. This is for signing. I just grab a white piece of paper sign it and hold it up to the webcam to capture it. After that it’s really simple to do it. Seconds. You can move align resize your signature anywhere you want in the PDF. Then I just print it again as a PDF save the file and send it to whomever. Make sure you print it because just saving it allows someone to grab your signature for any document they want. Once your signature is in your Mac you’ll never have to do all the capture steps again. Yiucan do the same within iOS.

Wait a minute... 6TB of data in Outlook ? Are you serious ? I'm not sure how can he handle this because Outlook is apparently not designed for such task. It's a GTD Get Things Done and groupware tool but not a knowledge base nor a good journaling tool not to mention data storage. If it's real then he must have some SERIOUS PROBLEMS in his workflow. Outlook is infamous for locking up all its data in the proprietary repository and there is no way to change the repository path which is located at /Library/Group Containers/UBF8T346G9.Office . Moving these data between machines would be difficult because you're supposed to use Outlook built-in archive export/import feature for this task. I'm not even sure simply copying files within that folder can work. A far as I know some people had tried to move files somewhere else and make symbolic lines to the old position but Outlook just ignore it and recreate a new profile instead. So the best solution would be manually archive and export every time. For a long term solution first he must learn NOT to put all data in the same stash because it means that you'll need to go though 6TB of data for only 1MB changes inside that way. Try to get a profession knowledge base / journaling tool like DEVONThink and classify data into different categories. If you have trouble making categories at least you can do this Ongoing Project Reusable Resources Recently closed projects Archives So that you only keep the ongoing project on the local drive and this should drastically reduce the data size that need to be synced every time. TL DR the whole point is to minimize data that needs to be synced every time. If he can do this then the storage media isn't really important.

Thoughts on my current XPS 15 9500 Pros ★ No Coil Whine!!! I used to own a XPS 13 9360 and the coil whine is always the most annoying issue that I faced especially when I am in a quiet room. Finally the Dell engineers was able to solve the issue! ★ New mold. By adding the 16 10 screen ratio and do some modification on the vent and ports this machine is finally built for the consumers! ★ Low heat. I thought the 10875H would be generating a lot of heats but the machine stay mostly cooled when I ran Path of Exile. When I tested the R20 the fan was not running at peak. Dell was able to engineer it very nice and is just as expected! ★ Four sided InfinityEdge Display! 16 10 really made the huge different and I compared it to Zbook Studio G5 the G5 was just not enough for me. By the way Dell also put the Windows hello facial recognition into the ultra thin bezel on top which is amazing! ★ Long battery life. I think it might because I chose the Full HD and that is why it will last for more than 8 hours. Not sure how long would the 4K last. ★ 60W PD charging. It will show that I am connected to a slow charger but it still charges the laptop even when I was running the Cinebench R20. ★ Powerful Performance. I was surprised that the performance is similar to my Ryzen 7 1700x. Cinebench R20 shows that the single core performed better than the Ryzen 7 1700x. Cons. ☆ All type C ports. It’s good that it comes with DA20u about the half size of DA200 without ethernet and VGA port but there is no Type A or HDMI. Also there are only 3 type c ports while xps 15 2in1 has four. ☆ No dedicated microphone mute key. I see that F9 does not have other command on it. I hope Dell would add the mute key on F9. ☆ Page up and Page down is integrated. For those of you use a lot of pg up and pg dn like me you might need to get used to it with two hands.

Thank you... I had the exact same thoughts. I wonder whether by doing so people wouldn't notice that they're buying yesteryear's hardware? They could have just gone with XPS 13 Early-2020 like Apple.

Nothing like this happens by mistake. There is usually a marketing ploy behind this. Check out the model numbers / names of HTC phones. Fortunately they confused people so much people stopped buying their phones and the business model tanked. I suspect that Dell wants to either reset the model numbers since their scheme led them down a cul de sac or they want to be able to clear out older models and stock by making it unclear which model is the newest. When they release a new model it takes time for the production process to ramp up become affordable and the market demand to grow. So they inevitably still have a few months supply of the previous model in the pipeline and probably not even made yet. But people typically want the newest model meaning they have to struggle to shift the older models which are more profitable when sold at full price but loss makers if have to be sold off in bulk to bulk purchases for clearance.
