Lol why TF ur disabling Turbo Boost man that's like throwing your money out of the window! Anyway undervolt settings are different for each user because none of the CPU/GPU are made the same welcome to silicon lottery! . Basically you gotta figure out the undervolt setting for your laptop by yourself. Also if your laptop has the latest BIOS that may prevents you from undervolting due to plundervolt so downgrade to older BIOS If necessary. For CPU First turn back on Turbo boost and download throttlestop. For your starting point set the CPU and cache to -125mv and use TS Bench to to test CPU's stability. If 1 of the 3 tests give back error then you have to dial back the undervolt setting maybe to -100mv or whatever till the tests no longer produce errors. If the tests don't produce errors at -125mv setting then increase it to -130 -135 -140 etc. until your laptop BSOD. The trick is to undervolt as much as possible but undervolting too much is just as bad as disabling turbo boost. For GPU Undervolting GPU is a bit trickier but often time not necessary because Turing GPUs are easy to cool unless your laptop sucks donkey balls. For this you will need MSI afterburner. Tutorial on how to use it is over all the internet so just look it up. I think 925mv is the lowest you should go. After you done toying with your system you just perform a stress test using this guideline here and let it run for 20-30 minutes. It won't kill your laptop since it's as bad as playing AAA titles at ultra settings maybe even lighter in some cases . Make sure power management/fan setting is set to max so I can see the best your laptop can give. In HWInfo64 focus on CPU Package PoweGPU Package Power if supported . It should sustain 45W/80W respectively while running at 85-90 Celcius/70-80 Celcius respectively. Obviously with zero sign of thermal throttling. Any significant deviation means your laptop needs physical care such as repaste dust out fans whatever else. If you want your stress test result examined either PM me the screenshot of your stress test or join Suggest A Laptop discord.

Don't expect huge performance/bottlenecks/temps/noise changes because XPS 15 9500 have almost the same cooling solution and Intel 14 nm CPU it's have even smaller 86Wh battery than previous model with 97Wh.

I hate to break it to you... but a lot has changed in 15 years. No computer will reliably last that long now. Your average lifecycle on a machine will be 5 years - and that is pushing it. I would say go for the XPS and get the best graphics card you can put in it if you plan on going long term. The XPS hardware is significantly nicer than the G series gaming laptops. Since you aren't a gamer you will definitely appreciate the aesthetics as well. The G series gaming laptops are the budget line - below Alienware. It is in the same line as Inspiron laptops which are below the XPS line. I would say go with the XPS as you aren't going to see a noticeable difference between those two video cards if you don't do any serious gaming. They will both work fine for editing etc. Mostly software has not caught up to the raw power in the hardware so you should be fine for a few years. I would imagine this is a 9th gen i7 you are referring to? If you can get a 10th gen processor I would recommend it. Also be sure to check the Dell outlet for a machine as well as they are usually significantly cheaper there than new. If you do that also be sure to do a chat with a rep and ask for a better price as they will almost certainly take 5-10% off what is listed.

I think that you need to to consider your use case here. If you're not a gamer and you're not doing any GPU heavy tasks like video editing or machine learning then a GPU will not be doing much for you. For a basic use case browsing the Internet word processing videos a CPU 8gb RAM and a solid state drive would be fine with no GPU the solid state drive will make the biggest performance difference here . You probably wouldn't need to spend much more than a few of hundred. In terms of latest features I'm not sure what you want but desktops tend to be expandable and it strikes me that there aren't really any latest features aside from the solid state drive and maybe a nice screen that will make much difference to you. All that said there are no guarantees any PC will last 10 years let alone 15. If you're feeling frugal the best thing to do would probably be to buy a cheaper desktop now for half the money and another when you need to several years down the line.

I recently got a g7 7590 that had better hardware than yours but same issues with fps. I've built desktops for years so I had a bunch of monitoring apps to troubleshoot. My laptop was reaching 100C during bootup so anytime a program would run there was extreme thermal throttling and power throttling. You can get realtemp 3.70 and run realtempgt for the temps. Look up how to run an elevated command prompt to get it to start with windows. Also go get Intel XTU and run the benchmark quickly. It will show whether you have thermal or power throttling. Hwinfo64 is another good monitoring app that reads way more sensors than necessary. What you want to check with that though is what peaks and where your processor clocks stop and your gpu clocks stop. For example when you run gta 5 if the computer hits 100c before max performance it will thermal throttle with dells proprietary software to try and keep the temps down but it doesn't work as intended because the fans take too long to run. If you have a major overheating problem then start a chat with Dell do a remote session and show them the temps by opening up a program. If that's the case it's either a hardware issue or bad thermal paste application at the factory. Other things to try that I've read about my machine would be to undervolt with throttlestop or Intel xtu reinstall windows to get all the Dell bloatware and power management software out create your own power plans that best match how you want to use the machine.

I own the 2019 model of the XPS 15 with i7 and 1650 16GB RAM which I upgraded from 8GB and FHD non-touch display. And I'll list out the things that you'd have if you went with the 2020 models. Better thermals/performance If you're not planning on playing video games then you don't have to worry about this or demanding tasks. But if you do plan on playing video games the 2020 model would better since it has better thermals and a little bit better chipset. But the main advantage is the better thermals. You can still game on the 2019 model it will just get warmer and throttle at certain situations such as newer AAA titles. You're fine with older or lighter games. Audio Gonna be honest the speakers on the 2019 ones are pretty bad. From the reviews that I've seen 2020 ones are really promising. Display/design You'll do fine with the display of the 2019 model. But 16 10 does look really sweet along with the gigantic trackpad. But on the other side you're going to lose some valuable ports. Windows hello facial recognition is a good bonus. If I were in 2019 about to buy the new XPS 15 but I also knew that the 2020 model would be a major redesign I would've waited another year and just stick with my old laptop for another year. I don't know how much you can manage with your current laptop but a year from now the XPS would be a lot cheaper and even if Dell comes up with a new laptop I doubt that it will be much different from this years model. Or can stick with your Macbook only until the winter semester. Dell laptop usually get cheaper around holiday season.

if you read the details of the recent bios update you just did intel removed the ability to undervolt. no undervolt awful thermal management in xps laptops lots of overheating which can lead to consistently high fan speeds. i personally downgraded my bios after finding out my undervolts no longer worked and you need to go into bios settings upon boot to restore back to defaults or else it will keep the undervolt restriction from the 1.16 update. you can find videos online or search google for others dealing with this issue. id recommend opening your laptop and cleaning it using pressurized air carefully . make sure to unplug the battery when you open it to be sure you dont damage any of the components incidentally. if there are thermal problems with your laptop id recommend repasting the thermal paste and replacing the thermal pads as well as adding thermal pads to the VRM's to transfer heat to the case of the laptop. i did this recently and saw a 20deg celcius decrease in overall temps. im now down to 40deg C idle and 60-70deg C while gaming. GTA V runs 70 fps high settings with peak CPU temps of 75 usually between 68-70. the xps lineup unfortunately has incredibly bad thermal throttling especially over time so it's worth looking into imo edit i know you said you dont want to undervolt or repaste but you are quite literally leaving yourself with no significant options to decrease temperatures if you rule out those off the bat

The first and main thing is to just enjoy it. I have two one for myself and one for my wife and they work without issues. Some people will have problems and that is the same for any brand. You will have to find all the drivers etc etc and that is not always easy if you are not technical. I would suggest you run Dell Update to get the latest drivers Windows update and that is about it. The only setting I would recommend you changing is the Thermal Management in Dell Power Management and set it to Quiet. Enjoy your new laptop and dont look for issues as you will always find something

Why are you asking all of this after having bought the laptop already? I just don't want it to run extremely hot Laptops are designed to run hot. A laptop being hot isn't a bad thing it's doing exactly what it is intended running as fast as possible up to the designated thermal limit. There is no product-life-threatening aspect of it running hot. Will it run hotter if you cover the vents with your legs while playing a game? yes. duh. But you can run it hot all day and that won't do anything adverse to your device. I've probably logged over 400 hours on my 9570 doing 4k-video rendering where it's run flat-out for dozens of hours at a time. Nothing happens. I'm also wondering about the portability You can easily find out the dimensions of what you bought by looking online. Why didn't you do this before buying it? The XPS is designed to be a portable and powerful laptop. It's not a gaming laptop those are far less portable. Is it a laptop? Yes. It's very portable. I've heard that these tend to suffer from not the best thermals and some throttling Why does this matter to you? It throttles under heavy load. So what? it's not going to throttle while browsing watching movies or audio engineering. Will it throttle if you play a AAA game that absolutely maxes out the computer? Yes. It's going to run right up to the limit. As intended. Overwatch and The Sims it can play no problem at all. It can play Rise of the Tomb Raider 1080p at 50fps. It can play Far Cry 4 5. It can play most AAA games from a few years ago.

Gaming shouldn't be an issue it'll get hot but that's every computer. It'll get a tad warm at most when doing simple web browsing. Using any laptop on a couch or bed will get warmer than normal because when it's not on a flat surface the air flow isn't optimal so give space for the fans. Very portable device for a 15 .

That website is incorrect. The Quadro RTX 3000 has equally as many shaders as does the GeForce RTX 2060 in fact they are exactly the same card I owned the Quadro RTX 3000 albeit in the thicker and heavier Precision 7530 here are some benchmarks vis-à-vis the Quadro P3200 same card as notebook GTX 1060 mobile and the Quadro RTX 5000 same card as desktop RTX 2080 SUPER . Open the three orange spoilers for the actual results. In fact the Quadro RTX 3000 and 5000 perform worse than they're supposed to because of the neutered power limit compared to the desktop cards. The RTX 5000 I currently own has 3072 shaders and 16 GB GDDR6 VRAM but the 80 W power limit means it performs like a desktop RTX 2060 SUPER achieving little more than 18000 in Fire Strike Graphics. The desktop RTX 5000 has as many shaders and as much VRAM and runs at a whopping 265 W TGP and destroys the RTX 2080 in benchmarks. To answer your other questions Programming robot simulations lil' gaming and a lil' machine learning majority I do in the cloud . This is precisely my use case. I run CUDA simulations write OpenGL D3D12 projects and am getting into 3D modelling rendering and ray-tracing too. I also play my fair share of games. AC Odyssey runs at high settings 60 FPS 1080p Witcher 3 runs at ultra settings 60-70 FPS 1080p Shadow of the Tomb Raider runs at 50-60 FPS Ultra settings 1080p Control before DLSS 2.0 runs at high settings no ray-tracing at 45-60 FPS 1080p Kingdom Come Deliverance runs at high settings 45-60 FPS 1080p. This is a variety of the games I am currently playing. Overall games are certainly playable at higher FPS if you turn down some settings and accept the quality drop. I wouldn't buy the Precisions just for the Quadro but rather for the incredible business-class customer support make sure you get ProSupport Plus with Accidental Damage for 3 years at least and generally better QC and QA than the XPS. They're exactly the same chassis but the Precision name is more important to Dell. That said if you are bent on getting a 17 machine with high performance why not get the 7750 instead? You get options to go up to the Quadro RTX 5000 can upgrade the memory displays SSDs M.2 WiFi cards you name it...

Considering you'll be equally thermally constrained in both setups I doubt you will see much of a performance gain from the Quadro RTX 3000 Mobile . It all depends on how well Dell has tuned these GPUs as it's highly unlikely that you will be able to hit 80W on the GPU as well as 35-100W on the CPU without crashing the limits of the cooling.

rtx 2060 and quadro rtx 3000 are the same core TU106 the quadro does not have more shaders or pipelines i'm not sure where you got that info from. They are going to perform nearly identically I would say with how nvidia's boost works. Also killer 1650 is just a rebranded intel chipset it likely works good in linux killer no longer uses qualcomm for their wifi6 generation. Even then you can just buy an AX200/201 intel card for 20 if you really want that instead. Just get the XPS 17 the precision has no advantages for your use case

Remember that in order to boot Ubuntu you need to have secure boot disabled also you’ll need to have to check the boot sequence if by any means the bios did a factory reset in settings just try to add the boot sequence or just check by booting the laptop into F12 menu if there’s an Ubuntu boot option then everything is fine just enter to the bios and set up the boot order you want like if first the grub then the windows boot manager MBR

That is probably going to be a driver BSOD yes however I would be very wary of running 2 versions of Windows 10 on the same drive when it comes to feature upgrades. When these run they essentially reinstall the whole OS given Microsoft's track record I would not trust that one of these wouldn't end up wiping the whole drive or destroying the boot record and cause issues getting into one of the versions of Windows. I really don't think there's a need to partition Windows like that anymore if you're really intent on doing it though I think using another version of Windows in a VM on Hyper-V or whatever virtualisation tool you want to use would be a better way of doing it.

What I would do is to find out how much the battery wear is. I have BatteryBar and it displays it in their program all the time. If the battery wear is high you may just have a faulty battery replacing the battery with a new OEM one will be an easy fix if there isn't much battery wear it could be something else.

Unfortunately the battery life on the 7390 is terrible. The one thing that is majorly flawed. You’ll have to be extremely conservative and maybe even make sacrifices to have anything near average battery life on one single full charge. I wish I could offer you a solution to your problem because I certainly searched for it every possible way. But as you said continue to play with the dell power management tool to optimize your laptop. Mix a little undervolting in there if you’ll like too.

I have the same model and 3 hours is too little. I get 5-6 with moderate use meaning things like listening to music browsing the web note taking and reading. This is also with the Better battery setting. I don't know too much about what can cause these kinds of issues but sometimes there are programs and services running in the background that are draining the battery. You might explore this possibility if you haven't already. Also check to make sure you're using the default Balanced power plan in Windows and that Thermal Management is set to Optimized in Dell Power Manager.

It seems battery life widely varies per person. Mine was definitely 5-6 hours when new FHD I cannot imagine getting the same with the 4k version so 3 to 4 hours seems about accurate in case we use our laptops similarly. ThrottleStop and Dells Power Management features can definitely help extend the battery life a little however. Unfortunately my battery health just degraded in a weeks time with 32% and the battery life has been 3 hours max now after 5 months of usage . I am so disappointed.. Dells support is looking into it now but their first support agent said this was 'normal'.

You battery life is terrible ! I previously had the 4K version and I agree the battery life is bad 5 ish hours . Run sleep study report after a sleep session to see exactly if the laptop was idle. Also try to undervolt it helps battery life and performance. Also check that you are not in max performance mode in dell power manager for battery life go in quiet mode . You should also check if you do not have any background apps that are active when using your laptop maybe something is taking some of your CPU usage. I now have the FHD model and the battery is way better around 7-8 hours for the same usage however i do notice the slight screen difference but you get used to it after couple of days. If you can i would suggest swapping for a FHD model buy and sell yours on ebay you might make a small profit out of it I do not regret at all my decision.

Your title and wattage question is one thing. Not charging past 70% is something completely different. Either way regarding both the wattage question and not charging past 70% the answer is absolutely not . While slower charge cycles may help maintain your battery health you still MUST USE THE POWER ADAPTER THAT YOUR SYSTEM REQUIRES . The wattage is not only required for charging. It’s for running the rest of your system CPU RAM graphics display etc. Do not use a lower wattage power adapter. Long answer Always fully charge your battery whenever you plug it in. Never partially charge the battery. When you do plug it in to charge wait until the battery is fully charged before unplugging the charger and using the system on battery power again. Never use the “express” or “fast” charge options in the BIOS or in Windows. Always use the slowest charge method that is available. Faster charge cycles wear a battery out quicker. If the battery is easily removable removing it entirely once it is fully charged while the system is plugged and turned on will keep the battery from wearing. Systems can pull power from both battery and AC power simultaneously while the system is running hint this happens when you use aftermarket or undersized power adapters so your best bet is to simply disconnect the battery or turn off charging if this is at all possible. Most systems have a battery charge disable option. Do some research on how to disable battery charging. If you do need to charge the battery don’t do it while you are using the system. It’s always best to charge the battery whenever the system is not in use so try not to use the system while the battery is charging. If you need to use the system remove the battery or disable charging if you can. Try to wait until the battery has discharged at least 20% before recharging it. Short charge/discharge cycles quickly wear out the battery. It’s actually better to fully discharge your battery before charging it again to avoid those short discharge/charge cycles. You should also calibrate your battery once a month for heavy battery users or every other month if you use the battery less often. Follow this link for detailed instructions on how to properly calibrate your battery. As you can see proper battery charging techniques is only one step of many when it comes to battery maintenance and maximizing performance. However please use the adapter that your system shipped with and do not use a lower wattage or aftermarket adapter or you run the risk of not only destroying your battery but also burning the adapter and catching a fire. Simply don’t do it. And while we’re on the subject of aftermarket power adapters let me say repeat do not use aftermarket or undersized power adapters or they will turn your battery into an spicypillows

The most concerning points are the battery drain and text appearance. I’m owning a 4K version which gives 6h regular use according to batteryreport. If you are fine with the batter life or it is constantly on a charger then definitely go for 4K. About text on a 27 in monitor you can clearly see the difference in 1080p from that on a higher resolution screen. On win10 1080p on a 2k or higher res screen aka downsampling looks even worse and text looks a lot more blurred than on an original 1080p screen due to its rendering approach. So in my mind 4K could come better in your case.
I've got the XPS 15 2 in 1 with 4k and yes I see the difference between 1080p. The sceen is even better than MacBook pro 15 2017. I would take the 4k again

on a 15 screen it for sure makes a difference. my current laptop is 14 UHD and while I can tell the difference resolution-wise from the FHD version it's not a particularly noteworthy downgrade though the lower brightness and color reproduction is noticeable . on a 13 machine I'd be hard-pressed to tell the difference at normal usage distance and even harder-pressed to recommend it as a worthwhile upgrade unless you specifically need it for work video editing digital artist photographer etc. - the battery life hit is very noticeable I get 7-8 hours on my UHD the same device with an FHD display will hit 10 easily and the benefits are much less so.

I've had both FHD and 4K of the XPS 7390 2 in 1 and I can tell you there is a difference. Small difference but it is there. I had the 4K for 4 months and wanted to change for FHD to get more battery life. The 4K screen has much more details its visible dont get fooled by online reviews that say its not noticable . The 4K is better for visualising articles or webpages however watching videos its not really a big difference. However you get really used to the FHD and I think the trade off for the battery life is so much worth it. If you never had a 4K display before go for the FHD. If battery life is a concern go for FHD. Otherwise go for 4K.

How good is the heatsink? Is the fan plugged in? The 4690K puts out 1.5-2x the heat of your Pentium if it's running at a big enough load.
You might check the windows system event logs leading up to the freeze. Are your drivers updated? Is this a fatal freeze or does it continue? Is it always at exactly the same point?

To get a Bitlocker recovery code two options Open PowerShell or CommandPrompt as an admin and enter command manage-bde -protectors -get C swap the C if you have a different OS partition . The recovery code will be listed under numerical password. Go to Settings the modern Windows 10 one then Updates Security then the device encryption tab. On the right side under related settings it will say Bitlocker settings. Hit that then an option will pop up allowing you to print recovery key or save to a file. Possibly will also let you back up to a Microsoft account. If it doesn't I think your only option assuming Win 10 Home is turning off Bitlocker waiting for it to decrypt and then turning it back on. This will auto add the key a new different one to your MS account. And you have to check with the specific Linux distribution if it has Secure boot enabled. I know Debian does in the latest stable and possibly in Debian 9 as well but couldn't tell you for the others
if you re-enable secure boot can you get into Windows?

I had this problem and others relating to BIOS . Did it attempt a BIOS update right before this started happening? What I recall is that the installed BIOS didn't like to do firmware updates and it would get stuck on reboot trying to apply the same update AFAIK . You can try a few things 1. use the BIOS recovery process where you put the BIOS you want on a usb stick and use the special power-buton-key-combo to turn it on and into recovery mode then flash from that. 2. Let the computer sit in this hung state for 1-2 hours. Mine actually took that long to do whatever tf it needed to do to finish then it started normally. 3. As another poster said try resetting BIOS to default and then don't touch em. Defaults seems to be the only settings they actually test to be working because ordinary custom settings would create long hangs on a variety of operations. 4. You can try other versions of the BIOS including earlier than what you have but beware the Dell Command Update utility trying to patch it back to the version you're having the problem with and then more hangs . But you could run into a different bug on a different version.

Seems to be a lot of misunderstanding around what this rating means. 300 discharge/charge cycles the amount of times you can fully drain then fully charge the battery before capacity will noticeably start to degrade. ie if you've gone through 250 cycles you can still expect to have close to full battery capacity. 400 or 500 cycles the battery will be far below 100%. This is pretty standard across the industry across most devices. Notable exceptions are many mobile phones and some Apple products. I understand Dell and other OEMs also offer long-lifecycle batteries with 1 000 cycle rating on their commercial products. If you're really worried about battery longevity recommend disabling any 'fast-charge' settings. These along with full discharges to 0% degrade your battery at an accelerated rate.
I believe XPS has the ability to limit charge in their BIOS. You can easier increase the cycle count to thousands before losing 20% of capacity by just limiting charge to 80%.

More info needed on what cpu it has. The i7 9750h I have has an max turbo of 4 5ghz if only one core is active with all cores active the turbo is max 4 0ghz. It will be hard hard to keep it at 4 0ghz stable because of power limits and temperatures. As for as I know the 3590 doesn't come with cpu that can be overclocked so there is no way to set the minimal clock speed at 4 ghz. You can set speedshift to 0 in trottlestop so it will try to keep the speeds as high as possible but throttling will happen at some point. Thermals in the 3590 aren't that great with the shared heatpipes. I put max turbo speed at 3 2ghz on all cores and it manages to keep it that way for 95% of the time while gaming without going over 70 C.

Significantly better screen and brightness. And this might sound stupid but you'd be surprised how many people care a lot about this - LOOKS. The sleek metallic clean finish matters a lot these days. I'm a big XPS hater here due to a mediocre experience with the 9570's QC and bad product design but objectively speaking there are solid tradeoffs while an updated X1E doesn't release. Major two points for the XPS would be 10th gen H series CPUs 45W with 8-core options and the 16 10 bezel-less form factor. Other than that there are a lot more good and bad things. For the good touchpad is huge and best-in-class class being not a Mac probably much better speakers finally but still no Macs dual M.2 not sure on the 15 . Also that dual Thunderbolt3 and right-side usb-c with DP and PD not a typo . Also eGPUs should be really nice on 10th gen. For the bad you can't get it in black Precision-line exclusive again metal frame makes it heavy despite smaller profile Wifi NIC is now soldered it didn't get significantly upgraded thermals like the 17's vapor chamber and worst of the worst vs a Thinkpad - the keyboard experience will be a downgrade you may not cope with. Oh and pricing so far seems pretty stupid but then again so is Thinkpad's X1 line. And you'll have to buy some legacy port adapters but well it's that Macbook-induced future now and I don't hate this change. As for the X1E there are probably promos since it's been out for a while it still has a trackpoint if you use it and that KILLER keyboard it's black and sleek-looking and the materials make it feel exactly the amount of light and rigid a laptop should be too much density makes laptops more fragile and harder to carry in hand . Screen has nice options particularly for pros who work under strong daylight or need privacy guard. I also personally believe QC and support are still better on Lenovo but that varies by region and of course how relevant you are for their reps individual vs large business purchase... . For the bad well everything not good from the Dell and likely price. But then again Thinkpads actually sell REALLY WELL and expensive even 2-4y after launch not something you can say for the 1.3k fully loaded 9560/70's original price double that on ebay with refurb warranty and all. People really crave that keyboard experience.
The 16 10 screen would be enough for me to pick the XPS over the X1E every day in the week.

If the system cannot determine the AC adapter wattage the battery charging circuit is DISABLED. If the center pin in the DC Connector is bent or missing the system cannot determine if the adapter is a Dell adapter and the wattage. If the pin is good and a known good adapter doesn't work either then the DC in port is damaged. So either a new adapter or a new DC jack is the MOST LIKELY resolution. / IWork4Dell

ProSupport is business-class support. 1. You get a 24/7 hotline that is still manned despite COVID-19 and you can talk to an agent that's local to your country or at least region and not a crappy outsourced one. 2. If you get Accidental Damage coverage ProSupport Plus they fix/replace your machines regardless of what you do to it coffee spills cracked screens broken hinges on purpose etc . 3. Any repairs are done on-site free of charge. If the warehouse in your country has the parts available locally you can get the repair person the next day and things can be fixed. If you want to repair things yourself that is perfectly possible too just ask for parts-only during your call to the CS officer when reporting a need to repair. It is 100% worth it and they treat each person like a company.

My experience has been great and i do always recommed ProSupportPlus with Next Business Day Repair. Normal ProSupport im always speaking with someone in India. When you can for something they always send a engineers and may replace parts that you dont actually need to just in case. You call sometimes for a fan noise and end up with a whole new assembly. x200B Two different experience i prefer the profesionalisme of the US guys but indian guys are also pro and always email you solution few hours or days after. Dell hardware support is awesome. Software support is not as good. x200B If you need w10... definetly the way to go. Do you use the original charger ?
Try looking up what the different cables are for then swap the connectors. Looking at that there should be no soldering just a knife to get the contacts out

Once u have the same number of cable and same color coding in the same order it's 100% safe to swap them around. If the new fan connector can't fit on the motherboard then you'll have to swap connectors. If you look carefully on one side of the connector you'll see each individual pin take your time lift up a bit the plastic stopper and wiggle the cable out. Power it off and open the machine and disconnect the battery. Press and hold the power button for around 10 secs to completely drain all power from the circuit. Then reconnect the battery connector and put the machine together and power it on and see whether it works. This has saved me many times with notebooks that have these kind of issues. Downside is you have to open up the machine but if it works... .

I know the cards to some degree do share the load I've always assumed my discrete graphics focused on the heavier 3D lifting while the integrated handled more of the Windows Aero / Explorer load. That being said you should see the discrete card taking the number crunching on. If for some reason it isn't I think you might want to make sure that the necessary configuration is made to have the system prefer that card. I'm not sure of the verbiage on an ATI model as I have a NVIDIA card in all of my various systems. In NVIDIA it's something to the effect of Prefer High Performance Processor . Another possibility is thermal throttling occurring which you should be able to determine by getting the Intel XTU and monitoring your card during gameplay. For me I had to undervolt my Dell XPS 15 to some degree for more stable performance. Additionally and this may be contentious I disable TurboBoost in the BIOS. I find the short burst of performance overpowers the thermals on my Dell XPS and I'd rather have a steady clock speed and predictable thermal variables. Finally I found that I often had better performance using the Dell drivers for the video card. I know that is also somewhat sacrosanct in the PC world and I don't do the same thing on my Dell G5 gaming PC or on a Dell XPS or Alienware tower. For whatever reason I see better more predictable performance on my Dell XPS with the Dell provided ones. They seem to update enough that I don't feel left behind and I run into far less problems. YMMV. Good luck!

Have you tried switching to Disconnected Standby turn off wifi during sleep ? You can try looking up for offenders using SleepStudy. But it may be difficult to fix if the offender is system/driver CS is broken by design in this regard - users are not allow to make the laptop sleep soundly. It should be possible somewhere to make the laptop switch to Hibernate after x% of the battery as been drained.

Connected standby is consuming too much battery when the machine is turned off completely. If the computer is in connected modern standby then it's not off. It's largely business as usual but with the screen disabled. Certain services shut off and the hardware goes into a low power mode but it's still sitting there checking your email periodically listening for other notifications and generally doing stuff you didn't actually want when you put it in suspend in the first place. Microsoft claims a laptop can stay in this mode for a week or more but my experience is that every Monday morning your battery will be nearly dead. How am I sure the machine was off? Either use Hibernate or Shut Down.
Undervolting and repasting would typically help. I've done it with all laptops I can get inside of.

Also check where that 15% comes from. Is it 15% while the CPU is throttled down? Or is it 15% while the CPU is running max clock speed? I suspect your CPU is running max clock speed all or most of the time which would explain the heat even at idle. Also do the ThrottleStop things but start with the above.

I have both a Macbook Pro and an XPS and I prefer the carbon fiber on the XPS. It looks great imo. While the all-aluminium design on the Macbook also looks great but it's cold to the touch and feels slippery. My palms after shift while I'm typing on the Macbook and I've never had that problem while typing on the XPS. The Macbook excels in two main places the trackpad and the speakers. I have the butterfly keyboard model so I can't comment on the new Magic Keyboard . The trackpad is great it's large and it has a satisfying click that's not too obnoxious. The trackpad on the XPS is great for a Windows machine. Compared to the Macbook it's good but not great. It's a little too small for my liking and the click is a little too loud for me. The speakers on the Macbook are phenomenal. The XPS pales in comparison it just sounds worse. The thing is I almost never use the speakers. I have earbuds that I just plug and play. The only time I would ever use my speakers was if I was in a presentation and I needed to play a video to an audience - the XPS speakers are decent enough. Some might say but the Macbook build quality is SO much better than the XPS . There is 0 chassis flex on either machine both feel rigid and sturdy - something a 1000 laptop should feel like. How about the webcam! The nosecam is god-awful on the XPS The XPS has a nosecam but it also has Windows Hello and in my experience Hello works flawlessly even if the webcam is at the bottom of the screen. I use my laptop far away enough so that the nosecam isn't even a nosecam but more like a chincam which you can still see my face - perfectly acceptable for any conference call. Macbooks don't get viruses and are long-lasting machines that have 0 problems! Look at my comment below about QC control on the XPS lineup. As for the no-viruses a recent study by malwarebytes one of the world's leading antimalware company found that MacOS has more viruses than Windows As for the Windows gets viruses take a look at this Windows Defender is awesome and after using Windows machines for over 4 years I've had 0 malware/virus issues even after pirating/torrenting on sketchy sites. Windows Update has never updated without my permission even when it's a urgent security update. People forget there's a simple setting to turn off automatic updates. Because I don't want to rant more and I ran out of time the XPS lineup is on par with the Macbook. If you prefer MacOS you know what to do. If you prefer Windows you also know what to do. Both are excellent machines and I'm sure you'll do just fine if you go with either of them.

Honestly I don't think you can go wrong with any of them.
Always go for ultrasharp due to better QC and product quality.

P - Not factory calibrated U - DELL says it's factory calibrated Both are good. It will not charge your XPS 15 while doing demanding tasks because monitor has only 65W power delivery. XPS 15 has 130W brick.

Indesign in particular makes it sound like you're doing lots of visual work that lots of people are going to be seeing e.g customer facing maybe even stuff for print. So I'm going to second Lordship Mern's recommendation of UP2716D which notably gives full aRGB/NTSC coverage and much better DCI-P3 coverage. USB-C doesn't matter for XPS 15 since you can't charge the laptop properly with any monitor so you can just use a 10 USB-C dongle problem solved . If we're just comparing the P2720DC and U2719DC... Hmmm. Honestly no meaningful difference except that the U series supports Daisy Chain which could be handy if you ever want a second FHD or QHD monitor. P2720DC is overall very nice. Out of the box it'll give 100% sRGB/72% NTSC at 6500K with 2 dE. This is very good and calibration beyond this point will not matter. The U2719DC does not offer meaningful color advantages. Also U and P series have similarly high quality standards with the same warranties 3 year with advanced exchange the same dead pixel guarantees etc. P series is Dell's primary line of business monitors. In this market reliability is a very high priority . No difference here. But again with your described use case I would recommend a wide gamut monitor like the UP2716D over either of these choices.
And what about the upcoming U2721DC? Is it worth waiting for?

I'm running the latest BIOS that patched the plundervolt exploit probably 2 updates ago and throttlestop still works but it quits once every few days now. Maybe. Ice Lake isn't affected by Plundervolt so as more 10nm chips are available there will be fewer systems where blocking undervolting is required but that doesn't mean that manufacturers won't do it anyway. Ideally manufacturers would just expose it as a BIOS option mitigated by default but with a user option to disable but that's not likely to happen.

If the battery is degrading work with Dell support. If that's not it... Based on my fans also seem to be running louder and more often I'm suspicious of some rogue application loading up your CPU all the time. Open your task manager when the machine should be idle but the fans are running and identify the process that's using the most CPU. Regarding even with CPU usage under 10% 10% is measured against the clock speed of your CPU. If the CPU is running full-tilt all the time then that at a 10% load indicates something is using the CPU when it should be idle which would drain the battery fast. OTOH if you're talking about 10% while the CPU is throttled way down and you're doing something else that would explain that 10% like watching a video then this might not be the culprit.

This means the system during post cannot figure out what Charger is plugged in and adjust how it powers your system. The system will try and use the charger but it usually will not charge the battery at all in this state if it uses the power adapter at all you can just tell the system to continue and that will let it boot to the OS and what happens then is hoping it works fine. I would disconnect your charger from your computer and from the wall outlet check the charger for any damage anywhere. Move to a different wall outlet. Make sure it’s a dell charger that is at least 45 watts. You may need to do a bios update also but that needs a good charger to do so on dell systems. It’s possible the charger itself has gone bad or a connection on the motherboard/ within the charging circuit has failed. The chargers tend to be pretty tough I’ve seen dell chargers that are 10 years old still working in an office with people traveling.
I get this error when the charger isnt plugged in all the way. Perhaps ur fix is as simple as ensuring its plugged all the way in.

Just fixed a XPS 15 9550 with the same problem last night lol. As the other person has said it's most probably the charger or the DC in jack if replacing both the DC in Jack and the charger doesn't fix the issue then you need to replace the over-voltage protection zener diode that sits on the PSID line coming from the charger. That was the issue with mine because the entire middle part of the DC in Jack was broken off and the 20V and data pins were touching together.

I had this exact problem on my old dell 17R 7720 SE. The problem was the charger and not the laptop. I just ordered a new charger on Amazon and it all works fine now

It sounds like a webcam issue which is pooled into the the display as one assembly. If you were still within warranty Dell would most likely replace the whole screen to fix the webcam issue. You could try re-seating the connectors between the display assembly and the logic board. If it does not work you could try purchasing a new display assembly from eBay Alibaba etc. EDIT You might also just buy a USB webcam. It could have better quality and be positioned better than the built-in one.

This might sound stupid but try applying some pressure either side of the cam with your thumbs. I have a 9560 and one day the cam just stopped working. Pushing on it fixed it. I also had a Lenovo where the cam would start and stop repeatedly when you tried to use it. Same fix. Both have been fine since.

You should try undervolting. Download Intel XTU go to core then go to core voltage offset and then go down by -0.010v then do a stress test for 5 minutes. Keep going down by -0.010v and keep stress testing everytime you go down until your system is unstable. Then go back up 0.010v and run a stress test for 30 minutes you could stress for longer to make sure it is stable . That should be you max undervolt. If it is ever BSOD or is unstable again just go up by 0.010v again.

Limit your framerate to something sensible in CS. This stops your GPU working too hard. In console type fps max 60. From memory you have to do it on every start up but maybe that has changed. I guess you can also do this via the nvidia control panel these days. Also get Throttlestop and create a profile for gaming with Turbo boost set to off. You'll get a lower peak clock speed but will produce much less heat. Try those two risk-free options and see if it helps before opening her up.
Cleaning fans regularly and thermal repasting is help with your overheating issue

I had similar issue. Steps I took to fix it. 1. Update BIOS and drivers to latest. 2. Install Alienware Control and set thermal to balanced and power to ultra. 3. Reapply thermal paste to CPU and GPU. Any decent paste will do wonders. 4. Undervolt using throttlestop CPU and CPU cache to -.125. might be able to go lower depending on silicon. Watch Bob of all trades video on YouTube. 5. If you can mount it on a laptop cooling pad or just get so.me airflow going in. I went from 90-100 degree 100% fan and constant thermal throttling to 70-80 degree nirvana with only occasional fan noise under stress test conditions. And performance is better now.

It can be basically everything. Software or hardware error. In my experience most BSODs are caused by hardware failures. Try reinstalling audio/webcam/video drivers or update bios.

The issue is usually caused by a hard drive/driver corruption Try reinstalling/updating your graphic drivers doing a chkdsk and a full malware scan with your preferred av except norton/mcaffe To do the chkdsk open up command prompt eith administrator right then type in chkdsk /f /r press Y restart. Once the chkdsk finished you need to open up cmd with administrator right and type in sfc /scannow this will take a couple of minutes but this will ensure that no drivesys file has been corrupted To update the drivers open the Run dialog Win R type in devmgmt.msc open the drivers section right click the graphic drivers click update drivers and follow the update instructions. After this finishes just restart if it doesnt do it automatically then test for the BSOD. Hope this helps

Sounds like a dead PSU or mainboard to me. The black button on the PSU is actually a PSU tester. If the mainboard itself works and you press that button you are providing power to the mainboard. The system itself won't power on fully but can be used to see whether 5V rails and devices attached are functioning. At least with the T5500 it early brother they were notorious for their bad PSU's. I had random freeze ups and occasionally blue screens on mine for ages. Wound up being related to the SSD. Replaced it recently and feels like a new machine. What state is your battery in? Could it be working overtime to charge it non stop? My 9560 is 3.5 years old and the battery is starting to die. It's charge capacity is about half of what it's rated to and its very unreliable when charge level drops below 30%. It's spent most of its like on AC power which likely hasn't done it any favours. There are dozens of other things you can do to keep the temps down including undervolting cpu igpu dgpu repasting tinkering with boost settings etc in Throttlestop. There were some particularly problematic builds of windows in late 2018/early 2019. The way updates are layered on top of one another seems to cause issues on a lot of machines.

Cooling issues are never fun on computers and being in a laptop just makes it harder. Have you run the bios diagnostics to be sure everything is working as it should. This will also show your battery health with other specs. But if everything is working correctly then there is a few issues that can be left. Biggest will be thermal paste between the heat sink and the cpgpu also could be the heat sinks/heat pipes being broken could also be the issue. With the whole sleep issue with lid close that should work so an wipe/ reload can help as windows rot is real. Before you can try to run some commands to recover windows with scannow/sfc . Look at the Precision line on the Dell website. I couldn't begin to reccomend a certain one but those are Dells professional line. I work with mechanical and design engineers and my company has issued about 25 Precisions to them as their main computer.

I agree with GoSitInTheTruck that the Precision line 3540 5540 7540 is what you'd be interested in. Of the 15 in 35xx line only goes up to 32 gb ram 5540 goes up to 64 gb ram 7540 goes up to 128 gb ram The big differences between these two are portability sustained performance and upgrades The 5540 is smaller and lighter but that means that although it can pack similar components as 7540 it overheats much more quickly and will severely throttle the performance in sustained hours processing. Because the 7540 is bigger and has a better cooling setup the maxed configurations do have more powerful silicon inside. A few more notes •The new line of xps is announced and all that there is a new line of precisions in the works but not out yet. •You mentioned tight budget - either look at refurbished Dell has superb quality control for refurbished products or look into price matching the system you want look up other computers with the same specs you want to find one that you can price match . •If you're doing lots of heavy computing if it's sustained over a long time or gpu-heavy then I'd suggest the 7540. Otherwise save a few bucks and go 5540

Power Limit Throttling is a function of the CPU drawing more than it's rated power draw or VRM/other components exceeding thermal maximums. If your thermals are in check and you've opened up the CPU's power limits as far as the firmware and/or XTU will allow you then there is nothing else you can do. For example if you have a 45W CPU and the restriction on this chip is say 60W even if you push it above 45W to 60W if the chip tries to draw more than 60W it'll Power Limit throttle and there's nothing you can do about it.

60-70 fps doesnt sound that bad. If mine throttles CPU clocks down to 800mhz and I get 2fps. The thing chokes so hard I cant even exit the game. The trick is to keep cpu gpu and ambient temps down. They all affect one another so improving only one doesn't help much. Some things that helped me repaste cpu and gpu shaved near 20 degrees off peak load temps no joke undervolting cpu and igpu maybe another 5 degrees or so turn off turbo boost when gaming caps clocks at 2.80ghz but produces much less heat in a much more controlled manner undervolting dgpu now able to hold a constant 70 degrees with consistent 1800mhz dgpu clock speeds Set ultra performance under thermal settings in dell power manager allows the fans to run a bit harder Literally pointing a desk fan at the laptop if I really want to push it. A cooling pad would be better but I haven't found any that has the fans in a good spot for the XPS.
Its because you are undervolting cpu gpu way too much so system becomes unstable and crashes.

Hello for information which computer? x200B Never keep the standard battery charge parameters in the BIOS modify them to avoid a too deep discharge and a too high load. The worst is when you are on the mains and the parameters ins BIOS or Setup require that you always charge the battery. My parameters in the BIOS or the Setup because I am under Linux are to never charge more than 85% and to charge the battery only from 50% of SOC on mains see also the parameter critical charge action in Windows or Linux and set this parameter to 15 or 20% of remaining SOC State of Charge in order to avoid producing lithium dendrites which will irreparably destroy the battery slowly very slowly but definitively. From time to time every 4-6 months change the parameters to obtain a full charge at 90-95% never 100% and discharge the battery up to the threshold of 15-20% SOC depending on settings to calibrate the inevitable wear of the Li-Ion battery in the battery manager. Avoid to use Rapid Charge too often. OK we will have a battery that will have a range of use of only 20% to 85% on battery but it will last longer except construction defect . My parameters mean that on the mains as long as the battery is not below 85% it never charges even I plug in the main AC the LED charge indicator turns on but stops and if it does charge it charges but stops at 85% max. I install lithium battery systems LFP or LiFePO4 technology and charge systems solar panels alternators and shore for sailing boats I know the problem well even LFP are more safe. Unfortunately the XPS 15 bragging-right specs listed at Dell sales pages don't include the cooling capacity which is unfortunately a poor match to the heat dissipation of the listed chips when put to a serious long-tem workload. Certain hardware in the form of heatpipes and cooling fins is lacking. The XPS 15 is a thin-and-light and throttling is essential to keep it from meltdown. As you notice there are guides how to make it cope with gaming loads better. Repasting may be needed if you find the CPU and/or GPU temperatures higher than normal see Notebookcheck review for references . Padding the mosfet VRMs is highly recomended because they tend to run too hot. The main thing is to make the laptop produce less heat while still running reasonably. Undervolting tends to help substantially. For gaming it is mostly advisable to restrict CPU performance disable turbo or restrict package power or lock max multiplier so that the GPU is more likely to run unrestricted.

I have been using my XPS 13 9300 for almost 2 weeks now and the complaints are always over-dramatic. There are no issues that I have noticed aside from some random stuff that almost every laptop has. If you want really in-depth overview of things that someone might find annoying here is a list The laptop will get pretty loud doing anything graphics intensive but there is no whining sound it just sounds like smaller fans spinning really fast. It will get fairly hot if your running anything graphics intensive after around 20 minutes. But remember this laptop is super thin and very light so it is to be expected. If you are planning to game on this frequently though I would not get any kind of ultrabook. If your not planning on running graphics too much then this laptop remains pretty cool and dell has optimized this laptop to have excellent battery life. I can go about 8-10 hours without needing to charge. Random Wi-Fi disconnects maybe once a day Screen Flashes something to do with auto-refresh I believe this is not a bad thing but it bothers some people Average quality speakers but definitely not bad they work just fine for most normal media consumption Software stuff implemented by Dell that I believe is related to battery life. Dell Power Manager that's installed seems to change speeds a little but you can tell this laptops power is being throttled a bit for sake of battery life. You can install a fresh version of Windows that may fix this but I didn't and don't think it's necessary Other than that stuff this laptop while a bit pricey is definitely gorgeously designed and is pretty much exactly what I thought it was going to be. It is probably the smallest 13 ultrabook but the nice 16 10 aspect ratio and borderless display make this laptop feel around a 14in while being crazy light and portable.

if you search this forum and also DellXPS you will notice 2 issues that many people are complaining about first major 2nd minor TB3 not working properly especially when trying to connect external monitor under Ubuntu screen goes blank for a 1-2s on some events Furthermore several people pointed that the following components are working but could be better quality webcam speakers Finally as all XPS 13 laptops and macbooks and probably many others to that matter it can't operate at maximum CPU frequency for more than few minutes which makes the name XPS eXtreme Performance System sound a bit like a grotesque... . After that it will throttle down CPU to stay cool. This is an obvious misdesign of the cooling system Lenvovo Thinkpads can operate for days on full throttle without even getting close to get hot but they have laughably little amount of RAM OTOH I'm considering purchasing this laptop also but I will definitely wait for the TB3 issue to be resolved specifically I'm waiting for Plugable to announce 9300 to be compatible with their TBT3-UDV dock Other than this it really depends what are you going to use this laptop for but comparing to other brands it has IMO outstanding quality specs /price ratio in 13 category it is the only 13 laptop with reasonably small display bezel reasonable amount of RAM although 64GB would be better TB3 support when they fix it duh... official Linux support and reasonable international warranty support I currently own 9360 model and often move between various South-East Asian countries and so far always managed to get Dell engineer to come fix whatever problems I had just waiting for parts to arrive was taking long

While similar the Extreme is for power-hungry users whereas the P1 is for professionals as its hardware e.g. graphics card is not geared towards gaming but rather is optimised to work with software like AutoCAD and Solidworks. If you care about the screen the OLED of the Extreme is significantly brighter than the P1. You can look more into them if you care. Now as far as the XPS with the i9 goes... You'd be avoiding all heating bills in the winter but you would be giving up your laptop. Seeing the thermal issues of the XPS lineup I would not trust it with the i9 even with undervolting and repasting. I've heard similar thermal issues on Lenovo's side though so make sure to do some digging in each subreddit to see if there are many thermal issues with your chose processor . It's generally not very smart having a high-performance chip like the i9 in a thin chassis.

I haven't paired to an external display but there's enough knobs to turn that you should be able to get the volume to a reasonable place. Repasted with Arctic MX-4. I'm not brave enough to do liquid metal. You'll eventually thermally throttle but it shouldn't be at 56C. You'll want to undervolt. You can try reloading the defaults in the BIOS but that didn't work for me. Most are downgrading to 1.8.0 but you can use the information in to find the CFG Lock offset and re-enable undervolting on the latest BIOS. CFG Lock is offset 0x5C3 to save you some work. Once you have undervolting enabled click the TPL button in ThrottleStop and uncheck Clamp then go into FIVR and check Disable and Lock Turbo Power Limits. This will keep the system from lowering PL1 on you. Mine would limit the CPU down to 16W before I did that.

I'd go with a Lenovo Yoga C940 - they're offered in 15 and 14 models use AES 2.0 digitizers generally preferred over the MPP digitizers in the Spectre line and have much more modern specs than the XPS 15 2-in-1 which also isn't set to get an update anytime soon . My C940 14 does really well in Sketchbook and Krita and if you find the built-in pen a bit small it's roughly pencil-sized if you're more used to that then there's a lot of other options for it check out stylus under the AES 2.0 heading in the wiki to see what will work . The 14 has one of the new Ice Lake chips which will be great for lighter gaming Minecraft older AAA stuff or indies maybe not ARMA 3 and even my UHD model gets me around 8 hours of battery life pretty easily. The 15 has a more powerful processor and dedicated graphics so it'll be better at gaming but the battery is the same size for more power-hungry component so if longer battery life is your priority the 14 might be a better pick. Both the 14 and 15 models have Thunderbolt 3 ports though so you could go for the 14 and add an external GPU later if you need the extra horsepower. As far as how they compare to a Wacom tab generally they'll have a bit more wobble on diagonal lines especially slow ones a higher initial activation force though it's still pretty good compared to MPP and in general feel a bit less like working on paper or canvas - you kinda have to learn the system and its issues and work with it as opposed to just doing what you want and it coming out with no issues. It's a pretty great compromise compared to having a laptop or desktop and a separate tablet though because you can take it with you anywhere - I had some work for classes that required a visit to the Met so I took all my notes some sketches and a quick map by hand on my laptop.

You probably know that fan speed is controlled by temperature. So do all fans rotate as they should? The only reason why the laptop keeps increasing the speed after you do something must be that the fan is not cooling for some reason so the electronics keeps increasing the RPM. Hi 1. Open the Device Manager type devmgmt.msc in the Windows search box . 2. Expand the Sound video game controllers and right click on Realtek High Definition Audio . 3. Select to Update Driver Software . 4. Click on Browse my computer for driver software . 5. Click Let me pick from a list of drivers on my computer . 6. Put a check in the box Show compatible hardware if not already checked. 7. In the list of devices click High Definition Audio the native driver . 8. Click Next . 9. On the Update Driver Warning box click Yes install the driver . 10. Restart the laptop if prompted. If not prompted then no need to restart. To get back to the Realtek driver do it again but reverse the names in steps 1 and 6. SK

The audio crackling seems to be a perpetual problem with Dell. It's the result of a number of design decisions. These include - the Killer chipset dodgy video drivers poor power management and poor thermals. Undercooling helps turning off turbo boot helps running on mains power helps changing the audio drivers helps but... all the fixes published only address one of the contributing factors so things get better but not perfect. To be fair it's difficult to replicate because it depends on network activity graphics activity ambient temperature charging/battery status and how good the thermal pasting is but despite promises Dell haven't really tried that hard either or I'm sure they would have fixed it. Maybe there is a cost implication or the problem needs to affect more people? I finally gave up because audio is really important to me sent my new XPS 15 back and bought a MacBook Pro. I still use my 3 year old Latitude for writing email browsing CAD and because I like Windows - but use the Mac for anything that needs real-time low latency performance. In reality Linux/macOS is designed around real-time and Windows isn't.

I'm having the same problem undervolting on my G7 7790 17 . Which is a pain since the i7 9750 is actually as hotter than the surface of the sun. That's not EPP issue that's the turbo power limit. I face this issue too my i5-8250u would only boost for maybe a minute before being limited to 15w rated TDP. This is what I did go into FIVR and tick the disable and lock turbo power limit you need to download a file and put it in throttlestop but this completely ignores any turbo time limit and let your CPU turbo forever as long as thermals are good. Also in the throttlestop main screen make sure you press save after any changed and that it's turned on and not just monitoring.
Are you using the latest bios 1.9.2 ? It brakes undervolt completely. If you you do. Just downgrade and reset settings in bios. It should work.
I run 1.8.0 with no problems. Others like even older ones. Here are the instructions. Just download and install After that try if undervolt works if not. Boot to bios and reset defaults settings.

It's not a gimmick. I'm a grad student and I use the current 7390 2-in-1 for note taking when I'm in class. The handwriting recognition is very good and the sensitivity of the pen allows you to write in very small spaces legibly. I have the version with a 4k screen and I get around 6 hours of battery life. As far as other benefit tent mode comes in handy when I'm playing games. Also when I'm eating lunch and reading I like to flip it so that the keyboard is flat against the table and the screen is angled towards me. This way I don't need to worry about crumbs falling into the keyboard

I use my C940 in the foldy modes about as much as I use it as a regular laptop. Handwriting notes is great in tablet mode especially if you're working with a lot of diagrams or want to have a more accurate representation of what your professors are putting on the board if they're write-on-the-board kind of people . I use it in the stand mode when I'm in bed to have some youtube playing on the side too which is nice don't really use the tent thing too much but it's there if you have limited space . As far as battery life the 9500 has a bigger battery but also has higher-powered components so it's bigger partly to compensate for that. If you're going with the 13 I'd say definitely skip the UHD screen because it's very much not worth the hit to your battery - my C940 is 14 and I could barely notice the difference vs. the FHD one the only reason I went for UHD was because that's what was available with the specs I wanted. I'm not too mad because I still get like 8ish hours of battery life pretty easily with the latest bios and driver updates but realistically with the FHD display I'd be hitting 10 hours regularly. I will say that if you're not set on an XPS you can get 15 2-in-1s the HP Spectre x360 just got a refresh that looks really sweet and it's designed from the ground up with a UHD screen so it has a 97Wh battery or a 14 like the Lenovo Yoga C940 that I have - built as well as a Macbook IMO great screen the best audio on a Windows laptop solid keyboard pen built in and good battery life even with a UHD screen if you're set on that . You'll get a bit of extra real estate if you're worried that a 13 will be too small coming from your Macbook but I'll just say that 14 is about as big a 2-in-1 as I'd be comfortable using - they get heavy they get big and it's just kind of a clunky experience to use them as a tablet.

I use it occasionally to show coworkers things during meetings. Also just to watch a movie without having a keyboard in front of me. I believe it also makes the laptop more durable stronger hinge and screen

If you consume a lot of media like Netflix YouTube a 2in1 is better. You fold the keyboard back into a stand position and it becomes a media player. The screen is close to your face so you get a more immersive experience. I have kids so it's a great for them to watch some kids show without messing with the keyboard.

Yeah its very useful especially if you're using an external keyboard on a desk - you can fold laptop backwards to bring it pretty close to your face - especially useful on smaller screens and smaller desks. Have to say tablet mode is actually the thing I almost never use. Instead I use positions like tent when kids stream to keep device cool on carpet. Surprisingly versatile.

Sounds like a botched explanation. Nvidia G-Sync is the name of the dynamic refresh rate feature. Nvidia PhysX is the physics acceleration feature for video games. Nvidia Optimus is the feature that switches between internal graphics card the Intel GPU and the external graphics card the Nvidia GPU . They are trying to say that G-Sync is dynamically setting the refresh rate. The part about PhysX is wrong. I have a Dell G5 5590 with a 144hz display. It does not have dynamic refresh rate G-Sync . I don't know if there are possible configs with G-Sync. My display always runs at 144hz.

Are you sure your G5 5590 has a 144Hz display? There are models where the screen is only 60Hz e.g. the one with the i5-9300H on Dell's site . Yes the explanation makes no sense. ChadValijean is right in that Nvidia PhysX has nothing to do with framerate but I also want to add that G-Sync or FreesSync does not limit your display's refresh rate in any way. It dynamically syncs your monitor's refresh rate with a game's FPS to eliminate screen tearing. But when you're on your desktop or doing any other sort of tasks your screen should be running at 144Hz. Optimus technology also shouldn't have any impact on your display's refresh rate. That offloads work to your iGPU if your discrete GPU is not needed so your laptop can extend its battery life. Both GPUs should support 144Hz. Edit Have you gone into your Nvidia Control Panel to check the refresh rate there?

Are you trying to set the refresh rate for the built-in intel gpu which might not support 144hz? You might have to check and set any nvidia-specific display parameters from an nvidia app not the windows control panel or from the app/game you're trying to use.
I had to disable intels graphics settings. The panel refresh and power saving mode of I recall correctly.

Sounds like overheating. Use a temp monitor tool like HWinfo64 to monitor CPU's temp during idle/light tasks. Temp should hover around 40-60 Celcius. Anything higher than that indicates overheating and will need attention.
Look in the Windows Task Manager what tasks using the most CPU. Use Coretemp to monitor your CPU temps.

It is absolutely a heating issue. i9 is a heat monster unless they have excellent cooling these will overheat. You might want to keep all firmware drivers upto date. Disable unnecessary programs from starting up uninstall McAfee and enable Microsoft Defender . If these did not work Have Dell replace the heatsink fan MB.

i have a 9575 not sure what issue maybe with your keyboard but i assume maybe debris... the 9575 uses a MagLev keyboard which means its a butterfly mechanism that floats on magnets and like with Apple's butterfly switches if too much debris finds its way under the keys it may mess it up. so you may want to knock the debris out of it either use compressed air or turn the laptop over so keys are face down and bang on the back of the laptop hard enough to knock crap out of the keyboard.. its a tough machine i dropped mine countless times so just dont hit it full force but ya like your spanking it.. i had to do this a few times on my laptop..no biggie good luck

Yeah looks like your CPU is being thermal throttled hard. SMH 800mhz on the CPU. Unplugging the battery won't do much because the cooling design and Dell's thermal management are inherently flawed. The biggest culprit seems to be the uncooled Mosfet VRMs on top of both the CPU and GPU. It's a well known issue among the XPS 15 lines that none of the paid reviews out there address about it. Undervolting won't help much throttling will eventually occur under sustained load. Disabling turbo boost is not a proper solution that's like throwing your money out of the window. Dell finally addresses this in the new XPS 15 2020 by actually covering the Mosfet VRMs under the heat sink. Though only through stress test that we can tell. I would say once thermal review for the new XPS 15/17 comes out you should ditch this piece of junk that is the XPS 15 9560. We need less people romanticizing the XPS line on this world.

First the Dimensions Yoga 720 14.3 x 9.5 x 0.75 XPS 15 13.57 x 9.06 x 0.58 XPS 13 11.6 x 7.8 x 0.58 As you can see XPS 15 itself is significantly smaller than your existing 15 even with 19 10 screen ratio. XPS 13 will be really tiny as compared to both of them.

It'll depend on which cpu on the 13 and the 15 you're comparing. However compare it with the cpu that you currently have. Even if you go with the 13 it'll still be an improvement. If that's enough for you I'd go for 13 . If you found you're current cpu lacking then consider the 15 .

If you've had it for a year or more you may want to try to re-paste the CPU. I recently did that on my Dell Latitude 7390 2-in-1. It had idle temp in the 70's and frequently gets throttled due to heat. I repasted the CPU with Artic Silver 5 and now it idles in the upper 40 to lower 50 and reaches high 80's low 90's under load and almost never throttles anymore. Dell does a horrible job with cpu paste out of the factory. Make sure you clean the old paste off with some rubbing alcohol and q tips before you put on new past. Don't put too much on just need a very thin layer.

Hi! Thank you for reaching the Dell Reddit Support. I understand that you're facing an issue with the speakers and LCD. Please be assured that I will look into this and help you with the best available options to have this resolved for you at the earliest. Before we proceed I have a couple of questions to understand the issue better 1. How long have you been facing the issue? 2. Have you made any recent hardware/software changes to the system? 3. Can you share a video of the issue? Let’s run the hardware diagnostics to understand if there is any hardware failure in the system. To do so 1 Restart the system. 2 Keep tapping F12 key when the Dell logo appears during the startup. 3 Select diagnostics from the one-time boot menu and run the initial test. 4 Once done do let me know if you receive any error code and validation code. They're not shady so much as understaffed due to what I'm assuming is significant call increases from COVID purchases and outsourced either pre-COVID as a matter of cost savings or more recently as a method of trying to keep up with the call volume . That results in a large number of reps being unqualified script-readers which also makes the calls take longer as well as introduces more scrutiny than normal on metrics. Management knows they're underwater and any CSR who is below par will get replaced quickly to try and bring things up overall. Dropped calls lost sales It's no different than shopping at a local department store and being asked 17 times if you want to sign up for a store credit card so you can save 15% today. They get a small bonus for every signup or sometimes for passing a threshold and get fired if they don't hit particular numbers. I don't consider the checkout person to be shady nor really the company as most are upfront with the employees about what will happen to them if they miss the numbers though I do find it distasteful. EDIT On the new order number thing there are two possibilities there. First the rep did it to get their name attached for metrics. As long as there's no cost increase or order delay to you this shouldn't really matter. Second if the order was canceled because your payment didn't go though it's entirely possible that the system considered it dead and forced a reorder. I'm in eCommerce and we explicitly designed our order management system to not allow an order to be un-canceled .

I think your laptop is basically overheating and switching off is it's way of protecting itself. What i would do if i was you. A . Send the laptop back if it's still in warranty or let it be repaired by Dell. B . Open up the laptop repaste the thermal. Try undervolting the CPU a but usually -0.125mv or so use ThrottleStop if undervolting does not work try downgrading your BIOS to a earlier version. Also using ThrottleStop turn off Turbo Boost yes you will lose some performance but the CPU will run a lot cooler and draw less power. Edit Open up the laptop repaste the CPU with new thermal paste.

Configurations supported 4 GB 8 GB 12 GB and 16 GB so you can use a 4GB and an 8GB. As long as the modules match in speed/specs differing brands don't matter a lot.

The ThrottleStop FIVR window has a monitoring table in the top right corner. Look in the Offset column. If your undervolt is working it will show in that column. If that column shows 0.0000 your undervolt is not working. -100 mV for core and cache offset is usually a good place to start testing.

It's still blocked probably. Install HWINFO and check the voltage offset. You can do factory reset on bios to get back undervolt. You should set turbo bootst power long and short max to 25 - 30 in order to give enough temperature room for GPU. There is no need to undervolt your GPU but if you'd like it to be quieter and less heat. Undervolt it to 0.7v and cap the frequency to 1500Mhz. Check this post With above settings my cpu and gpu temp are below or around 70 degree and the fan sound is moderate even during games. I pretty enjoy it.

Downgrade or reset the bios and do as the other user stated which is to limit the boost wattage to 25 watts which even at 3.0-3.2 ghz should be sufficient for games and if you arent comfortable downgrading or resetting try use that trick alone.

They're basically the same computer. The 2-in-1 was launched as the 7390 before Dell decided to change all their model numbers again.
The 2-in-1 has a soldered ssd. That's a big difference for me.

The 7390 2-in-1 came out at the end of September and was the first of the XPS lineup with the updated build 16 10 display with minimal bezels . They changed the naming convention with that model away from the 9XXX numbers to the 7XXX numbers because they claimed they wanted all of their premium laptops to start with the 7XXX numbers. Then when they launched the new XPS 13 9300 they decided to change the numbers back to the old naming convention. To answer your question here are the differences between the 2-in-1 and the 9300 7390 2-in-1 has soldered RAM and SSD presumably to make the device thinner 9300 only has soldered RAM SSD is replaceable They both use the same 10th-gen Ice Lake processors They both have 16 10 display ratios with identical displays including the touch They both have similar batteries and similar battery life the FHD models have significantly better battery life than the UHD displays The 7390 2-in-1 has the new vapor change cooling system that just looks like a plastic cover placed over the heatsinks The 9300 does not have the new cooling system but reviews says that the performance on it still better than the 7390 2-in-1 in some benchmarks although it does run hotter. One review said that the increased performance may be due to updated system settings on the 9300 since the specs were otherwise the same. I personally noticed that my 7390 2-in-1 was faster to boot and more responsive after the latest Intel UHD drivers and the most recent BIOS The 9300 has an updated keyboard with more key travel than the 7390 2-in-1 but they also got rid of the separate pg up and pg down keys instead making the left and right arrows larger and placing the pg up and pg down keys as function activated keys. They both have the same trackpad. Obvious but might as well point it out The 7390 2-in-1's keyboard can be folded back completely and be used as a tablet. The ports are identical on both models while the 9300 is slightly smaller almost imperceptibly thinner and weighs slightly less. Big difference 9300 has Windows Hello facial recognition support and a better webcam. The 7390 2-in-1 has no Windows Hello facial recognition and a potato web cam. They both have fingerprint readers.
