When I experienced this back in 2015 I had to replace my RAM but that's not always the case. I'll just give you some generic things to look out for... Is the CPU running overly hot? Grab CoreTemp to see in excess of 100c the power will be cut so I think this is unlikely. Plus the laptop would practically burn you depending on how you use it... Is there any bloatware on the machine you can afford to cut? Eliminating potential causes is probably the only way to troubleshoot and it can be tedious. Booting into safe mode is an idea if you don't encounter the same problem then you can more confidently blame software since safe mode will only allow core services to start. Remove whatever software you think is sketchy and just rinse and repeat. If it's still buggered you'd generally want to remove some memory and see how it goes. Then your GPU and so on for each piece of hardware again just eliminating possible causes . Not so easy with a laptop. It's probably a repair shop or support from Dell job at that stage.
May i ask if you are undervolting your laptop or not? If yes then that is normal just reduce the undervolting.

Hi Run a monitor diagnostics test and share a picture to see if issue could be seen in the test. To run the built-in diagnostics 1. Ensure that the screen is clean no dust particles on the surface of the screen . 2. Unplug the video cable s from the back of the computer or monitor. The monitor then goes into the self-test mode. 3. Press and hold Button 1 for 5 seconds. A gray screen appears. 4. Carefully inspect the screen for abnormalities. 5. Press Button 1 on the bottom of the monitor again. The color of the screen changes to red. 6. Inspect the display for any abnormalities. 7. Repeat steps 5 and 6 to inspect the display in green blue black white and text screens KP

It says it runs at only 1ghz but that things flies all day long even on the lowest power setting constantly chilling at 1.3ghz and jumping to around 3ghz when opening stuff. I just got the 7390 2-in-1 and it has the 16 10 and Ice Lake like the 9300 and it's worth it. Not sure where you are hearing slower there are maybe some certain benchmarks it's a few percent slower but 10x as many that trounce the older one especially once graphics are involved. They are both same generation processor but Comet Lake is on the older 14nm process it's more like the 9th gen they never launched while Ice Lake is on the new 10nm process and more efficient and double the graphics power.

They improved alot of things to the newer model. The base model now has a much brighter 500 nit screen as standard. The old one hit 300 nits. The newer one has a 100% srgb display. Older one hit around 65%. The speakers have been improved. The track pad is much bigger. The processors are not slower. Ghz clock speed isn't the only way to measure perfomance. What also matter is instructions per clock or ipc which has improved alot on the newer models. Graphics even on the i5 has also seen a bit of a bump with the i7 having the biggest jump. The older models also have big issues with overheating yes they may be advertised as hitting 4ghz or more but in reality that's an up to speed they hit it for a few seconds but actual sustained performance is far far lower.

The new CPU in the 9300 is... hmmm. In CPU performance it's slightly better than the 4 core CPUs in the older XPS models e.g i7-10510U . Long story short the frequency is lower but they can do more calculations in a single clock cycle Hz so it balances out. There are some use-case specific differences. For example the Ice Lake 10th gen G parts are better for vectorized workloads. But if you're dealing with intensive multithreaded workloads then the 6-core i7-10710U is usually better. For most people I would say... this isn't a big deal. But it is worth noting the G4 and G7 configurations have much better integrated GPU performance 50% so this is a big plus for the 9300 much better for any e.g light gaming . Anyway overall I would say the 9300 is a better machine. I don't think it's worth the extra money in an objective sense - the improvements are nice but they aren't essential or game changing in any way. If you go to Dell Factory Outlet and get an older XPS or a Latitude 7400 you can save hundreds of dollars and it'll do everything you'd need for many years to come. But subjectively speaking... if you want the 16 10 aspect ratio upgraded iGPU etc and you can comfortably afford the 9300... well yeah... You do you I guess.

Yeah that's how Optimus system works. When you tab out to check the dGPU's usage on task manager the game stops rendering in the background so... there is not much works for the dGPU to do hence low usage. And when you're watching video it's considered to be light task so the system will automatically use your iGPU to do the decoding instead of using your dGPU. The frame rate drops you're describing is thermal throttling/power throttling and has nothing to do with GPU's usage. This is caused by the CPU/GPU/any other components on the motherboard overheating and the laptop has to intentionally gimp the performance to prevent itself from catching on fire lol. Fixing this ain't easy because the cooling design thermal management are inherently flawed and not suit for gaming. You can try undervolting repasting repadding padding Mosfet VRMs look it up to alleviate the issues.
Dell uses some proprietary stuff to get over the 100w limit.
Well from my understanding the specification is just up to 100w. But Dell did some modifications to provide 130W.
i think TYPE C can have up to 100W is the specification. Specification is possibly a minimum requirement. It is easy to use thicker cable to push more wattage. x200B someone correct me if i am wrong.
USB C “Power Delivery standard” is limited by 100W. Dell is using their own solution I guess.

From a technology perspective I believe the brick is built to handle up to 130w charging but since regular type c standard only goes to 100w Dell probably had a unique handshake that tells its adaptor to go over 100w to 130w when the conditions are met a dell laptop that needs 130w . But on a regular computer or smartphone it is maxed out at 100w.

The Dell WD19 dock can provide 130w via USB Type-C to the system The dock uses a 180w AC Adapter and the dock itself uses up to 50w of the available DC Current . Many of the newer models have a 130w USB Type-C AC adapter now. / Iwork4Dell

I have the 2019 base i5 model . It has the smaller 56wh battery. Note that I have the igpu only model. IIRC if I added the GPU upgrade the battery would automatically bump upto the 97wh. It is expected to be worse than the equivalent 7590 in terms of specs i5 8gb ram xxx gb ssd 1200p display. Since the new screen has the same 15.6 diagonal but now it is 16 10 it is actually bigger than the previous 16 9 15.6 display around 5.2% bigger as a result if the display tech is the same it will have a bit more power consumption talking just about the size . Also now the res is 1920x1200 compared to the slightly lower 1080p of last gen. Inlcuding all these changes and also the fact that 10th gen intel cpus don't offer any improvements in terms of power consumption the batterylife will the noticeably worse with the 56whr battery compared to last years base config with 56whr battery. If you see batterylife results of last year's base config anywhere online i've seen some that stated around 5-8 hours expect around 10-20% worse batterylife under the same conditions with the new 9500 base config.

I will do my best to answer your questions from my experience with my XPS 9300 i7 / 16GB Ram / 512GB SSD / FHD non-touch. 1 - No my unit is completely stable. I have read a few people complaining of this issue on the new models however it seems the majority of people do not seem to be experiencing this problem myself included . 2- IMO the keyboard is fantastic. Having come from a Macbook this keyboard is a joy to use. Only slight issue if the positioning of the home / end / delete / arrow keys but its easy once you get used to it. If you are not sure get your self down to an electronic store and try typing on one in person! 3- The new models have windows hello so you can use Face ID to log on - it works very well in my experience i have not had to use the fingerprint scanner or pin once. Having tested the FP scanner it seems to work well. 4- This is an interesting one. The laptop wakes up pretty much instantly from sleep. HOWEVER if my laptop is not used for a while 30min - 1hr then when i open the lid the dell logo appears for approx 10-15 seconds before i can log in. I am not sure if this is meant to happen as a power saving option or if my laptop is defective but it is slightly annoying. I am sure with a bit of digging in the power management settings this can be fixed.... 5- For me I very rarely hear the fan - only when i first got the unit for a day or two whilst it was indexing and when installing software or updating the system - even then it is not super loud. I have heard that some people will have the fan on full throttle even when watching a HD youtube videos however this is something i have not experienced. I do not use it for gaming or heavy CPU usage therefore i would not be able to give a truly accurate answer. 6- Currently using the info provided from a battery report my battery's average is 7.5 hours however others are getting around the 8-10 mark. I am not sure as to why mine is under performing - I only use it for surfing the web and writing work documents....? This is something i need to look into. Other issues - i have been having problems with my BT audio - the audio stutters every 10-15 seconds. This is VERY annoying. I have tried re-installing audio driver but no fix. I suspect the issue may lie with MaxxAudio Pro Waves. - when on full volume the keys will vibrate at certain frequencies. This is slightly annoying also but i rarely have my laptop on full vol so i don't mind. Again i am not sure if this is a design floor or my unit being defective. I have a technician due to come out at the end of this month to investigate / fix both issues. Many of my posts on here fell on deaf ears so i made an effort to try and help you - I hope this helps

how can I make a complete backup of my PC so that I can restore the entire system even if I lose my laptop? Look up on restoring full system state for Acronis or another backup program . You'd have to do it from a bootable external restore environment based on Linux or WinPE so that the system drive is not in use . Mind this is mostly only applicable for restoring to the same laptop after disk failure or corruption or to the same laptop type while isn't useful for restoring on a different laptop - then you'd only restore the data but reinstall the programs and drivers. You might be interested in SSD cloning which is also supported by backup software but doesn't work incrementally like regular backup.
I use Macrium Reflect for this. Works flawlessly. I've recovered several times using this on my new machine.

Did you change the settings in Windows which makes text larger and make everything else bigger? To check this select Start Settings Ease of Access Display Adjust the text slider to 100% under Make text bigger Choose the 100% option from the drop-down menu under Make everything bigger Did you have to adjust any of these settings? Having said that the reason it's going to look blurry is because your display is set to have a specific 2560 x 1440 resolution. LCD panels like to run in at their native resolution and trying to adjust this without a dedicated graphics card to a lower resolution simply zooms in on the image which makes it look blurry. You also will not be taking full advantage of your display quality. If it's simply too small for you try leaving the display at the higher resolution and adjusting those make everything bigger and text size slider settings to fit your personal preference. That's what they're there for. To apply the changes log out and log back in again.

Sounds like a funky OS. You'll need to attempt a Windows repair. Tap F11 as soon as your BIOS completes POST and keep tapping F11 slowly until Windows 10 Advanced Startup Options shows up. Then select Troubleshoot Advanced Options and run Startup Repair. If you are still receiving BSOD or other boot failure errors during boot after the startup repair is complete go back into the Advanced Startup Options doing the same method as before except this time under Advanced Options select Command Prompt In Command Prompt type sfc /scannow and press Enter Once system file checker is complete attempt to reboot. If you're still having problems I would strongly recommend shipping the system back for a fresh wipe and reinstall of Windows since it is only weeks old. It's better for the factory to do this as they have an image of your original hard drive and they will pre-load all the necessary drivers. I mean unless of course you're feeling adventurous. In which case go for it but don't say I didn't warn you. Every driver has to be installed in a specific order and you run the risk of deleting the Dell Diagnostics partition if you reinstall Windows and end up formatting the drive. If this wasn't a new system I would say let's do it. But it's not. It's brand new. Just get them to wipe and reinstall that boot drive and you'll be good to go.

When you say you calibrated the usual way do you mean you tried this method of battery calibration? Calibrating a battery using these specific steps is critical in order for the battery to report its capabilities to the system board accurately. If you use the system while it's charging during the calibration the charge cycle is disturbed. Likewise if you use it to do anything other than one single operation while discharging the system will discharge in variable spikes. Both situations will amount to a battery that does not accurately report its health.

This sounds more like a software issue instead of a hardware issue. I would recommend backing up your laptop to an external drive with software like Acronis True Image and completely reinstall Win10. When reinstalling Win10 there's a few things you should do. Beforehand go to the dell support website and download ALL drivers/software packages for your laptop and stick it on a USB drive or something. I'd recommend NOT connecting to the internet during the installation process because a It will force you to create a microsoft account which you don't want your PC to be attached to and b it will auto-install drivers that are likely to be out of date compared to the ones you got from Dell's website. So reinstall win10 install all drivers from the USB. I also recommend using PC decrapifyer to uninstall dell bloatware and please use Win10Debloater to uninstall default Win10 bloat Office trial candy crush Minecraft netflix etc... This will ensure the cleanest installation of Win10 possible. After you're done I recommend imaging your hard drive again so you can restore to that state later if you run into problems again. Ninja edit -- I will add These were the first steps I followed when I received my 7590 this past January. It was plagued with software issues sleep issues windows explorer 1909 bug bloat issues internet issues . Reinstalling Windows the stable 1903 update fixed all of these for me. ALSO Look up how to disable S1 Modern Sleep. It's a sleep mode designed for Surface tablets that for some reason Dell enables on their laptops causing weird sleep behavior and major battery drainage.

Your first step is to ensure your system is configured properly. There are settings in BIOS and OS that prevents S3 sleep. FYI. There are only 2 sleep states S3 sleep S4 hibernate and S5 power off. S1/S2 refers different working states unrelated to this issue. Navigate the power option in control panel and go into advanced setting to ensure everything is correct. Google it if you need to. I will not repeat those available on Google. 1 your first step is to ensure you have a healthy sleep state. Set your sleep timer to 1min boot clean then observe your system goes to S3 sleep then wake it up. You want to do this a few times to make sure you don't have a intermittent sleep problem. If necessary use CMD to run 'powercfg -requests' to troubleshoot anything prevent S3. You need to unplug everything when do this - some USB/other devices may wake the system up in wake-on-LAN or other similar events. 2 repeat step 1 with power connected. This verifies your S3 is healthy even when power is plugged. Note the system has different setting when adapter is connected. 3 Leave the system in S3 for 10-20mins observe any screen lit or temperature rise on keyboard the hot spot is near the F9 key which suggests OS secretly wake up due to some events. If you have a Fluke meter with thermal probe you can do this fairly easily. 4 If you have gone through 1 - 3 then you are sure your OS is OK. Now get to the software part. Open browser Office and everything you could think of. Then leave system idle to trigger S3 and let it sit to observe abnormal screen/thermal events. This normally happen in 10-20mins if it happens. 5 if system overheats in step 4 use binary search to identify which software/element is causing this. This would take a few hours but it will systematically find out what causes your problem.

Try to disable the dGPU from device manager. Alternatively switch to S3 sleep mode instead of modern standby. From regedit go to key HKEY LOCAL MACHINE SYSTEM CurrentControlSet Control Power modify or create if not exists CsEnabled and set its value to 0. Also if you happened to have a samsung SSD use Samsung's NVMe controller driver or switch SSD mode to RAID and use Intel's RST driver.
I solved that problem on my 9370 by reinstalling Windows from scratch and avoiding to install any of Dells drivers or assistant software. Works for me.

Have the same issue. Laptop would go to sleep and not cool itself even if it was burning. Thermal protection would kick in and turn it off then. My solution was to disable sleeping whilst plugged in so it would never forget to cool itself down.
Try this 1. Start the registry editor regedit.exe . 2. Move to HKEY LOCAL MACHINE SYSTEM CurrentControlSet Control Power. 3. Double-click CsEnabled and set to 0 then click OK. 4. Reboot

This is a good question and one I've been asking myself although from a different perspective. I have a 4K 9550 i7-6600HQ and have always found it a bit sluggish which I've always thought was the hardware struggling to drive the high resolution display. Yes it's nice to know that the display is amazing but I can honestly say that for me I think it's been more trouble than it's worth. Support for HiDPI in a few applications that I use has been a bit ropey and I can't be doing with workarounds and hacks just so I can see things properly. Four years on I have no doubt that there's now sufficient performance to push all those pixels around but I'm asking myself if I'd miss it if speccing a replacement with a FHD panel. I certainly don't look at the 24 FHD displays I use with my desktop and think that they look crap and there are way fewer DPI there. So go FHD in a new 9500 and save myself a few hundred and hopefully release more performance for the things I really care about being snappy?

In the software world we're not going to see loss of lo-dpi support for a very long time things are mostly just moving toward being able to nicely scale. It almost entirely depends on what battery life tradeoffs you want to make whether you want to sometimes deal with stuff being scaled incorrectly on the 4k display and whether you care about the extra pixel density.

If you want to use it long term get the quad-core i5 at the minimum. The i3 is a dual-core processor and is far more likely to become underpowered in a few years' time. 8GB of RAM is for the near-future but I would go with 16GB if it fit my budget. Also keep in mind that the SSD and RAM are soldered onto the motherboard so you won't be able to upgrade it later. Get the highest spec you think you'll need.

AMD is a big gamble when you need to rebuild the laptop's internals from the ground up and lose Thunderbolt. Not only that but you get a problem where a good portion of consumers are stuck in the mindset of AMD can't compete with Intel on desktop let alone mobile. All of this makes it a very dangerous proposition to put AMD in your flagship laptop. I've seen the poll results heavily favoring AMD at the moment and it's pretty clear that this community is eager to see the new stuff. That's good but there are going to be teething issues. What if there's worse stuff than it's a bit of a fireball and some issues can't be fixed? Would you still buy it? The other issue is AMD's power management isn't quite as fine-tuned as Intels so we're going to see higher idle utilization on AMD as well which means we won't get the battery life we expect out of the same battery sizes. All in all it'd be great to see AMD in there but I think that Dell would be delivering a rushed unfinished platform if they'd done that.

If you want a laptop that doesn't throttle in games don't look for another XPS 15. XPS 15 is a nicely designed thin-and-light with relatively high specs but inadequate cooling for these specs when put to serious work hence it relies on throttling to keep itself from meltdown under long-term load. Look at gaming laptops with at least half a kg more heatpipes and cooling fins.

Maybe wait for proper reviews of the new 9500 and 9700 to pop up but basically anything 7590 and older will throttle due to poor thermal design. If it's only for gaming go with something like an Asus Zephyrus G14/G15 which are killer PCs.

Most Dell machines come with 10% factory wear which is actually intended bad calibration. Li-Po batteries degrade faster when charging the 90-100% of their true capacity along with trickle charging at 99-100%. Some companies feel the bite on customer support. Knowing the typical consumer will not wisely avoid those limitations or program his charge schedule to compensate for them they just ship with 10% wear. Of course all claims of battery longevity in marketing material do not account for the synthetic wear and reviewers get models without this most of the times. There are ways to manually remove the 10% wear. Google it for your model. The 1% off is either real wear or within margin of error of sensors.

Undervolting is unlickely to void warranty but will advice to be discrete on that aspect. Youve many options. One could be to call Dell and explain the overheating issues they will run a couple of test and probably help you with a solution. Even a huge repair like a motherboard replacement or fan replacement can not be the solution. If youve a working machine now you will have the same issues in the future and have to find what software wise works for you. Tweaking Dell devices can sometimes be a huge pain. First of all youve to know more about why your CPU temps are so high. What are your iddle temps max temps max clocks etc... Have you tried cleaning the fans ? Or repasting with a quality paste ? incoming rant... My laptop i got in user tag years after I graduated bought laptop in 2019 graduated 2017 . That said I'd suggest looking elsewhere before considering a dell g7/g5. The BIOS has been a CONSTANT issue for many people with this laptop and pending on what version you get will determine how unhappy you will be. Issues include but not limited to stuttering/freezing bad thermal performance fan curves lack of options for powefan profiles etc. Look into some other brands and see if you can get opinions on how users feel with that model like you are here. As far as battery goes you can reasonably expect poor life with just about any gaming laptop as far as I am aware. This line I'd say you can reasonably expect 2 maybe 3 hours mild use. Performance on battery will be heavily reduced. With full tweaking you can expect enough performance to watch 1080p 60 fps youtube but thats pushing it. If you DO decide to get one heres what I did with my laptop which is a slight upgrade and/or different from the g5 to mitigate most of the issues and max performance thermal i redid my thermal paste for CPU/GPU screen color upgraded to a 120hz panel storage replaced HDD with 1TB SSD ram upgraded from 16 to 32GB bios stopped updating after 1.9 wish i could go back to 1.3 i hear its the best for my model power options tweaked settings so CPU doesn't throttle as bad on battery can disable nvidia GPU in device manager for a more performance. surface temp i rigged a fan setup at my desk to cool everything down just that bit extra. unless they fixed issues after my model made in 2018 doubt it you can expect similar fun times All said and done however for the price I got mine 880 300 in upgrades it isn't a bad laptop that does great while plugged in and is adequate enough for short stints on battery. Desktop performance lets me run Destiny 2 1080p 60fps highest settings etc. TL DR look elsewhere before considering dell IMO. Linus Tech Tips constantly does laptop reviews. If you're serious about using for classes I suggest getting a more battery friendly laptop not gaming

A motherboard replacement means that the problem with your laptop is repairable. Whether or not this constitutes a minor or major problem I don't know --- but giving the manufacturer a chance to resolve your problem is important if things go south.

You can't just get a refund without giving the company an opportunity to repair it's unreasonable to expect a refund straight away after that period of time. Dell have offered a repair you should take that and sell it after.

You can ask a business for your preference of a free repair replacement or refund but you are not always entitled to one. For example the consumer guarantees do not apply if you got what you asked for but simply changed your mind found it cheaper somewhere else decided you did not like the purchase or had no use for it. See Exceptions to consumer guarantees If you have a minor problem with a product or service the business can choose to give you a free repair instead of a replacement or refund. When you have a major problem with a product you have the right to ask for your choice of a replacement or refund. For a major problem with a service you can choose to receive compensation for the drop in value below the price paid or a refund. Read your own laws. Let dell try to fix it then ask for a replacement or refund.
You will not get a refund just go for the repair.

I'm in Victoria Australia and have had a similar experience to you twice I had to take Dell to VCAT. If you are the complainant it only costs about 200 non-refundable to get a hearing but it's a small price to pay if you've forked out 4k for a premium laptop which you expect to work for many years. Not unreasonable. We have one of the best consumer laws in the world. Under Australian Consumer Law all goods are expected to last a reasonable amount of time. And that reasonable amount of time is SEVEN years. Period. Anyways as soon as a hearing date was set Dell immediately gave me a full refund. I'm assuming it would've cost them more than just the refund if they had to defend themselves court costs 'strike' against their name etc. Most people don't take it this far and Dell know this so they get away with it! But if more people stood up to these giants they would think twice about making products that don't last. We've all heard of planned obsolescence. Don't give up mate! Sooner or later they will give you your money back. Cheers hopefully I've been of help.

Yes you can undervolt to keep the Laptop from throttling but your best bet also is to set the the Turbo Boost power long and short to 25 watts which even at 3.0-3.2 ghz will still give good performance whilst lowering temperatures to those more less depending on the ambient temp also I would suggest undervolting the dGPU too to allow it to maintain higher boost clocks as when it reaches 75 degrees it will reduce somewhat. I wouldnt necessarily recommend disabling turbo also especially when the game you are playing can have a performance hit due to a cpu capped lower and your better off with 25 watts again

Update I think I figured it out. When the laptop is plugged in or docked ie on AC power it recognizes all cores and threads. Confirmed in dxdiag cpu-z and CB15 and CB20. 4 cores 8 threads when plugged in. On battery power it seems to disable hyperthreading. Only 4 processes run and from what I can tell it is using 4 cores just no HT. I could be wrong though our cups be disabling two cores on battery. Now I get to muck about in battery settings to see if I can disable that lovely /s feature.

I have same configuration as you I can tell you what helped me reduce temps. Undervolting using ThrottleStop Turning off HyperThreading in BIOS Yes I know that by turning off HyperThreading you will reduce cores from 8 to 4 but this gives me much more higher and stable performance and reduced temps. As for undervolt it decreased my temps by about 5 degrees which is not much but was just enough to stop it from thermal throttling the GPU. Good luck!

I own this laptop with the exact specs you have. It's true that this laptop heats up like crazy and has aggressive fan profiles. Another redditor and I both swapped out our thermal paste for liquid metal. Turns out the GPU and CPU dies and heatsinks are quite optimal for dealing with liquid metal. Both of us experienced 10 C drops in idle and peak temps under load. Unfortunately due to the way this laptop draws most of its air from the grille above the keyboard a laptop cooler just won't yield effective results. Hope this helps somewhat 👍🏾

I have the ASUS Zephryus GA502 w/ 1660ti Max Q and Ryzen 7 3750H. On idle I am at around 45C-50C. On some load like with Photoshop for 3 hours I am hovering 70C-80C. With a simple elevation stand 15 that raises the laptop one inch off the surface I was seeing 5C-10C decrease and on load as well. With a cooling pad I was seeing the same results. The way my laptop was designed air flow circulation is limited to the area above they keyboard. The cooling pad helped but not as much as I would like due to the design of my asus laptop. NOTE I also like my 15 stand over my laptop ran cooler because it is portable. It folds nearly and I can put it in my laptop bag. I use this set up with me everywhere. GOOD AIRFLOW ON THE GO 🙂. Okay so you need to specify the exact temperatures of your CPU/GPU. 80-90c is absolutely fine for a CPU in a thin gaming laptop however it's not okay if you're GPU is hitting those temps. Anything above 84c for the GPU and like 92-93c for the CPU is considered bad. So download Afterburner and monitor your temps properly first. There are a few things you can do before repasting. You can undervolt your CPU undervolt your GPU and even limit your CPU turbo boost. Make sure you know how to do these things first. Also since it's a new laptop you can send it in for them to repaste it for you if you don't wanna void the warranty. Otherwise if you're confident enough just repaste it yourself! If the laptop was in fact just sitting there for 2 years there always a probability that the thermal paste degraded.

I'm not experienced with Fortnite but I heared it's quite a heavy game surprisingly. Anyways try the following things Basics - Make sure you're playing while the laptop is charging you're probably doing this already . The battery can't deliver enough power for a powerful GPU thus lowering the performance. Windows settings - Right click the battery icon in the taskbar down below and click Windows Mobility Center . One of the tiles shows an image of a battery and probably have balanced in that same tile. Click on the balanced and set that to High Performance . This will increase the maximum power delivered to your laptop which means more performance but will lower battery life. NVidia Control Panel - Right click the desktop then NVidia Control Panel. In the menu on the left click Manage 3D Settings . In the list of settings scroll down to Power Management Mode . Set this to Prefer maximum performance . This tells the GPU that performance is more important than battery life. Now on that same page go to Program Settings . Check if Fortnite is in the list of programs. If this is not the case click Add Browse and go to wherever fortnite is installed possibly C Program Files Epic Games Fortnite . Add whatever starts Fortnite I expect this to be Fortnite or Fortnite.exe . If it is in the list ignore that part. Set the power management in this list also if this is not on prefer maximum performance . - Make sure it uses High Performance NVidia Processor how however it's called and not Integrated Graphics or Auto Select . This forces the game to run on the NVidia GPU. - In the control panel click Adjust image settings with preview in the left menu. Select Use my performance emphasizing and set this to performance. This will reduce the graphics a bit there's a preview so you can see the effects directly for a bit of extra performance. Fans I do not know where to change this in an ASUS laptop so somebody or the interwebs else might be able to help out. Your fans cool down your device. It could be that the temperatures in the laptop might be too high to squeeze out extra performance. Setting the fan curve to a more aggressive one fans blow earlier and harder might get some extra performance but you'll have to check if that is possible with that laptop I assume it is and how to do that. This should help a lot already. Do keep in mind that advertised performance is measured in a perfect scenario possibly with overclocked hardware which I absolutely do not recommend doing in a laptop or that it was measured with the strongest GPU that is in that series. There should be a list of specs somewhere on which version of the laptop this was tested on.

Well depending on what failed you might be able to fix the laptop yourself. If it's just heat re-pasting installing a fresh Windows image and then undervolting responsibly may help. If it's the battery you can replace those from online stores depending on the model. Keep in mind just like re-pasting this could require a lot of work on your part but to save a 3000 investment I believe it's worth it. As for other suggestions to find better quality unfortunately many modern laptops follow the recent trend of going as thin and light as possible... Which of course leads to stability issues on more powerful hardware. You should check out Jarrod's Tech on YouTube. He gives unbiased reviews on hardware and isn't afraid to lay into a system if it doesn't meet his standards. The machines he reviews tend to be gaming laptops. Keep in mind more often than not on this forum even you're more likely to run into people who have problems with a product because if it's working fine most people don't have an interest in participating with the forums. But if there is a problem they'll let everybody know. Of course in th case of ASUS the general consensus is they're shit now. The G14 might buy them some praise but I don't expect it'll be long before thermal issues start to pop up with that thing. The new Alienware M15 R3 features vapor chamber cooling which has been known to be handy but since it just launched it'll be some time before we know if it helps much... Plus the Alienware price jump is something to be concerned about. Overall just research machines before you buy them. Many people don't know much about thermals TDP and stuff like that and many companies will leverage that to sell overpriced flimsy machines that simply don't have longevity.

The G75 and that whole jet engine design series was so badass. Now all ASUS machines are these flimsy super thin ultrabook style machines that favor aesthetics over consistent internal cooling. They use these crappy AMD-in-tandem-with-GPU systems that share heat pipes between the two and crappy buggy software to regulate temps and voltages software that mind you breaks half the time under the most normal of circumstances. All this results in temps that regularly climb into the mid to high 90s which for modern processing architectures is actually within spec but still hot enough for concern when the failure threshold is just above 100 degrees Celsius. The fear of having these software systems break and fail to cool the processors in time to prevent damage is one of the many reasons I hardly ever touch my GA502. All this could be avoided if they just nut up and make the machines a little thicker with better pasting dedicated heat pipes and bigger fans and the jet engine series as I like to call them is proof they can do this and still have the laptops looking quite nice and very portable. In fact I favor the old aesthetic from a purely visual standpoint as well. I don't know what it is about gaming PC manufacturers feeling like everything has to be as thin and light as possible. This is a tangent frankly this whole comment is but the cell phone industry did this excessively until like three years ago when they realized they simply can't pack all these features into an ultra-slim ultra-light design without making concessions on the battery and heat yes phones and tablets can overheat and it happens more often than many think . Now you'll notice cell phones are getting bigger and heavier with better displays tonplacate the ignorant masses who thought slim-and-light was just the bee's knees. The big difference with cell phones is that if your battery gets too hot expands punctures itself on an internal component and ignites your handheld device just turned into a chemical bomb. On a laptop however the thing will just fail to operate before anything gets hot enough to physically harm the user... But you'll still have lost some expensive hardware. So why haven't PC manufacturers taken notes on this? It's not just an ASUS issue Dell has the same fixation with their Alienware M15/M17 series being super thin and while those do actually function better under most circumstances even while hot 90 Celsius range they can control the throttling and still deliver consistent performance they shouldn't be getting that hot in the first place. MakeLaptopsThiccAgain is basically what I'm saying.
I am looking at all that dust that was removed... that alone definitely accounts for some of the reduced temps

That's a sign of a dying ROM or even the flash chip itself. I fixed some Motorolas in the past who had similar problems booting up and/or crashing and fixed it by reinstalling the ROM on the phone. You'll need a Windows PC the ROM for that specific ASUS device and a flash tool. Every manufacturer has its own tools. By googling it's likely that you'll find a tutorial on how to flash ASUS phones or even THAT specific phone. After reinstalling the ROM completely the problem should be gone. If it STILL happens it's a hardware failure Though unlikely since your phone boots up Since you go through the steps of flashing a complete ROM you could check out LineageOS. It's an Android that doesn't come with bloatware and is 100% pure even the Play Store you must flash manually. Currently it's on Android 10 Would be an upgrade for you faster than ASUS lol Plus points by installing this ROM mentioned above The tutorial has you 100% covered and you just need to follow the steps. If you want to revert later it's possible. Just search for the stock ROM Little caveat By flashing Lineage you might void your warranty.

Use HWMonitor to check your voltages and temps. Sometimes the ASUS Armoury Crate 'performance' profile fixes this by maxing out the fans and regulating clock speed. Of you don't have Armoury Crate installed just know you need to. It is absolutely essential for the function of any gaming on most ASUS laptops. Arpiry Crate tends to break itself under the most mundane circumstances however so make sure if you're installing it to reboot after the install is finished and also have all the AMD/Chipset/Vega drivers installed. AMD handles cooperation with graphics cards in a weird kind of 'sharing' mode which can sometimes read usually cause issues unless the workload environment is perfectly within the variables Armoury Crate and the Vega drivers expect to receive.

That’s literally what heat pipes are supposed to do but if your exhaust vents are clogged or fans are not moving air either not spinning fast enough or have blockages then the heat pipes can’t TRANSFER the heat away. Replacing the thermal compound as other suggested will only transfer more heat from the chip to the heat pipes but if the heat transfer after that is the actual problem it won’t make any difference and may even make that spot hotter as more heat can be transferred in to the pipe from the chip.

Are you seeing high temps on your CPU and GPU using HWINFO64 to check. Also check to make sure the radiators just behind those fans arent clogged with dust if they are then likely thats the problem. You can clean them out using compressed air if you want the quick and easy way. Or for a proper clean you can remove the heat pipes and radiators and give it a proper clean its simple enough to do and so long as you dont go bashing about trying to force things you wont break anything whilst you have the heat pipes and radiators up you could swap out the thermal paste to some arctic silver stuff doubt it will make a great deal of measurable difference though .
Clean the fins of the fans and clean the heatsink fins if that doesn't work change the paste if you need help on me and I can walk you through it Edit download hwinfo and give me temp readings

those should get hot they are transferring heat from your components that need heat dissipation to the back of your laptop to be dissipated by your fans. the only way to make them cooler is to have the fans run fastelouder. don't listen to anyone telling you to replace your thermal compound the job of the compound is to form a seal between the copper heatsink and the component you are transferring heat from. better compound more heat transferred to pipe. hot pipe good transfer good compound. the pipe SHOULD feel hot to you. it is not hot to the components. heck it's probably only 50 celsius which would feel like it is burning you but is completely fine for your pc. if you want it to run cooler turn up the fans. that's your only real option. this is just a problem when it comes to putting high performance in a thin chassis. you don't have much buffer room between the heatsinks and your lap and will feel that heat.
I can say that my cpu runs at like 81c when playing fortnite but when i play games like r6 siege or gta 5 it runs a bit cooler really wierd might be because fortnite is more cpu based
its supposed to get hot its literally the whole point of the cooling system.

Well they are heat pipes they will get hot because of the amount of heat transferred inside them. But if they get too hot that means your fans aren't doing a great job of driving the heat away. Make sure the exhaust vents aren't clogged and your fans are clean too so they can spin comfortably .

pull the entire heatsink and repaste with kryonaut it will trasnfer more efficiently and theoretically not run as hot since its able to get the heat into the pipes better before the chips are in melt down territory

No matter what GPU you choose with that CPU all of them will be bottlenecked. Most of the games don't use the CPU that much so in 99% of the cases you'll see your CPU utilisation at 30% while the GPU is at 99%. That doesn't mean you won't get some good performance out of it. It's about that in terms of graphic intensive games the CPU will always wait for the GPU no matter if it's an 2080ti or a 1650ti it's only about what performance that graphics card can push in the end. To give you an example with the CPU at 30% utilisation and the 1650ti at 100% utilisation you will get 60FPS in a specific game While in the same scenario but with an 2080ti will get 100fps at 100% GPU utilisation. I did some digging since i’ve ordered a zephryus s15 and i’ve found out how to undervolt with the new bios but it’s at your own risk should be fine if you only change one thing . If you follow the link it’ll show you how to edit the bios. Instead of giving supervisor access to the SATA options like in the tutorial enable supervisor access on Overclocking Performance Menu and then flash it. Make sure you keep a backup if you do it because if something goes wrong you’ll be able to revert it. When you go back into BIOS this menu will be there go into it and enable XTU interface now you’ll be able to undervolt in throttlestop or XTU. I hope this helps! BIOS EDIT TUTORIAL

Well I would suggest that you wait to purchase the additional memory as no one but the factory will know what memory is in the computer. With any factory built PC the components will differ because the factory will always be buying the components they don't produce at the lowest price that meets their specification. Once you get the PC you can check with CPU-Z as to what is actually in it so that you can purchase the same thing if available . You could also order the PC with the amount of memory you actually want and therefore get the same memory most likely 2 DIMMs . Good luck!

x200B I suspect you have a short of some kind somewhere. Start from scratch remove the motherboard from the case place it on the static bag it came in on top of the box or a flat surface. Connect the 24 pin EATX and the 8 pin EATX if your PSU have a 2nd EPS12v cable spit that and connect the 4 pin EATX. I suspect the RM550x doesn't have 2nd EPS12v but the 24 8 pin should do fine Install one DDR4 stick in DIMMA2 Install the GTX 1050 ti and connect the 6 pin PCIe cable. Reset CMOS for good measure. heres the steps. first try this 1. shut down pc turn power switch off on psu. wait 15 sec. 2. power on go to bios F4 aura off 3. go into windows shut down again flip psu again. 4. power on bios aura on then see if the board re syncs with the aura app. If steps above fail do this may take 1-2x but it does work 1. uninstall aura and lighting services. 2. go into program files asus erase anything that says aura or lighting service 3. go into program 86 erase asus and lighting service folders. 4. install cc cleaner and clean registry files or B manually delete aura and lighting service registrys in regedit. 5. shut down. wait 10 sec power on bios aura off. 6. install latest aura. shutdown wait 10 sec 7. power on bios aura on now when you go into windows you should see it blink and go all rainbow then have control again.

I have one in use for about 2 weeks and at first I was really disappointed. This device really has a problem with temperatures when in stock conditions. At first battery run time was not near to those values represented in youtube reviews but with the newest firmware 5 to 6 1/2 hours with below mentioned office tasks are realistic which is pretty sweet in my opinion. Overall build quality is more than OK for the price available ports are also decent and I like the look because it looks not gamey . I ve bought mine for 1350 EUR 4800HS 1660TI 16GB RAM 1 TB NVME incl. Taxes compared to the G14 in the same configuration rougly 2000 EUR incl. Taxes this notebook offers good value. Coming from a desktop I ve always found it somewhat strange that temperatures from 85 - 95 C are considered normal for a notebook. I personally can accept temperatures around 80 C if they occur under heavy performance duties aka gaming. Average CPU GPU Temperatures with below tweaks Office tasks like browsing coding watching videos 41 - 54 C Gaming Bannerlord Total War Warhammer 2 65 - 72 C Unfortunately the fans are not software controllable yet so when doing office tasks my temps will slowly increase from 40 to 54 C and the fans then will start working. Software related Probably the most f upped power plan settings I ve ever seen did result the device to deliver a minimum 100 % of power to the cpu - CPU temps when browsing avg. 65 - 67 C Can be solved by reducing minimum wattage to 3 - 5 % the device will constantly boost the cpu under heavy conditions like gaming even if it is not even close to necessary set maximum wattage to 99 % this will cause lower base clock speeds which is not what you want or modify one entry in the registry so you can disabling CPU-boost in the power plan settings. As this CPU is game changing powerful I did not notice any differences. the Armoury Crate Performance Settings do some really strange things on my device so I ve set the mode to Windows and modified two power plan settings that I am comfortable with Hardware related the pasting is really poor I estimate the Dies have been covered by about 95 % I have repasted every chip that is cooled by the heatpipe with one tube of 3.5g Gelid GC extreme - really solid improvement. Just be aware that different screws have been used so take notes or pictures. Even when unscrewed the heatpipe does not come off easily you will need to apply some reasonable force. Before this process I ve only done some mods on desktops so this whole thing felt like a operation to me D When correctly done this should not remove your warranty in most countries afaik The air vents of the CPU GPU fan are blocked by what I call it AMD paper. Removing this paper will again decrease your temperatures by a lot. This will void your warranty so do it as you are comfortable with it or not. ASUS states this is to improve air flow to other mainboard components see youtube reviews but I call that bullshit. The exact same chassis has been used for a new Intel version of this notebook and guess what despite the exact same components the air intakes are not blocked. I did take a risk here because I feel this way the notebook has a chance to reach a respectable life span otherwise I think with those temperatures it will be case of warranty runs out and it destroys itself. There is a temperature sensor for the NVME present and the temperatures now are the same or even lower I did not make any notes for this unfortunately.
Also have an issue where a dialog box pops up saying cannot find oc scan profile data

I've run into this issue a bunch. In Bios go to Boot CSM Launch CSM Enable. I would also disable Fast Boot which is in Boot Configuration. Edit If that doesn't work let me know and I can give you some other steps to try.

Hello Had the same issue with M2 nvme ssd on an another Asus Board. is your ssd NVME or SATA ? try this and read it to the end hope your bios is the same and i know some of your options are already right Verify SATA controller is set to - EnabledSet SATA Mode to - RAID Go back one screen then select Onboard Device Configuration. Set SATA Mode Configuration to - SATA Express Go back one screen. Click on the Boot tab then scroll down the page to CSM. Click on it to go to next screen. Set Launch CSM to - DisabledSet Boot Device Control to - UEFI onlyBoot from Network devices can be anything.Set Boot from Storage Devices to - UEFI onlySet Boot from PCI-E PCI Expansion Devices to - UEFI only Go back one screen. Click on Secure Boot to go to next screen. Set Secure Boot state to - DisabledSet OS Type to - Windows UEFI mode Go back one screen. Look for Boot Option Priorities - Boot Option 1. Click on the down arrow in the outlined box to the right and look for your flash drive. It should be preceded by UEFI example UEFI Sandisk Cruzer . Select it so that it appears in this box.

I say go for the new Asus ROG Zephyrus G14 if you want processing power that isn't only for productivity but ultra settings gaming as well. The thing is a beast and provides more than enough power for everyday tasks in a thin and light package as well as boasting a 10-hour battery life doing everyday tasks such as browsing which really is impressive for a mobile gaming solution. The new Ryzen 9 chip absolutely dominates any other mobile processer and it's packed with an RTX 2060 as well. The whole thing comes with a 1tb ssd and 16gb of ram for 1450 which is really solid. I believe the most impressive aspect of the laptop is its thermal solution which was so well thought out pretty rare for ASUS to be honest . Inside there is a dual heat sink with dual fans and ample vents on the side center and bottom. The ergonomic lift allows for greater airflow and a solid typing angle. The keyboard is fantastic although the backlighting is a bit uneven. Because of this design flaw I would go for the black model. The screen has a 120 hz refresh rate and a really even rgb gradient as well as solid nits in the brightness. Response time is a tab bit off but its barely noticeable and really solid for gaming manageable ghosting as well. Build quality is really good as well lots of thought and care went into a very sleek design. It outdoes previous ROG iterations 10 fold. I have the same laptop. The Armoury Crate profiles are kind of messed up in how they approach power. Manual is broken. It just doesn't work so ignore it. Performance and Turbo deliver full power at all times with the latter ramping up the fan speed to a greater degree. Even if I manually set the minimum processor state to 5% done through the advanced power profile options in the Windows control panel in either profile the CPU never downclocks remaining in the 4.0-4.2 GHz range. In Silent mode the processor downclocks properly. There's a registry tweak for the power options that exposes a separate option to disable turbo boost all together so the CPU's maximum frequency will top out at 2.6 GHz. I did this for the Silent profile and it's been working out really well. It's my primary gaming profile since most of the games I'm playing are older and/or not particularly demanding. It should work well for Oblivion in your case and it's also surprisingly capable for newer releases. With the optimized silent profile the system can still average more than 90 fps in Forza Motorsport 7 with a minimum of about 75. Instructions for applying the registry fix are available in this thread Good luck.

That doesn't sound like any beep code that Asus uses here is the list of what they use One short beep - VGA detected No keyboard detected Two short beeps - When using Crashfree to recover BIOS the new BIOS is successfully recognized. One continuous beep followed by two short beeps then a pause repeated - No memory detected One continuous beep followed by three short beeps - No VGA detected One continuous beep followed by four short beeps - Failure of Hardware component Hope this helps good luck! Hi thanks for reaching out to our team. We're sorry for the inconvenience and we're happy to assist. Were there any recent software or hardware changes made? Can you recall if any windows update took place recently? Also does the Mic work on any other application? If not we would advise that you perform a system restore. This will try to keep any personal files such as document music pictures but remove any application that was installed after the date selected. Select the Windows logo Bottom left of your screen - Select Settings The gear wheel icon - Select Update and Security - Select Recovery .- Advanced Startup Click Restart Now - Select Troubleshoot - Select Advance Options - Select System Restore - Select a previous date from the list Ensure that Show additional restore point checkbox to the bottom left is checked if being shown - Select Next then Finish - Please wait for a response from the Computer stating that the System Restore has completed. Please let us know if the issue remains the same after doing so

This may be too simple if so I apologize in advance. ☺ When the router shows the internet status as disconnected hook a wired device laptop with wired network port is good directly to the modem powered box between the router and cable that goes out of the house . If the wired device connects the router has issues if it does not connect most likely is your internet service provider has issues. One thing I do when I get the disconnected response is to check the modem status. Depends on model modem manuals are available for download typically that show what the lights mean but if the lights on the front of the modem are mostly off a problem with your provider is likely the issue. Also most modems have a reset button that can be pushed with a toothpick or paper clip. If the internet is disconnected resetting the modem sometimes helps. Hope that helps!

I just got an A15 a couple days ago. I only use it connected to my TV as an HTPC and for living room gaming so I can't comment much on its suitability as an everyday laptop. That said my impressions are I think the design looks nice and the build quality is pretty good. The keys and trackpad feel good to me. The screen is kinda washed out but considering the insane amount of CPU and GPU power you're getting at this price point it's hard to complain. It feels lightweight considering how big it is. The lid for the screen looks pretty classy and it opens with surprisingly little effort. The cooling solution is good. Temperatures stay low and nothing throttles. It could be quieter but you could say that about any gaming laptop probably. I've never owned a gaming laptop before but I've been reading a lot of reviews. Using it in Silent mode will often allow it to completely stop the fan and then it's obviously completely silent although when it does occasionally spin up it's kind of annoying. The minimum fan speed is 2200 RPM which is audible and it has kind of a whine to it. Depending on what you're doing the fan will also sometimes speed up and slow down and that's noticeable. I don't have much experience with Windows laptops so I don't know if this amount of noise is common. Install the drive you want as C under the heat sink first install Windows. It will be the boot drive going forward. Add the second M.2 later and it will be assigned D. You can always go in and change or re-assign things later and there are ways to know which is which from BIOS but it can be a bit daunting trying to figure it out. Motherboard manual will also tell you. I have found it is just simpler to do it as above install the drive you want to boot from under the heat sink and you are good to go. M.2 slots are connected differently on motherboard. The one between CPU and PCIe 16x is connected to CPU directly and the second M.2 slot is connected through Northbridge chip. If you got really high speed M.2 like 5000Mb/sec Sabrent drive you might get better speed with top M.2 slot than bottom M.2 slot. I can't find 100% verifiable and reliable source but it seems like some random testing I saw on Youtube reported about 5% speed difference between that 2 M.2 slots.

for those who read this in the future it turns out - it doesnt matter since the Corsair Force Series MP600 NVMe PCIe Gen4 x4 M.2 I bought for it have their own heat sinks and so dont even fit unless you remove the heatsink that comes with the motherboard... this didnt even occur to me until i was installing them. the heatsink that came with the mobo is now in trashcan. Sidenote - the M.2s do not come with screws or little posts - they assume your motherboard provides those which this ASUS board did so I was fine but had a moment of panic when opening the Corsairs. In addition the answer i found is a little more complicated than I thought - the M.2 next to the CPU is listed and 1 but it is only PCIe 4.0 if you have a 3rd gen chip otherwise it is 3.0 - the M.2 with heatsink next to the northbridge chipset labeled 2 in the manual is 4.0 regardless of your CPU. Hope this helps someone one day. thanks to all who helped me!

Found this looking for a fix for my situation which is the similar. I have the AX89X and had it set up as a solo router for the house for about a week. I ordered two of the 86U routers to try and set them up as AiMesh nodes to help strengthen the signal at either ends of the house so the AX89U would be in the middle. Currently testing has only been to use one 86U at a time. The problem I’m experiencing is not with the initial set up. Link a node to the main router and devices connect to and I’m getting great speeds through the mesh. The 86U node router will at least once a day just say its offline. Pull the power cord and put it back in a boom back to working again. Or if I have a device connected to the node and everything is working good and I put it down to take the dog for a walk when I come back I have a connection to the node router but no internet connection. Some time toggling the devices wifi off and back on will fix the internet connection. Some times it requires restarting the router even through it doesn’t show as being offline to fix it. Seems most times it is some but not all devices connected to the node that are having a problem. Last night I was watching a movie on my iPad which was connected to the node and half way through I had just lost my connection and had to toggle wifi on and off to get the connection back. So while at first I thought it was it just couldn’t make the reconnection after sleeping I am having an issue with an active connection. There shouldn’t need to be this much restarting toggling powering off to get the mesh to work. This set up is replacing the two Apple Airport Extremes I’ve been using for years.

First Like said already graphics card needs to be in first slot. The first slot is the only X16 slot on that board second the NVME drive in the top slot will steal PCIe lanes and make the first X16 slot into an X8 slot which is totally fine a 2080ti only suffers about 2% loss on an X8 gen 3 slot. Now for the other issue. Enable nvme support in bios should be enabled already but good to check. Secondly try disconnecting all other drives and see if it comes up third enable CSM save changes and reset.

I have this same laptop purchased for 1 300 when Best Buy had it as one of its daily deals a couple weeks ago. Out of the box the Armoury Crate software was saying one of its components needed an update. It would download and install but the update notification would still come back. It wasn't really affecting anything so I left it alone. I tried to undervolt using ThrottleStop but my settings were too aggressive causing an endless BSOD boot loop. Tried using the built-in recovery partition but it got stuck in the middle. I ended up wiping the drive completely and starting over with a bootable USB. After some initial trouble getting Armoury Crate and the SSD cache set up properly it's been working fine - for the most part. I love the feel of the keyboard the hardware packs a punch and I can achieve 4-5 hours of battery life in Silent mode doing basic tasks without an undervolt which is great for a laptop with a high-power six-core CPU. Haven't done a ton of gaming yet but in Performance mode it has no problems maintaining a solid 144 fps in Doom 2016 at a mix of high and ultra settings. Temps seem to stabilize in the 70-75 range when the fans ramp up which can get a bit loud but this is a characteristic you have to expect from a thin and light gaming laptop. The screen is amazing. You can charge it via USB-C which can be handy if you need a bit of extra juice in a pinch. The fact that it comes with a 1 TB SSD out of the box is nice and you can add more via a second M.2 slot. Note that the standard 16 GB of RAM is soldered to the motherboard and runs only in single-channel mode. I would recommend ponying up another 60- 70 on a second 16 GB stick to put in the free available slot as you'll see a noticeable bump in CPU performance by moving to dual channel. The only thing about the physical design that I really find negative is the fact that the WiFi card is also soldered to the motherboard. At least it's an Intel 9560 which is an excellent unit but moving up to WiFi 6 later is out of the question unless you get an external dongle. Their decision to do this on the GU502GV is even more baffling when you consider that you can upgrade the WiFi hardware in the cheaper GA502DU which has a virtually identical form factor. Overall I'm satisfied with it. At its current sale price of 1 450 as of this writing I think it's a bit overpriced but if it comes back down to 1 300 again I would say it's worth it.

I don't have a workaround but do have the most likely reason for your having issues and a suggestion. ZEN 2 processors are rated 3200 MHz actually MT/s processors. Anything above that is dependent on your memory controller silicon lottery . Also with you using 16Gb DIMMs this will also stress your memory controller more. I saw that your memory is on the QVL list for the board but the board is not the processor. That said are you just using the DOCP or are you tweaking settings? Maybe try using the Thaiphoon Burner and DRAM Calculator for Ryzen combination to tweak your settings turn off DOCP and manually apply settings . Good luck!

We're terribly sorry about this happening. We will be more than happy to help. We're going to recommend that you check to see if there are any available windows update on your unit. 1. Check the settings of output device a. Type and search Sound settings in the Windows search bar 1 then click on Open c. Check if the speaker volume set to mute mode . Click on Sound Control Panel in the sound settings. d. Select Playback tab then select Internal speaker and click on Properties e. Select Levels tab use the slider bar to adjust volume level and check if it does not set to mute mode then click on OK to save. Mute mode 2. Enable and reinstall the driver in Device Manager a. Type and search Device Manager in the Windows search bar then click on Open . b. Check on the arrow next to Audio inputs and outputs then right-click on Internal Speaker and select Enable device . If the Enable device option does not display that is meant the touchscreen function is enabled already please continue to the next step c. Right-click on Internal Speaker then select Update driver . D. Click on Search automatically for updated driver software e. Windows is searching online for drivers. f. The automatic update is completed please click on Close 9 . g. If you fail to update speaker driver in device manager please go to the ASUS Support Site to download and install the Audio driver learn more about How to search and download drivers The following pictures are the current version as a reference please download the latest version from the ASUS Support Site.
I would say probably 3200 MT/s RAM is what the CPU is rated for but why do you want to run a single DIMM? FYI the 64Gb kit you listed is 4 of the same DIMMs as the 16Gb single your asking about.

For one thing you are best off buying a kit of 2 sticks of DDR so a 2x8GB kit if you want 16GB as the sticks are likely to be better matched that way. Second thing is 32gb kits are less likely to overclock well due to them having dual rank chips. Third is that a 3200 rated kit will have been tested at that speed on intel and is less likely to run stable at that speed on AMD. So if you want it to run 3200 buy a 3400 kit. Also because of the silicon lottery you could get a kit that overclocks well or one that doesn't.

Such issue can be due to these possible reasons 1 Fast startup is taking time storing system image. just turn it off you won't lose performance. This solved it for me. To turn off fast-startup start/settings/control panel/power options/Choose what the power buttons do left menu pane /change settings that are currently available just above the power button listing /shutdown settings underneath password protection / uncheck fast start-up and hibernate 2 Intel's Management Engine Remove it and get v9 or so.

Hi Destroyer10super thanks for reaching out to our team. We do apologize for any inconvenience and we'll be more than happy to assist. Was this issue always present or did it recently develop? Also were there any software or hardware changes around the time this issue started? We'd recommend that you factory reset your device. However before doing that reset Be sure that your device has at least %50 charge life and Logout from your Google Account to remove the FRP Lock. Also just to be advised your data will be wiped. Any information that's not backed you will not be able to retrieve. - Power off your device and wait a few seconds. - Press and hold Volume Up Power buttons together until recovery mode screen appears. These button combinations can change on different modals. - When you see the Asus logo release the Power button but keep holding Volume Up until the recovery mode screen comes. - Leave all the buttons when Recovery Mode screen appears. - Go to Wipe Data/Factory Reset option using Volume Down and press Power button to confirm it. - Go to Yes –Delete All User Data using Volume Down and press Power button to continue. - After the process finishes go to Reboot System Now and press Power button.

Switching the disk interface to AHCI from IDE or RAID changed the way your computer interfaces your storage devices with your operating system. Likely what happened was that Windows was still expecting your disks to be connected to the IDE/RAID controller and tried to communicate with them but was failing. Somewhere along that chain of reboots it installed the drivers for the AHCI controller and was able to boot again. To answer your question no it's unlikely that setting a BIOS password had anything to do with preventing Windows to boot. Although I highly recommend against setting a BIOS password unless you know what you're doing as it adds needless complication for barely any security gain whatsoever.

After studying your photo in great detail I'm fairly certain the socket is LGA1155. I can just make out 'LG 55' at the top right of the CPU fan. The only LGA socket series ending in 55 is the LGA1155. Plus I can just see a 'P8Z77' just above the PCIe slot where the graphics card is. The only motherboard that looks anywhere similar to yours I can find on PC Part Picker is the Asus P8Z77-V LK ATX LGA1155. You won't know for sure until you take those cards out and have a clearer look at that model number but I'm 90% confident it is the Asus P8Z77-V LK. Also download and install Speccy which will tell you what components you have in your system. x200B

The 502DU is a decent option as long as you can get it for less than 1 000. I got one when it was 900 a couple weeks ago. The keyboard was one of the best I've ever used and I've owned plenty of laptops. Out of the box the Performance and Turbo modes in Armoury Crate set the CPU to 100% performance at all times which caused idle temperatures to hover in the 55-60 degree range. Setting the minimum to 5% while plugged in or on battery dropped those readings to a far more manageable 38-43. I disabled turbo boost on mine as I didn't encounter a situation where I felt it was necessary. The newest game I tried to play on it was Doom 2016 and with the Vulkan API it had no problems maintaining a 100 fps average at 1080p and high settings. The stock WiFi card was horrendous but that was easy enough to swap for an Intel AX200. You could even go with an Intel 9560 if you wanted to save a few bucks - I've seen it as low as 10- 13 online. nbsp All this said I'm going to be swapping out this system for the GU502GV since Best Buy put it on sale for 1 300 as one of its daily deals and the store nearest me has it in stock. The better specifications 6-core CPU RTX GPU 1 TB SSD 144 Hz screen RGB keyboard are worth that much of a price premium.

I just wanna point out something for others if they had or are having the same problem I did. I agree with a lot of what OP says but the unit I got had a major problem with thermal throttling. There's no reason that you should be afraid to brick your computer just because you install another OS onto it. Linux runs well on most Thinkpads. There are other computer makes that are far less linux-friendly eg. Acer or HP but even that one cannot generalise. Yet with Thinkpads especially older models you can just go ahead.

My T440s works perfectly with Linux one issue with trackpad - see below . It's a very similar machine to yours so I would imagine that should also be fine. The one minor issue I had was that the trackpad would sometimes not wake up correctly after the laptop went to sleep. But that might be reoslved now because I last tried it a year ago.

I wouldn't worry about bricking your computer simply by installing Linux. You're basically only writing data to your hard drive this way and not much can go wrong with that. You could brick your computer by flashing a BIOS update and something going wrong for an example.

EVERY ThinkPad I've ever owned has run Linux nearly perfectly. I have Debian running on my x220 x230 P50 X201s x201 and soon W541. I just DD an image from one linux machine to another. The older ones with Classic Keyboards and no dGPU need tweaks but you can't brick your laptop just by installing an OS. You can make it temporarily non-bootable but there's nothing you can do that would prevent reinstall of Windows or Linux. I recommend getting a USB drive or second SSD/HDD and boot a LiveOS version of something like Ubuntu Pop!OS or MX. There are plenty of HowTos to guide you. Good luck and welcome to Team Tux!
You can't really 'brick' a laptop unless you corrupt its firmware/BIOS. If you want to preserve your Windows install just image the drive first.

In terms of performance the T480 has all the other machines you've listed beat. As for it being sluggish that really depends on what you intend to use it for. I wouldn't really bother with the L and E series if you've got a T series budget. As for the 7490 it's built well and has a better panel than the stock FHD panel on the T480 but yes the 7490 and it's successor the 7400 do run hot. The T480 still has the edge in terms of performance that one notebookcheck review with the T480 and the i7 8650U has some strange numbers .

If you'd like something fast for a limited budget go AMD - they're faster and cheaper than Intel offerings. As for the build quality current day E series is decent and L series is now practically on par with T series so don't be too afraid to prioritize performance. As a fun weekend project I tried to get as much of Windows 98 SE working on my ThinkPad T60 as I could. The laptop officially only supports Windows XP and later and a lot of things like network access couldn't work. That said I did find a generic VGA driver capable of driving higher resolutions and colors and a USB 2.0 driver that let me transfer files off and on albeit unreliably . I was able to install Office 97 and Photoshop 5.5 and get some real offline work done! Tried to play games as well some like Midtown Madness 2 worked great others like NFS 2 SE and DOOM worked but in 256 color mode which is messed up in this generic driver. I wish there were a driver for the ATi X1400 for Win9x but I wasn't able to find any. Overall it was pretty fun one-time experience! As someone who grew up with Windows XP it was fun going through DOS and ScanDisk and everything to the Wild West days of Win9x from before I was born. '

If you dont have any older thinkpad keyboard experience to compare it to the x250 keyboard is simply great. You should not let yourself be blinded by the keyboard look at everything else these three models have to offer and make a decision based on that instead. x220 will probably be cheapest and actually quite fast for the money with average to below average battery life . x250 can be a bit sluggish depending on what processor you end up with but good battery life and nice screen options out of the box but also very sucky ones . Is the x250 a quality machine compared to the x220? Any handicaps that should be noted? I have both well it's a x230 . The x230 feel sturdier than the x250 but that's also because the x250 is thinner which is probably what's giving me that impression. There's been some threads here that said the x250/x260 suffers from bad internals eg. the RAM module shifts when the laptop is held on one end but I have not experienced this. x200B Is the KB horrendous or meh or good for a modern KB? As I'm going to be a student soon it's fairly important. It has a nice travel to it so it still feels tactile which is great for typing. I recently measured the key size for another poster compared x250 vs x230 chicklet KB . The size of the lettenumber keys are the same but the other keys are smaller. The spacing is also a little off. From Q to P the x250 KB was shorter by about 0.5inch. If you're only using the x250 you'll get used to it. My issue was that it's my only machine that has a newer keyboard so i still have mistypes when i use it.

X250 or a T450s is what I would recommend not the 2nd gen x1 carbon Lenovo kinda sh t the bed with its keyboard layout for that generation . The keyboard will be a change from the x220 mostly just slicker keys and a bit less efficient layout. Personally got used to it and don't mind as much anymore better than most other brands keyboards still. Just make sure to look for a fhd panel as otherwise you will get less than great tn panels. As for school I have used my T450s for a long time and it works fine with most things great for writing code and general usage.

Well I had a T440s as my main machine which is basically the same sans TrackPoint buttons . What I loved about this one is that design wise it is very similar to the regular T series – non-wedge design straight edges boxy look. That makes it unique among the newer T4xxs since the T460s switched to an X1 Carbon inspired wedge-design. It just oozes that classic ThinkPad feeling more but unlike the regular T450 it has much better materials Magnesium base cover instead of plastic and it also has smaller bezels so it is more compact. It also retains the Powerbridge which was certainly nice to have in the pre-USB-C era. T440s and T450s along with the T440p also were the first T ThinkPads since the T60 to feature an IPS screen. I made the switch from a Surface Book to my current X1C5 a few years ago. The primary reason for the switch was the fact that I simply can't live with Windows and Thinkpad's generally have great Linux support but to sum it all up The Thinkpad comes out on top as the better laptop by far in my opinion. The Surface Book is cool but unless you really need the detachable tablet as a feature I don't see a sensible reason to buy one. The Thinkpad wins in the following areas for me - Better keyboard - Trackpoint - More durable - More servicable - Linux support - Much better IO - Much faster SSDs - Better WiFi Intel - Native ethernet - Integrated WWAN I use it so much! - Matte display - Lighter smaller and the hinge is far better. Stiff no wobble and can rotate a full 180 degrees. x200B The Surface Book has a few things going for it though especially if you use your computer for media consumption primarily. - 3 2 aspect ratio - Better speakers - Detachable tablet and great pen support - dGPU optional in the base x200B The only thing I miss about the Surface Book was the fact that the design was so unique and the tactile feeling of detaching the screen even if the awesome click sound is artificial was so satisfying. In the end though the Thinkpad is much more comfortable to use as a pure laptop. I feel Lenovo has pretty much perfected the conventional laptop at this point and I don't really understand why people go for XPS's and Macbooks that give you 2 USB-C ports and a headphone jack and that's it.
