'Decade long' is going to be pretty much impossible to predict. You can google what 10 year old machines are still in use today but they are unlikely to live for another 10 however if you want to you can replace every dying component one at a time as long as you can find replacements making it at least a theoretical possibility . We have no idea how current machines will age we will know in 10 years but thats not really useful now. Modern machines will not allow component replacements like the old ones did so as long as you keep throwing new motherboards at a laptop you could probably make a modern thinkpad last 10 years but i dont think thats what you are after here. Going for a decent workstation and buying all the extended warranty you can will probably give you the most long lasting experience. Put some money aside to replace the battery at regular intervals 2 4 years depending on use and how much usable capacity you need as its usually not covered by warranty they dont last like they used to.

Most if not all SD card readers in thinkpads are PCI based not USB. As such you can not boot from them. You can install linux on an SD card jus fine but it won't boot in the thinkpad's SD card reader. You put that card in a USB card reader and boots fine as it it was a USB drive . You can bootstrap i.e boot from your SSD so /efi partition etc all go onto your SSD plus drivers to see the sd card reader once kernel is loaded and then start the SD card in the reader. This requires a bit of work.
Get the fastest card you can... MicroSD cards can be very slow. I have done this with a fast USB3 flash drive and it was totally acceptable performance-wise.

Yes it’s possible. I’m just gonna paste it here because i can’t find the link anymore i had this text saved How To Install Ubuntu To A USB Drive Insert the Ubuntu Live CD/DVD switch on the computer and tell it to boot from CD/DVD using your 'BIOS'. It will take a couple of minutes to load and you will be presented with two choices. 'Try Ubuntu' or 'Install Ubuntu' you should select 'Install Ubuntu' You will then be presented with a number of options. You need to select the bottom option 'Something Else'. This will bring you to the partitioning menu. Your Primary hard drive will be listed as 'Sda' followed by any partitions that are on it like Sda1 or Sda2. Below this will be your usb drive it will be listed as 'Sdb'. Click on 'Sdb1' which is the only partition on the drive and select 'change'. You need to select 'use this partition as Ext4 File System' some distributions such as Mint reqiure you to manually select 'format' at this point . Then you need to set the 'mount point' as '/' which is the root file system and click OK. You will be taken back to the previous menu and that partition will have a tick next to it. Now click on 'Sdb' just above that partition this selects it as the device to install to. Now just below is an option for where the bootloader is to be installed. It is VERY IMPORTANT that you CHANGE THIS OPTION. THE BOOTLOADER MUST BE INSTALLED TO YOUR DEVICE listed as '/dev/Sdb'. If you do not do this the bootloader will be installed to your internal drive. You are now ready to install to your external device simply click 'Install'. You will need to answer a few simple questions like 'name' and 'create password' then you can sit back and relax.

I'm assuming by good modern kernel you actually mean a good modern Linux distribution ? With Linux there are so many choices and what distribution you prefer depends on your preference. Ubuntu and it's derivatives are a safe bet but I'd argue Fedora strikes a better balance between bleeding edge software and stability and provides the best Gnome Desktop experience out of the box. Furthermore you get SELinux built in which is one of the few significant security mechanisms available for Linux today. I also generally just prefer Fedora's way of doing things and I find that they generally favor technologies that I prefer also. Of course Arch Linux will always be a great alternative if you want to live on the edge but you will have to live with the occasional breakage which can almost always be easily fixed . x200B In the end though there are so many Linux distro's out there that you really should just experiment and figure out which one appeals to you. Just create a few VM's to play with to get started

Linux user here. For what it's worth you might prefer Mint over Ubuntu at least to start. Only my opinion of course but with its app doc and persistent title bar Ubuntu is more like Mac OS whereas Mint's Cinammon looks more like your traditional Windows interface. But by all means try 'em both!

Not saying that you should it's up to personal preference but if you would like to install Arch Linux my preference check out this YouTube channel for great and easy to follow installation videos. It's really not that difficult and gives you so much freedom and the AUR Arch User Repository with all the software you'll ever need.

Are you doing the recovery from a different laptop and have the ssd/hdd for the x250 in a usb enclosure? If so windows will not recognize the drive. Go to Disk Management and you’ll be able to see the attached drive. From there you can right click the space on the drive and Format or Delete. When you Delete right click again and select New Simple Volume. If you have an installer for Windows you can install it straight to the x250. You’ll get to the portion where it will ask you which drive to install it. You’ll be able to see the drive. Both options will wipe the drive of Linux. If you plan on dual booting you’ll have to do the 2nd step and create partition then you’ll probably have to fix the Grub menu to be able to boot the Linux partition.

If you did a clean install and wiped the windows recovery partition you'll need an install image not a recovery one. The only macOS-compatible WiFi card that will clear the X230 whitelist is the Atheros AR5B95 part number 20002357. This card is available on eBay here for 8.99. Placing the IO80211Family.kext here in the EFI/CLOVER/kexts/Other folder on your EFI partition assuming you're using Clover will enable this card in macOS Mojave or Catalina. This card is WiFi only however the stock Bluetooth daughtercard in the X230 will work fine in macOS. If your X230 doesn't already have Bluetooth you can easily add this daughtercard in the socket located under the palmrest. You would need part number 60Y3303 or 60Y3305. These are normally available on eBay for less than 10.

Either run the Software Update tool from Lenovo Vantage in Windows or use fwupd from Linux. I don't think there's any advantage to choosing one over the other except you might spend a little extra time updating Windows drivers with Vantage if you don't deselect them. sudo fwupdmgr get-devices in Linux will show you the current version of each device's firmware so you can verify that against the known good versions after updating.

So I see some suggestions for AMD powered E L and T series. While these are great general purpose laptops I use my E495 for programming and playing older games on low settings I worry that it may not be quite the specs you are in the market for. For one thing video editing will likely benefit from a dedicated GPU and possibly a more powerful CPU though that may be less necessary . Finding a laptop like that for around 1000 is going to involve some other compromises. It may be worth looking at Notebookcheck's list of budget multimedia laptops for some good examples. For another the AMD models aren't typically given the best displays. A 250 nit 1080p display is just fine for me but you may want something better quality. Third the E495 that I have is pretty upgradeable and serviceable storage ram battery but more and more models are getting the soldered RAM treatement especially the premium T-series . The Thinkpad most directly targeted for multimedia content generation would be the X1 Extreme. They have a more powerful CPU and a dedicated GPU nice displays and are quite serviceable. It's a little more pricey but I've seen the first generation ones selling for around 1500USD here in the states. I don't know how much that would end up being for you across the pond or if you can find a seller with a good warranty but I suggest you check that model out.

I strongly suggest you to wait for AMD-powered L14 and L15. If you need a new laptop ASAP maxxed out E495 and E595 should be within your price range E series are not as sturdily built hence my suggestion to wait for L14 AMD and L15 AMD but they offer the most performance for the buck. Frankly speaking if the intended use for your new laptop is 50 tabs in a browser I strongly recommend you to switch to Firefox video editing and video capture then I think almost any new ThinkPad except 11e series and maybe i3 models will fare fine. Be prepared for suggestions to strongly consider used T series laptops. However if you do intend to buy a new ThinkPad specifically I'd recommend looking at L series - nowadays their quality got very close to T series and they're cheaper.

1 I'm not sure sorry I don't own an X1G2 nor do I have an HDR display 2 3 When the discrete GPU is enabled on a ThinkPad the CPU doesn't enter lower C States . C States are modes in which the CPU enters to reduce power consumption and this can really increase battery life and reduce temps. In my case the CPU with the DGPU on idles at about 1 Watt of power whereas with it disabled it idles at 0.5 Watts. This in my case reduces my battery life from 10 to 5 hours so be warned! I use an E490 with a AMD GPU so while this might not be an issue with the Nvidia card you have I did see the C State issue reported with the X1 Carbon 6th gen which do use Nvidia cards. The C State issue would also cause higher temps as putting more power in the CPU would mean more heat is produced thus explaining the higher temps. The article below goes a little more in depth with other battery saving measures to try and compensate for having the discrete graphics enabled I hope this helps!

That was one of the sellers/items i considered when i upgraded mine to IPS. Reasons I didn’t buy it • found a good deal on IPS screen 45 • that board is meant to be placed behind the LCD panel that’s what the spacers are for . Some reviews said it was causing some flex on the lcd panel. • i ended up getting the board with a longer cable which is meant for it to go under the keyboard 55 . I’ve been using this setup since beginning of this year and no flickering issues. Some reviews said that the shorter cable “might” be the one causing the flickering issue. Not sure if there’s any truth to that. All i know is that i have the longer cable and no flickering issues. Reason to buy sold as a set so it’s sure to work. It’s difficult to find a lcd panel if you end up with a “compatible” panel it might not work with the conversion board.

Unfortunately some Ivy Bridge ThinkPad models don't work well with 2133MHz RAM modules particularly in dual channel mode both modules installed . Another option you might consider is to flash the modified BIOS using 1vyrain This will enable the Advanced menu in the BIOS which will allow you to adjust the RAM speed under Memory Configuration Memory Frequency Limiter as shown here Not sure that will resolve the problem but might be worth a try.

I'm pretty sure thinkpads still have spillproof keyboards? I would still take off the keyboard and clean it/see what it looks like though.

Milk is unfortunately a bad liquid to spill in terms of its potential corrosive effect and obviously...eventual smell. Think of a cup of milk left in the hot sun the next time you power that machine on. How did you spill? Was it directly onto the keyboard or was it a side splash? How much? Obviously the more you spilled the more likely it was to overfill the keyboard tray and get down into the motherboard. If this came in to the desk my first move would be to flip the machine either on to its side or keyboard side down to drain any remaining liquid. I've never had any use for rice. Honestly if there was enough liquid inside to make that effective the internals would be toast. The good news is that the keyboard can be removed without having to disassemble the entire machine. See page 63. If no sensors are shorted in the keyboard the sugars will still crystalize making that spilled on keyboard crunch. You will want to get something with a high alcohol content listed as safe for electronics to try and remove that. I have used for years. I would also recommend at least removing the back cover tonight so you can see if the liquid got through to the underside of the motherboard. If it did you will want to go out an get some high % isopropyl alcohol for cleaning off any residue.
Should be OK. Don't turn it on unless you are sure its dry. I suggest getting one of those keyboard protectors if you are the type that is always eating around your computer.
Call around to local computer repair shops and find one that does ultra Sonic motherboard cleaning.

Higher performance at a given price stronger GPU than integrated Intel graphics also brings competition to the processor market meaning that Intel will finally have to work harder if they want my pick.
Performance. Security. Prize. Typically at least 20% faster. AMD is leading all benchmarks. Intel is a shit show recently.

There’s also the not-so-small small matter of security vulnerabilities this very informative article has Intel CPUs exhibiting 15x more such nifty “gifts” than AMD over the last couple of years. And even if you think you don’t care too much about security the secondary issue with those vulns is that their mitigation will steadily eat at your Intel CPU performance as they get patched often in the OS sometimes in microcode other times it’s been so broken that the advice is to ‘just’ disable SMT hyperthreading As a result your Intel-based machine ages much more quickly as its performance gets impaired. In a world where you could only buy Intel it may have been a perfect ploy to make you upgrade your machine more often. Thankfully there is now extremely capable competition!

the default bios cooling settings are usually bad. use this app to see your temps and manage your fan. it no longer in active development but it still works for most models . hardware maintainenence manual the service manual to order parts thinkpad forums and lenovoforums are your friend. if you want to check your internals

Assuming you are on Windows 10 1. Definitely re-paste first. As others have mentioned this is really easy to do. Don't cheap out on the thermal paste 2. You may use ThrottleStop to undervolt your CPU. I've managed to undervolt mine to -155mV depends on the quality of the CPU die . You may catch several BSODs along the way while fine-tuning your settings. Also pay attention to SpeedShift values basically how aggressively your CPU will go into Turbo Boost you may wish to limit Turbo Boost somewhat at least for one of the profiles . All in all you may get -10C or even better if you limit the aggressive of Turbo Boost . And/or... 3. ... make sure that your BIOS is updated to the latest version and play around with performance slider which is accessible by clicking the battery indicator in the Task Bar. I've noticed that for las 2-3 months noise and heat levels of my X1C6 are significantly bettelower than before even when not using ThrottleStop. Lenovo definitely changed something in how CPU/cooling behaves. 4. Using TP fan application to change your fan speeds is not the ideal solution. Basically you want to have as much performance with as low heat output and fan noise as possible. But TP fan won't let you achieve it. What it can do is lower the temperature by upping the fan speeds which will result in louder operation but lower temperature. Or vice versa - the lower fan speed with less noise but with much hotter case temperatures.

I have X21 X60/1 X200/1/t X230 X240 X260 X270 and the '40-'70 feel much more solid than the earlier machines. I think it's because they're made of less parts overall so there's not as much to rub together. Not sure about the X240 but the X250 X260 have the swipe-style fingerprint reader next to the keyboard. This is a weak point and the plastic of the top case around it frequently breaks. The X270 doesn't have this problem since it uses a whole-print reader which is on the palmrest under the arrow keys. If that's broken on yours it might be causing some of the problems you describe. But I'd start by grabbing a copy of the HMM and opening it up to make sure everything is screwed down tight and nothing is broken.

I've done contracting at a few different bases and we issued 9350's and a few newer models as well which were the 15 models. I was constantly bringing different Thinkpads on base to show my colleges and as people came into the command wing to talk with us they would use my Thinkpads and started liking them eventually ordering them for themselves. When I had issues with my T/X/W/ and P series it was always caused by me.

I went from a 2011 MacBook Air to an XPS 13 9360 to an X230 to an X270. I really liked the XPS form factor but it didn't hold up well after 18 months. The main issues were Awful coil whine. Poor thermals it gets quite hot the fan runs often. Battery lost half its capacity and wasn't great to begin with since I got the 4K screen. Adhesive on the rubber rails on the bottom failed and they came off. Soft touch material collects fingerprints / never looks clean. Stock wifi is awful on Linux and disconnects constantly. I replaced the m.2 card but I believe they started soldering them to the motherboard on later models. If it's the same Broadcom WiFi and you want to run Linux this is a dealkiller. The form factor is really really nice but I won't be buying another one.

Lots of folks love Ubuntu but I prefer Fedora or Mint. Mint is a great choice for someone new and on my X200 X201 X220 and X240 I have had no issues at all with Fedora. Go to the different distro websites check out the GUI and see which one you like is probably the best suggestion I can make.

Mint is a great start. Thinkpads are generally Linux friendly. I have ran Mint on my X250 without any issues.

Head over to distrowatch.com on the right side you can have a look on the Linux distribution sorted by downloads. The top 5 is really good actually. I have tried them all. Personal preference is Debian Light and breezy and Manjaro for the FULL extra stuff

Than there's FerenOS ZorinOS Arch Deepin Clear Linux tons of distros. Download an iso and try a few. Most people start with Mint and go from there. Just enjoy ! Yesterday evening I installed Arch on my X61

I do not think that you have to worry about any compatibility issues between ThinkPads and Linux.

I have an E490 and would consider it a Jack Of All Trades With software modification If you can find one these things have good build quality the 1080p matte display is viewable in sunlight but not very color accurate I use an external monitor so that doesn't really bother me but still . The keyboard is amazing and the trackpoint is good but mine has the synaptics variant so the trackpoint speed is on the slow side. The performance out of the box is good with the intel only model but the Radeon RX550X variant cannot cool the CPU and GPU simultaneously. Some software tweaks can rectify this and can make this a very competent little laptop! Davinci Resolve struggles with 4K .H264 unoptimized footage but I use the free version so that's all on the CPU I don't know how to enable GPU acceleration or whether you can in the free version and I haven't tested other codecs yet like .MOV files which will hopefully yield better results. The battery also hits 10 hours on a charge without the use of the DGPU no more no less. Using the laptop for gaming while on battery will only make it last about 2-3 hours however if any program is using the RX550X at all the battery will instantly go from 10 to 5 hours due to the CPU not entering power saving states although this also seems to be an issue with the X1 Carbon as well . I wouldn't recommend the E14 because the cooling is worse and the cooling on the E490 is bad the software can be tweaked to make up for it though there is no microSD card slot it isn't as upgradeable only one ram slot and a higher price for practically the same laptop. If you get the model without the DGPU I would say maybe get it but because you had a laptop with a DGPU I would say you wouldn't want that one I also can't say you can fix the thermal issues I have managed to do so on the Ex90 laptops but I don't have a E1x laptop to test. If you are happy tinkering to get good performance from the DGPU or just get the IGPU model of the E490 I would say get one but if not then don't. Also here is my guide to fixing the E490/E590

Here’s a list of supported CPUs for T430. I don’t see the CPU that you posted so confirm that with the seller. What you’re generally looking for is the TDP Watts . A dual-core 35W CPU should run fine in a T430 without any modification on the heatsink. Anything above that quad-core and/or 45W then you should get a beefier one. Do you also know if it has a dGPU?

If its done right I see no problem with that. The processor will be a huge update compared to the stock processors the T430 comes with. But it will also run hotter and probably reduce battery time. But if that aren’t the most important things it could be worth it. Also you could try to improve the software a bit to limit power when on battery. Main question will be the price... just look what a comparable T430 and the processor itself wouöd cost.

I don't think the change of processor itself is an issue if you buy old laptop you may want to repaste processor anyway. The issue is heat dissipation quad core processor heats more than dualcore and t430 is not designed for quad core. You still can buy a laptop then buy another dualcore i7 e.g 3540M replace it and sell quadcore i7 on ebay they go for 80-150 depending on the model . You may also want to double check i7 model with seller as I struggle to find 3680qm on intel website.

I had issues with my t430 I had put ivyrain on it and it was seeing critically low battery events in event viewer - I disabled critical battery hibernate when plugged in. Since I'm using some sort of 3rd part battery I don't know what to blame for the signaling issue. The flashing light is the system going to hibernate it goes as long as it takes to store the memory to disk.

This is an issue with Lenovo's battery drivers/Vantage and Windows. I had this happen too always whilst my laptop was plugged in. You need to go into the advanced power options and change the behavior for critical battery while plugged in to 'do nothing'. That fixed my issue and I haven't seen it happen again.

I have a very good experience with thinkpads. Abused them modified my t440p chassis to jerry rig a full size m.2 ssd put a 17 inch screen on my t440s because it fell from a really high table and the screen broke and blew up some fuses put solder in their place only for it to continue working to this day bought a full hd panel later for it . My X230 and X1 Extreme haven't had any issues so far. My old E480 ran a bit warm and I accidentally broke off the screw retention thing on the back two screws. It was also a bit more flexy than I'd like. A T470s I picked out for somebody hasn't run into any issues though there is a dented corner. A T440p I picked out for another guy with i7-4900MQ ran hot and some of the keys were a bit janky. It got stolen because he left it in his car and didn't lock the door. The W540 I picked out as a replacement is the only one that really gave me problems. With the Intel Rapid Storage Technology driver it stutters like crazy. Had to remove that driver. I also had to turn off fast boot to get it to wake up properly from sleep. It'd power on but get a black screen every other time. It still happens on occasion but it's much rarer now.

Yes. I've been using ThinkPads for almost two decades. I had three issues only in all these years The GPU from an R50p I purchased used desoldered from the mainboard because of a defect in this model and excessive heat. The backlight of a T60 died and was replaced by the warranty on-site. The IPS panel of my former X220 has a ghosting issue if you leave the same thing on screen for a while you can see its ghost afterwards All the rest worked and continues to work. My previous working machine is still working at home the X220 and is used carelessly by my 4yo daughter. I had A20m R50p T41 T60 T61 X220 and T480s throughout all years all running at least 10 hours a day the last four travelling in my backpack that used as a foot rest in the plane/bus as travelled. First a heatsink would be designed / held by hardware for specific numbers separation and pressure between semiconductor and heatsink. That must be known long before anyone can answer your question. Second most all heat transfers in direct CPU to heatsink contact when using thermal compound. Compound only fills microscopic air gaps to make them thermally conductive. Thermal compound can be ten or twenty times less conductive higher thermal resistance than what transfers most all heat - direct contact. So why add thermal compound? Only because others ordered you to do so? To increase CPU temperatures. To increase thermal resistance. Ignore any answer that does not discuss how this stuff works and the numbers. Why replace a thermal pad? They do not go bad become less thermally conductive even 20 year later with constant use. Third if even considering thermal paste then always ignore any recommendation that does not discuss relevant specification numbers. A first number that only the informed mention is watts per kelvin-meter. Anyone who does not discuss that first specification number always read datasheets is best ignored. Then discover which highly touted and much more expensive brands are only similar or inferior.

The manual states that you should use 'thermal grease' but the ones i have worked on have this clay like pad on the cpu cooler not as strong as an actual thermal pad but certainly more thickness than you could ever get with paste. Iirc i replaced it with modern 1mm thick modern pad material and worked well enough. Never mix and match pads with paste every transmission form one material to another will add resistance for the heat you want to lose so if anything you could make things worse not to mention that the paste might react with the pad .

Yeah I ordered a Lenovo gaming laptop and a mouse for my son so I could appropriate his ThinkPad. Lenovo put two active pending charges against my credit card for the order one for the total order and another one for just the laptop after they shipped the mouse - not cool. Luckily I caught it and it was only a 1200 laptop. They made out like it was no big deal even though those pending charges affect your available credit. Several weeks later as the shipping date was moving farther and farther out I decided to cancel the original laptop and order one that was in stock. They had removed the pending charge for the original laptop prior to my calling to cancel so It should have been an easy transaction. Lenovo put TWO pending charges for the original laptop against my credit card during my phone call with them cancelling the order. Unbelievable. It took several phone calls and e-mails to get everything resolved. The good news is that my son ended up with a better gaming laptop for similar money. The bad news is that it arrived while we still had the bogus pending charges for the cancelled original laptop on our credit card. Buyer beware.

Most laptop cases are some kind of metal alloy. Which means they are opaque by nature. If you wanted a clear or transparent colored shell you will lose out on the strength of that alloy. However if you really wanted to have one no matter what consequences be damned and all make silicone moldings of your case and mix up some slow cure plastic making sure to use a type that can resist high temps and go nuts. 3D printing can also be an option though you would still need to measure and model every single detail of the case into a 3D modeling program and slicer and then make sure you have as accurate of a print as you can get. After a week or more of work and research you will have what you are looking for.

I've had the same problem as well but was able to find a workaround for windows 10. Upon turning on your laptop you'll see a black screen which prompts you to hit the ThinkVantage key to interrupt normal startup. You'll then want to hit the ThinkVantage key and then F1 to get into the BIOS Setup Utility. You can then head to config and then Alarm Beep. You'll see a option called Keyboard Beep. Disable that and then press F10 to save and exit.

Why would you press so many keys at once? It has to do with the key rollover and the way the keyboards work. It beeps at you to tell you that your presses will not be recognized. While I see no reason this behaviour would be an issue since it will be present on every Computer the comment by the other user will be your solution.

It's a way of configuring multiple disks to act as a single storage volume. The advantages are greater speed and fault tolerance. You can read more about it here I've not used RAID on any of my systems and I probably don't know enough to even realize how much I don't know about RAID.. But my impression is it's mostly used in servers NAS systems and workstations. Only recently last year or so? have I started seeing it crop up in the context of laptops. I'd go out on a limb and say you'd have to have pretty specific needs to make the increased performance worth the extra cost and hassle.. But I'd love to be corrected if I'm wrong about that!

On a laptop I would rather have a robust backup strategy than have to deal with the extra complexity of a array on my machine. I think the real answer here is that if you have to ask if you raid then you probably don't.

DDR4-2666 is a tiny little bit of overkill for L380 as its CPU can only work with RAM at DDR4-2400 speeds maximum. It will work in your laptop it just would perform the same as if it would be a DDR4-2400. If you want absolute best RAM for your laptop I recommend Kingston Hyper X Impact sticks. If you're okay with something that has lower timings any SODIMM RAM at DDR4-2400 clock speeds and higher will do.

Hello from L380 land! A memory upgrade is almost always worthwhile. I'd just stick with DDR4 2400 in whatever brand you choose. Faster won't make a difference on this Thinkpad but more is noticable. Most of the time I use Timetec Hynix. The Crucial is probably compatible but there are usually other choices available for less. I've only ever had one unexpected compatibility issue and it was with Crucial. It was when I was swapping memory around in 2 Thinkpads and a Thinkcentre tiny. I had ordered a set of Crucial for the Thinkcentre only to find out that the model I have becomes unstable if Crucial memory is used. So that set ended up in the T480 instead. The Tiny got the separately bought Samsung stick that matched the original 8 GB stick from the T480.

I suggest you have a look in the NVidia control panel. Maybe there is an option for Vsync. There might also be a similar option in the Intel utility. Have you set the preferred card in the Bios? While idle or low use it may still be possiblt that the Intel GPU does the work. You can check that in Task Manager while watching a Video and seeing which GPU has usage.

Since you asked if there was any support for an eGPU it might be possible using the M.2 slot. It'll be cheaper and faster with 4x PCIe lanes but much more hacky from this example here. It also depends on how the M.2 slot is orientated on the Thinkpad which was perfect on the E495/E595 but I don't know the layout for this generation.
AFAIK EGPUs interface via Thunderbolt and I believe no current AMD model supports Thunderbolt.

So far the games I've seen a big difference with is World of Warcraft and Overwatch Minecraft has also seen an improvement in stability after changing the setting but it wasn't much of a significant improvement.

While I can't say much about the display brightness I can definitely say a brighter display is good during the day but while working at night it may be too bright. An issue I have with my Dell XPS The differences betweent the i5 and i7 are not that big and usually barely noticeable. But since you got this nice discount I would say go with an i7 to make everything just a bit more future proof. But I would stay away from the models with v pro . That is a feature that only few people need. The difference between the generations is also only a small improvement from one to the next but a 10th gen chip will have better performance and battery life in comparison to a 8th or 9th gen chip. One thing to look out for in the 10th gen chips is the integrated graphics. The chips that have a G1 or G7 the G7 being better than the G1 in their name have vastly improved graphics performance in comparison to the chips that have a U at their end. While cache is not as important as it used to be the general rule of thumb is the more the better. In general it is better to have 2 sticks of 8GB for 16GB in total because then the memory can run in a dual channel mode. Giving you better performance. x200B As for any recommendations Because you want a good screen and speakers I would suggest an X1 Extreme or a P1. These are fairly powerful machines with 9th gen chips and have nvidia graphics chips for good performance or light gaming. But these are also fairly light and portable with an okay battery life. On the cheaper side a T15 is also a really good option. If you want to have maximum lightness and protability and don't need a ton of graphics performance I can recommend the X1 Carbon. x200B I hope I was able to give some insight! Enjoy your machine

This is more for linuxquestions but you should install whatever distro you are going to because there isn't anything bootable on the drive after partitioning.

This may happen if your boot flag wasn't set during partitioning. This should happen automagicly when you let the install set everything for you yet sometimes it doesn't. So boot back into your live distro once up open gparted or whatever partioning utility it comes with. Look for manage flags there should be check boxes next to the bootable partitions i.e. /boot/efi. check that box exit and reboot. Should work if not your going to have to re-install if it still doesn't work you have other issues. Advise visiting that distro's forums for further assistance. HTH Regards --mac

Yes if you have set thresholds ofc you should leave the charger plugged in thats the whole point. If you dont youll discharge the battery so youll only end up having to charge it back up later and that in itself will wear the battery down. Half an hour or so before you take the machine on a trip just disable the threshold so you have 100% to use on the road. Normal use like that will be enough to 'discharge the battery every once in a while' no need to artificially force anything like that.
Lenovo has a battery threshold function built into the Lenovo Vantage app for exactly what you are describing. You can get the app from the Microsoft Store.

Some of the more fanatic open source proponents will tell you to avoid Windows at all cost but I use both of them for different use cases on my Thinkpad I'm using Linux because I'm a software engineer and the open source ecosystem fits my needs. On my desktop I use Windows because I also like to do gaming on my free time plus the Windows Subsystem for Linux brings much of the Linux ecosystem to Windows.

People could tell you the differences and benefits of Linux over Windows and the other way around but at the end of the day it is your Thinkpad and if you like Windows and feel comfortable with it then use it. I use Linux and I love it on my Thinkpad but I wouldn't make someone that enjoys using Windows to change it. The good thing is that you have choices and if you are interested you should try it but because you want to not because someone tells you that it is better.

I think it all boils down to the individual user. For me I just require an OS that works out of the box stable and reliable. I’ve been wanting to get an old ThinkPad for a while and came across an out of business company auction with lots of ThinkPads. Initially I wanted an X220 but the prices went above what I was prepared to spend. Instead I went for a X240 and won one of the lots. The listing was a bit of a mess description and pictures not matching so in the week between the auction ended and pickup I was very excited to find out if I had made a good deal or just wasted my money. In the meantime while surfing the local classifieds for spareparts etc. as one do I came across a very reasonably priced X201 that I couldn't resist. 4 GB ram i5 processor battery seems decent and very little wear to the outside. The keyboard is great and I love the look of no trackpad. The day came that I could pick up the X240 and my suspicion towards the listing turned out to be justified. First of all the HDD was 250 GB instead of 320 GB. No big deal It's getting swapped with an SSD anyway. Instead of the pictured 3-cell battery it came with a 6-cell battery. Great! Unfortunately the battery was DOA giving the replace due to normal wear warning in Windows and only maintaining a voltage of about 5v. The internal battery appears to be in decent condition and cosmetically the laptop is fine. All in all a fun experience would probably be more critical towards the listing another time. Next up both are getting new SSDs and I also have a new original battery in the mail for the X240. I plan on running a light linux distro possibly Lubuntu on the X201 and dualboot Windows and maybe Fedora on the X240. Both are also going to get a thorough cleaning and get their CPUs repasted. In the future I might upgrade the RAM on the X201 the X240 is already maxed out at 8 GB. Ideally I would like to get a new battery for the X201 but I don't feel like entering the 3rd party battery lottery and an original battery would cost me several times the price I paid for the laptop. Down the road I might look into upgrading the display and the trackpad on the X240 but for one I'm just going to enjoy spending some time fixing up these fine machines. Honourable mention of my T490s from work in the background which lured me down this rabbit hole.

The mhz doesn't matter so long as it's rated for or above working spec. If it's faster than your system supports it'll run at the supported speed and you can move it to a faster machine that uses DDR3 later but if you go below supported speed then you'll be bottlenecking your system.

The compatibility of fans and heatsinks between different laptop models is very very low because in most cases these are custom parts designed to fit a particular model and its variants. It's not impossible to shoehorn a different fan into a laptop I've done this myself but that usually requires that you already have the parts on hand. If you're only comparing pics of fans and heatsinks online then the chance of success is much much lower.

Fans move air moving air sound. There are some tweaks that make one fan more quiet than others but when staying within the same physical dimensions and performance amount of air moved the differences in noise will be small if any. Now if your current fan is broken mechanical like rattling and scraping sounds then replacing it with a fresh one will at least remove those sounds giving you an overall better experience. Also some brands just make a shittier product than others resulting in more of these noises being produced on the side even on a new sample you can google about the different brands and how users generally experience the sounds they produce. Finding a 'compatible' fan for a laptop will be very tricky there's so little space in modern machines that they pretty much need tailored components.

There are two companies that make special pliers for removing small screws. 1. Vampliers 2. Engineer Haven't used either myself perhaps some OP's can chime in with their results. I have considered purchasing a pair myself b/c its not a matter of if but when . HTH Regards --mac

You probably used a screw bit that is one size too big or small. The metal used in most laptop screws are pretty mild and malleable. Stick black insulation tape on it and try to screw it out again. If that doesn't work apply a small dab of metal epoxy to cover up the hole essentially make it flush with the screw surface . Stick a screw bit in straighten it and let the epoxy fully cure. It should be easy to unscrew it after that. Either way you still need to buy a new screw to install your M2 SSD back.

That looks like a job for locking pliers! Might also want to heat that screw up a little bit first if they were too generous with the locktite you could very well rip everything apart with the force pliers can apply.

The thinkpad rj45 adapter is a direct pin to pin adapter for Ethernet. It retains the internal mac address for networking. This is useful for a corporate environment with many devices all having set ip and Mac addresses so that admins can use mac address access control. Using a thunderbolt adapter is different because instead of matching the Mac address of the computer the Mac address will correspond with the adapter used. This is useful for consumers but would make Mac address access control impossible for corporate environments. Basically all of the people hating on Lenovo for making a proprietary Ethernet port and adapter on their business laptops miss the point that these are for business first and not necessarily for the consumer. Consumers want portability and compatibility business needs industry standard features such as a hardware mac address afforded by this proprietary port and adapter.

Thinkpad dongle is a breakout cable - aka the controller is in the computer it is basically a dumb cable. Thunderbolt is a whole adapter controller and everything rolled into one and will work with any thunderbolt computer.

Regarding tactile feedback - if you're feeling adventurous and have some time for a DIY project you can try swapping your switches to MX clears instead. They are a tad heavier but the tactile bump is very close to what a T25 feels like. If you want to replicate the key travel of a T25 try using two 2 mm thickness o-rings on each keycap. It reduces the key travel quite a bit but still leaves you with a nice tactile bump. As for the TrackPoint's sensitivity that should be configurable with the board's default firmware. IIRC the key combo to adjust this is FN 1 9 . You should be able to get it pretty close to the feel of your favorite ThinkPad with one of those sensitivity levels.

I am running a T480s with a 40AC0135US Lenovo Thunderbolt 3 Dock with two external displays at 1920x1080. I used Fedora 31 previously with this setup and I am now on Fedora 32. Check your BIOS settings to make sure your dock is being authorized and preferably try a desktop environment that has easy Thunderbolt settings. I know Gnome does and I am pretty sure KDE Plasma does out of the box.

Is it physically not possible because of the missing 2 lanes? Screens are not driven by PCIe so should not be affected by the number of lanes. You can even drive a screen if you use no PCIe at all on docks without Thunderbolt. For screens DisplayPort MST is used. Please post the output of this command to see if an MST hub is detected xrandr -q It will show DP1-1 DP1-2 etc. for the different ports of the docking station connected to port DP1 on my X1C5 DP1 is the left port and DP2 the right port. These entries show up if at least one screen is connected.

Not Thunderbolt related I also noticed that the overall compositing on the MacbookPro is WAY smoother and more satisfying than on a T480 The Macbook has an Intel 8259U with an Intel Iris Pro 655 the Thinkpad a i5-8350U with an Intel UHD 620. If I do heavy stuff like watching a youtube video in Firefox or opening a page with a fullscreen canvas the viewport rendering gets noticeabely slow and the mouse cursor feels like its getting rendered at 15-30 fps. On the MacBook everything remains smooth if I do the same workload. I tested both machines with the Manjaro 18 Live Image and my personal dotfiles means an identical configuration on both machines. Could that also be a 4 vs. 2 Lane performance limitation?
Did you try daisy chaining the monitors if possible ? Some will daisy chain through usbc or displayport. I have not tried this in linux as I am waiting for a new monitor.

I've had no issues running dual 1080p from a t480 through a Lenovo USB-C dock gen 1 out-of-the-box. My monitors are 24 1080p with HDMI input. I have DP to HDMI adapter cables for both monitors. The only issues I had was when trying new USB-C cables for length . Check the cable you're using at first I used a 6' USB-C to USB-C cable I had laying around that caused drop-outs when connecting the monitors. Changing that to a 6-foot thunderbolt-3 40gbps cable worked well.

GPU die is right under the left palmrest. Nothing you can do unfortunately. I repasted with good quality stuff and it's still hot as balls. The W541 is a bitch to repaste BTW it literally requires full disassembly of the entire laptop Even if you do repaste it the GPU won't be producing less heat. It'll just be transferring to the heatsink faster. A large portion of heat will still be transferred through the top of the palmrest.
Mine gets uncomfortably warm as well. Repasting helped but it's still not great. Maybe try repasting and see how you like it.
The W541 is an absolute housefire. The heatsink is far too small there's a reason they went with 2 fans on the P50. If you want to play games on a workstation laptop get a Dell M4800.

I don't think repasting would do much in this case as the problem is to do with where the GPU is located instead of at the thermal interface but if you are going to repaste then you might want to add some insulation while you have the W541 disassembled. I suggest layering thin sheets of packing polystyrene underneath the palmrest as well as under the dGPU area of the motherboard. It might be worth it as a stopgap depending on when you get around to selling it off in the USA.

If you change that resister all you do is change what the machine thinks the adapter can deliver. It will always still stay a 65W adapter delivering 3.25amps it will never be able to deliver more than 65W. If you do try to pull more and things go well then the charger will shut off to protect itself if things go bad the charger will burn up.

The maximum power output of a charger depends of the capability of the power supply not from the resistance it's like changing the wheels of a car and spec more power. I don't want to talk down to you but changing the resistance would trick the pc to think it's connected to a higher power output power supply that could overload the power supply in the charger and damage the charger itself or the pc or even blow up

Short answer no. More details ThinkPad OneLink Dock is not a USB dock like other models that came after. It still a pure dock in its philosophy and cabling/wiring. On that dock only USB ports and soundcard goes to the USB BUS linked to 2 separate USB BUS . But Gigabit Ethernet DVI connector DP connector or HDMI connector and power button go directly to the motherboard and its chipsets. I've got a ThinkPad OneLink Dock Pro the one with DVI DP and I've digged a bit about it while hackintoshing a Yoga 12

The two laptops couldn't be more different. The T470p notice the p at the end is a workstation meant for sustained workloads rendering etc . The X280 is an ultra portable with smaller screen and emphasis on battery life and non-sustained loads. Things in common 1. Both have 4 core CPUs 2. Both run linux fine only fingerprint sensors are not supported That's it. What is different 1. T470p has a proper 35W CPU with 4c 8threads that can run at full speed for a long time at a huge expense to battery life so expected to work mostly plugged in or on dock . 2. The x280 has a 15W CPU with 4c 8threads that car run at full speed briefly and then settles to lower clocks to avoid overheating. It is still plenty fast for common use. 3. The T470p has a 14 in screen the x280 only 12 inch. If you've never used a 12 inch before expect everything to be small. Or if large expect to have very little real estate to open more than one window at a time. If the x280 has the 1360x768 screen just walk away or be prepared to upgrade not trivial . The T470p comes with a base FHD screen. 4. The T470p has a 2.5 in bay for it's main drive. This can be a 2.5 SATA SSD or a 2.5 HDD or with an adapter a 2280 NVMe SSD limited to 2x PCI lanes. If the one you buy has either for the former two you will need to also buy an adapter to upgrade to NVMe. 5. The x280 only has a 2280 drive either SATA base model or NVMe SSD. 6. The RAM on the T470p is fully upgradable with 2 slots. 7. The X280 has soldered RAM what you buy is what you're stuck with. 8. The X280 has a USB-C Thunderbolt 3 port. The T470p has none. 9. The T470p has a removable battery. The small one lasts about 2.5 hours the bigger one about 6hours. The X280's battery is not removable and lastas around 8 hours for the same use light browsing . 10. The T470p has probably discrete GPU. Works fine in linux. The X280 only has the iGPU. Do you need the dGPU not unless you plan on doing some 3D or other compute tasks or light gaming but if you plan on gaming don't buy a thinkpad . So see what kind of use case you've got and the decision should be as clear as the huge differences between the two laptops. As for the battery going bad if you keep the charger on the answer is most probably . You can replace the battery of the X280 it's a tiny bit more involving. But you can minimise the effects of constant charging by setting thresholds. I hope this helps. P.S. IF you're buying used make sure there are no BIos passwords as if they are unknown there is no way to reset them.

Let's see... Then I found out that sometimes because of course only sometimes the internal HDD caddy doesn't get seen and I have to reboot it often twice before it sees it again. Well there's no caddy for internal disk - only a bracket. Disk itself is connected directly to motherboard. This issue can be triggered by either motherboard or the disk most likely overheating . I had a problem with T430 in the past that disk was malfunctioning and as the result it was not detected by system. After cleaning the device and replacing the thermal paste issue was no longer present. In your case your disk may be the culprit. Oh and when you install it into the Ultra Dock there's a horrible coil whine. This looks like a disk or caddy problem. I have been using second disk adapter official one for years and I never had such an issue. Oh and if you play games newer than 2005 then it will throttle the GPU heavily after approx 30 sec of playing and you will get 10FPS. Have you changed the thermal paste and cleaned the cooling assembly? Want to replace the WiFi chip? Can't! Because it's whitelisted! There was also a whitelist on your T530. Are all modern laptops incompetent? Aren't there any true workstation ThinkPads that DON'T throttle? I don't need a thin laptop I need a FUNCTIONING laptop! There are devices which do not throttle - such as this one check the graph in Processor section . It's not a workstation but still... Majority of devices are not designed to sustain prolonged boost clocks and after few seconds CPU reduces working frequency. In the past vendors tried to keep maximum boost clocks while now they are trying to keep base clocks. Personally I also have the same issue right now. I am looking to change my T540p to something newer but it is more likely not to be a ThinkPad. I have observed that Quadro cards installed in workstations have a tendency to fail after about three years. Current ThinkPads have only soldered GPUs so if they die and you're out of warranty then you need to buy a new device. You may ask what are the choices then? Actually there are three Get longest possible warranty with your device and try to guess if you would need more powerful GPU in the future as you cannot change it later. Buy a device with Thunderbolt 3 port and no dGPU. For gaming you can buy an eGPU enclosure and desktop grade GPU later. This solution looks nice on paper but life is not so easy... Buy a device with replaceable dGPU. The last option requires a bit more comment. There are mobile workstations with replaceable dGPUs - Dell and HP have them in their current porfolio. In the past Lenovo had some of them too but they started to solder everything starting from 2018 generation - last one with replaceable GPU was P71. Personally I'm looking for either Dell Precision 7530 or 7540 as they are only 15.6 devices with replaceable GPUs. Other options - Dell Precision 7730 7740 and HP ZBook 17 G5 and G6 are 17.3 . 7530 and 7540 have some issues/limitations thought Only 2x TB3 and 2x USB-A ports. 2.5 SATA port is available only as an option - you need to order device with HDD disk as otherwise you won't get it. dGPU uses proprietary connector so you cannot upgrade it outside Dell. You can still install 7540's dGPUs in 7530 but it requires additional steps to get drivers to work. There's a lot of odd configurations on the market with poorest screen no camera or no antennas for LTE module so it's hard to find a decent one. Dell warranty is calculated from production date not bought date. There is no problem to find not used devices with half of original warranty time. I'm still waiting with my decision as Lenovo plans to release T15p which seems to be a successor of T540p which I am currently using . Depending on what they will show I will make my final decision.

Just let the linux installation take care of everything. On the part where it normally tells you where to install linux it will actually detect the windows OS and ask you what to do. Just select Install Linux Alongside Windows and click next. The next screen will ask you how much to partition for linux.
You should check the disk with utility. There could be couple of hidden partitions from existing Windows installation. You can reclaim them.

My experience with installing linux OS's ALWAYS format the drive you want to install on BEFORE installation. So prepare a live OS iso of the linux of your choice on a USB stick put it in the computer then start the computer. When you can access the BIOS do so change the boot order so that the USB stick is first. Hit F10 to save and reboot. Boot the live OS and use GParted included in most distros to format the drive you want to install on. That wipes Windows off it. Proceed to install your linux OS.

In the US the Lenovo website sometimes allows you to build a custom to order Thinkpads and Desktops. They usually offer this option when a new laptop comes out. You do NOT have to use a 3rd party store to do this and are more than likely being charged for the store's time. Just dig into all the options on the Lenovo Thinkpad Model page. Shipping is usually 3-7 weeks as they come from China. Custom Desktops comes from Mexico and take 2-4 weeks. Best of luck!

X240s and newer are fine especially if you want portability - people just like hating on new things and this set of laptops was a different chassis from the X230 and its predecessors which people liked a lot . It didn't help that the X240 which kicked off its series was missing physical trackpad buttons and maxed at 8GB RAM both of which were changed in the X250 and newer . Since your budget is fairly low it's a good idea to go for used/refurb laptops - something like an X200-series ThinkPad or an 820-series Elitebook or a E5200/E7200-series Latitude. All of these are business-style laptops which have an abundance of parts you like projects right? and should be easy to work on. These are all also 12.5 laptops though you could go for the 830 Elitebooks or E5300/E7300 Latitudes if you want something bigger. I also want to mention that since you were satisfied with your i7-7500U I would say any i5 or i7 between around 2013-2017 should be fine for you as well - this means anything from Intel's 4000 to 7000 series. There isn't a huge difference between these since they're all just 2 core 4 thread CPUs with more and more efficiency you could even go older than this but starting from the X240 you do get a fairly big improvement in battery life partly from the efficiency increase. Also every new generation came with a better integrated GPU which may improve day-to-day performance a little so I wouldn't go too far from the 7000 series. That being said pretty much any i5 or i7 is guaranteed to be a marked performance increase from your Core 2 Duo and between 2011-2017 there were no significant improvements in CPU tech - it's only until Intel 8th gen came out when they were actually better i5s and i7s became 4 cores . If you really want a zippy laptop put in a good SSD clean install Windows and don't run startup programs you don't need. SSDs are extremely underrated in performance - they get your boot times down to 20s on a bad computer and 8s on a good one and just make day-to-day usage a lot better for less than what a better CPU would cost. Keep in mind that in a lot of these old ish business laptops RAM and SSDs are really fucking easy to upgrade so try not to worry about those too much. Also get the 1080p screen. At 12.5 a higher resolution will give you nothing but I have the 768p screen on my X240 and it sucks.

Honestly before you upgrade just see what you're actually bottlenecked by - i.e. if you're running out of RAM get more RAM. If you're running out of SSD space get more SSD. If you're running out of battery get more battery. Also when you say SSD Hard Drive do you mean an SSD a hard drive or an SSHD hybrid drive? Cuz if it's not the first one get a real SSD as your first upgrade. Aside from that there's not much you can really upgrade on your laptop that I would say is worth the effort other than maybe replacing thermal paste if your temps are bad. I guess you could also upgrade the WiFi and other small features if you don't already have the best one on it.

I can only speak from my own experience. My X1E1 is coupled with a Thinkpad Thunderbolt 3 Dock Gen 2 135W 40AN0135US . The machine and dock duo is capable of supporting three external monitors which are ThinkVision S24e 23.8-inch LED Backlit LCD monitors 61CAKCR1US in my case. So my configuration is made up with three external monitors plus the laptop screen. The downside of the 3 1 setup is there is an observable lag when running a few memory/CPU intense programs in the background. The lag can be annoying from time to time but an increase in productivity definitely compensates that deficiency. FYI the lag did not dissipate when I reduced to a 2 1 setup with the dock.

What you want is going to dependent on how much performance you want out of your laptop. I haven't had any issues with mine and I'm currently connected to two fhd displays one 144hz over displayport with a usb-c to displayport alternate mode adapter and the other 60hz over hdmi on my coronavirus refugee workstation. If you're going to want to use 'all the things all the time' then external GPU however many monitors you want is the answer you will run out of available bandwidth if you have multiple 5k 16 9 mind you not the dual qhd displays that are 5k or 6k monitors connected however at that point you probably already know this. External GPU's give you an abundance in monitor choice. I've run triple external monitors on mine no eGPU 2x4K 60hz 1xFHD 60hz with and without a Thunderbolt 3 Dock Gen2 135W This is the dock to get actual part number varies by your geographical area . The dock is nice if you want to have less cables sticking out from the laptop directly and you stay within the limits it sets. You should be able to run 3 4K displays with the ports available on the laptop. I would recommend against miracast if you want it to be performing well. If you use wifi while using miracast the performance will be worse it will have to split the time it uses for miracast and wifi. Ethernet is pretty much required for network connectivity this adds the cable you were eliminating with miracast back . As for multiple monitors far as I know you're only able to connect one miracast device at a time.

This is a cool project. I broke my X240 similarly only it was me instead of your cat and the keyboard/trackpad still work and I'm thinking about taking out the display assembly and doing the same thing. I didn't think messing with the structural integrity by making mods to the chassis was worth it - plus I can use it it like a ThinkPad Keyboard but with a full computer inside it. Mounting a desktop cooler would be cool but it would be a lot of effort since you'd have to come up with a structurally sound way to do it. I'd say just repaste to improve thermals. That being said I don't think there's such a thing as a fan whitelist so you should be fine in terms of that and even if you weren't you could always just find a different way to plug a 12V 120mm fan in. I'd also like to mention that an i5-8250U won't be leaps and bounds over an i5-2400 unless he's relying on the i5-2400 iGPU. Because of core configs 4c8t vs 4c4t and the potential thermal differences I think the upgrade would be around the same as swapping his i5 with an i7-3770 and a decent cooler. Finally I guarantee there's a market for your motherboard. The fact that there's no listings could just mean that very few people have that part to sell right now - it's really new after all.

Just slide the ribbon cable in and pin it down with your finger. The little clip does jack shit except pin it down. They break all the time and they never matter except for grip. If it doesn't work anyways it's not the clips fault replace the fan. If it does work pin it down permanently with some hot glue from a glue gun. Easy to install or remove later. Sometimes the clips can be pushed back in but if they don't hold there's no point struggling with it.

Return the battery and/or warranty the machine. Something is fishy. A higher wattage charger will not harm your machine a laptop will only take in the current it needs and/or know it can. A crappy charger however even one of similar wattage most certainly can damage a machine. Genuine lenovo chargers are cheap as chips so thats why i always recommend you get an original one. Also Wh is a capacity it has nothing to do with the power W of your your charger. W V A so your old 45w charger will be able to deliver 2.25A max not 3.25A.

You can get free win 10 upgrades Just download the Latest Media Creation Tool from Microsoft. Pick Windows 10 Pro... Create an Install Usb flash drive... Best Practice is to do a Fresh Install Backup your files first ... Whether you choose to Upgrade your Win7 or do a Clean Install of Win 10 you won't need to buy a new Key... It will Auto Activate your machine with the Digital Key already attached to your system.

My main concern is whether windows 7 pro is any good compared to windows 10 pro my current laptop is running. I found you can buy windows 10 online for pretty cheap I did a quick google shopping search and found windows 10 pro license key for anywhere from 5 to 20 the license key gets you the actual operating system right? and I found a windows 10 pro DVD-rom for 40 maybe I could find it cheaper if I shop around . -- Don't bother with licenses. Thinkpads have a Windows licence embedded in their BIOS so no need to buy one. Download Win 10 directly from Microsoft website and install it During installation process once connected to network WIFI or LAN it will check the embedded licence verify it and attach a digital licence to the motherboard ID so no more licence requested for any further installation of Win10 you can do on this laptop . Just in case Windows installation ask for the licence number you can preemptively read/get the embedded licence number from a Linux Live CD/USB like Ubuntu live try by typing this command in a terminal sudo cat /sys/firmware/acpi/tables/MSDM But usually Windows 10 installation can read licence directly from bios on Thinkpads models xx40 in 2014 and after. source Note I've installed no later than this week Windows 10 on a Thinkpad Yoga S1 for a family member this Thinkpad embed a Win8.1Pro license which is automatically recognized and validated by Win10 installation process .

Personally I would go with the full hd display. The image quality is far far better. As already mentioned you can get a free win 10 upgrade from win 7. Plenty of tutorials arround the web. The disk is not an immediate concern and an easy upgrade in a couple years down the road.

Go with the cheaper one. it has the 1080p screen and a webcam only downgrade is the smaller SSD but I would argue the 256Gb is kinda small too given the price on 480Gb SSD's You can install Windows 10 and it will activate from the Windows 7 licence. it wont care. In fact I have not paid for a Windows licence for years just used the WIndows 7 key on the bottom or the digital licence thats in the BIOS on the 40 series and newer

These are completely different boards that dont really compare well. Just try to make clear for yourself what you are looking for in a board think about portability wireless use typing feel and to some point functionality . I would pick the hhkb any day of the week the main upside that the lenovo board has is that its easier to bring with you in a bag and easier to connect but when im traveling ill just use the board straight on my machine so it will have no added benefit whatsoever. If working on a desk you have space for a decent board and mouse so make use of that and dont cling for dear life to the exact same form-factor thats already on your machine thinkpad boards are great for laptops but they simply dont hold a candle to pretty much any half decent 'proper' keyboard.

I have the original bluetooth version one of that keyboard and also a Realforce 88u TKL with the same topre switches which are used in the HHKB. I love both. The Thinkpad keyboard is small and very light so it is great for portability. But I far prefer the typing experience on a topre switched keyboard. Although some peopl ejust see them as an expensive rubber dome switch the typing experience is so smooth and precise and the 'thok' sound is to die for . So when at home I use the topre. However the HHKB has an unusual layout. It isn't a normal format and isn't even a TKL. Personally I think I would hate that layout. It's too heavy to be really portable and too compromised in layout to match the productivity of a traditional layout. You might want to consider the Realforce R2 newer version than mine which has the same submlime switches but in a regular TKL layout.

Save your money. You are in lust. You have too many ho’s that will take your money in the short-term i.e medical student loan . Finish your degree and get a PhD. Medical field is a war zone. What environment are you using for clinical research?

All those stripped down meme keyboards like those HHKB Pro 2 arent for doing real work. And i am not even talking about the way to high price. They are posting picture of it on instagram etc. TKL like the thinkpad ii is the lowest that would still be okay anyone should go in terms of number of keys. for 100 i would have personally gone for a full sized leopold or FC980R PD if you wanted to get most out of your money.

OMG another MX250 issue here. Yeps MX250 sucks badly in T490 and T590 because Lenovo is incapable of setting up their laptops correctly. Anyway follow my manual here Steps to fix but please follow the manual step by step 1. Downgrade bios to 1.53. This will allow your GPU to throttle at 74 degrees C instead of original 56 degrees C and it will get rid of the random CPU throttling to 0 2Ghz stupid Lenovo . 2. Install Throttlestop undervolt and limit boost to 2 4GHz. This will allow your GPU to take a bigger portion of your thermal budget. 3. Contrary to the manual do not overclock the GPU changing the settings seems to mess things up and it is not worth to go through the pain for few more FPS. Yesterday I spend 6h playing GTA V on my T490 with MX250. 1080p Medium settings with TAA enabled. Only once I overheated the battery so much that it actually throttled 60 degrees and I quickly fixed it by allowing it to breath more air. Ask if you have questions.

Lenovo X1 Extreme thermal throttling solution Undervolt i7 8750H and OC Scan Nvidia 1050ti I took up an X1 Extreme for weeks of testing and configuring. There are two adjustments which make this ultra-book significantly faster and cooler. I do not recommend repasting its just nonsensical. There are only two basic changes with made significant temp decrease and benchmark increase. Note the X1 Extreme's Core i7-8750H is benchmarking in the top 89% of ALL processors. Which means this X1 Extreme I configured runs faster than nearly 90% of all DELL MAC ETC other systems/configurations with this same processor. Here are result steps below. Cinebench R15 score 1178 up from 966 . Lenovo 20MF000BUS - UserBenchmarks Game 39% Desk 108% Work 79% Full Result Intel Core i7-8750H Nvidia GTX 1050-Ti Mobile Max-Q SSD WDC PC SN720 SDAQNTW-512G-1001 512GB RAM Samsung M471A2K43CB1-CTD 1x16GB Quick context - the i7 8750H is incredibly powerful. To access the full power of SIX cores the system must stay cool. Lenovo's cooling system outperforms Dell and HP in testing and significantly outperforms the Mac Book Pro. So its already just about as fast as you can get in a light thin laptop- but its going to get hot when running all that power. The steps below help keep your processor running at full potential - its a safe and sound no chance of harm. The two-step process must be performed in this order Start by turning off Lenovo intelligent cooling and set the button to performance. Also set your power mode to Best Performance. 1 OPEN MSI Afterburner and RUN OC SCAN This is new tech on latest GPUs. This will automatically run and adjust clock speeds while also undervolting your Nvidia GPU to its max stable state. This will greatly reduce GPU temps and improve framerates. It will also allow your CPU to run faster when both GPU and CPU are under load gaming etc because it will not be drawing as much power away and will generate less heat - leading to NO thermal throttling. Your system is smart it protects itself. NOTE This automatic process will not change the memory speed slider you can do that manually after. Slide it up 450Mhz for safe and sound performance. Save this profile and lets move on. 2 OPEN Intel XTU to safely and securely undervolt. A child could do this. First please forget or ignore all the bloat you may have read posted by extreme tuners which overcomplicate. Forget about throttlestop. Some people are trying to change their processor too much - trust me the uber science nerds at Intel thought of all this already with millions in research and development. I doubt you can balance the needs of your processor better... The ONLY reason we can improve performance here is because we know the one thing that Intel did not know when they made the processor. Intel does not know what laptop their processor is going to end up in. It has to work in a Mac Book or a Dell etc. with different specs and cooling. We do know that this processor is incredibly consistent. Meaning they nearly all undervolt the same way. Totally safe Intel's official XTU app gives you the only settings you need to adjust your i7 to your unique system. Configure your X1 Extreme as follows Open the XTU app and simply slide the slider labeled Core Voltage Offset down to -0.150 V You are done. If you like you can add additional performance safely by also moving the turbo boost power max up to 75.000W for both short and max. Your X1 will not allow you to add too much power. Sliding this up is removing any software handicap - the processor will still limit power per intel specs. Your X1 like your car is monitoring itself and has hard limits which can not be changed by a slider bar duh. Make sure you apply changes close and restart. Open the app on restart and confirm values are set. Expect to see large gains in frames games benchmarks and everyday processing. Anything beyond this is splitting hairs. Would like to conclude with a final word on this system. In my research I have seen post complaining about X1 temp and thermal throttling etc. Some folks report that they retuned the system.. imagine the frustration only to find that ALL ultra-books get hot under load. To be clear - you do not need to change anything about this machine - it is a beast out of box and the temps are outstanding for an ultra book. Its never hot unless gaming and when under load you really can not do better without defying the laws of physics. I sometimes wonder if commenters understand that actual electric is running through system and a lot of it. Touch a 15W light after an hour. Here we have 45 W in a chip the size of your thumb. Fire. Hot. Mac Book Pro if you prefer slow and cool - Lastly kindly note that if you want to watch HD movies in bed then you buy an iPad. This is professional machine with serious power - outperforms pretty much any other laptop on market and most desktops. All best!

There's definitely a lot more room for improvement with throttlestop. Sure XTU may be simple but throttlestop will give you better results if you know what to undervolt. You can undervolt your CPU cache and Intel GPU at least -100mV.

Your comment on Intel doesn't know what laptop their processor is going to end up in isn't the reason you can undervolt CPUs. CPU Dies are manufactured in large quantities and will have varying performance. For example the Ryzen 1700x and 1700 are exactly the same circuit and can come from the same batch. Some of the 1700 chips could reach a higher clockspeeds than others in testing and they get branded 1700xs and the ones that cannot get branded 1700s. The reason we can undervolt the 8750h is because Intel has to provide enough power for the lowest denominator in a batch to work at a set frequency. This gives a large room for tuning if you didn't get unlucky in the silicone lottery
Does anyone else get BSODs when trying to run the OC Scanner?

The gains are substantial. CPU is able to run at higher frequencies while Gpu under load and GPU is able to maintain max frequency without throttling down. Plus you get a GPU overlock. Under full load GPU temps hit only 60-61c - down from 76-80c. In terms of a real life example - I found low frames using Just Cause 4 at low settings during test and also universe sandbox slowing down simulation substantially after short time. As expected checked monitors and thermal throttling was clocking everything down. Controlling the heat in an X1 means addressing the two major sources. After GPU AND CPU undervolt I report 60 frames in Just Cause at High settings and Universe sandbox is able to fully tax all 6 cores at 3.9ghz for hours of duration without the simulation slowing down at all. So I would say both on paper and real world these changes together are substantial.

I have a T470 as my daily driver upgraded from a mid-2012 macbook pro. It's about 10% faster in terms of CPU graphics are a lot better I can play SC2 on medium settings at 45fps instead of low at 10fps. I don't do too many intensive things other than compile code which is a bit slow. I would not recommend going for anything less than a T470. I turned off the intelligent cooling option which seemed to speed things up a little at the expense of having the fans on more often. I got mine with 16GB of ram an SSD and a high dpi display video editing uses a lot of ram so I would recommend getting a ram upgrade and using an SSD if your budget can handle it. I'm using the free calibration display settings from notebookcheck and it removed the blue cast I was getting and it looks much more correct . This might be important when video editing as colors are important. However the srgb production in general is pretty poor so you'd be better off doing it on an external monitor if colors are especially important. I never used a T460 so I can't comment on it unfortunately.

I have a T460 my wife has a T470. I think there won't be any difference in speed if you are only considering the cheapest t470 configurations with an i5 CPU. They'll probably have the same CPU 6300u . However T470 has USB-c so I would go with t470 to have a more future proof laptop. Regarding the keyboards the keys on T460 have a longer travel distance. T460's keys almost feel like a desktop whereas the one on T470 is a very good and comfortable laptop keyboard. I think both are beautiful it comes down to what one prefers. I feel like I am faster on T470 probably because the key travel distance. I can add one personal experience regarding the keyboard of T460. I write a lot each day alternating between T460 and different desktop keyboards MS Sculpt Ergonomic Sculpt Comfort and Sculpt Mobile . I think typing on T460's keys is the most enjoyable great feeling and key click sound . However the keys are harder and I get tired faster on T460's keyboard. But that might be only me. So despite my enjoyment of T460's keyboard I would choose T470 if I had to pick between the two today.
