X230's had two screens both were 1366x768. The difference was the type of panel TN for terrible viewing angles/contrast/color and IPS for basically the exact opposite. As for the T480 the stock screen is lackluster in terms of its coverage of the srgb colorspace making it look lifeless. A replacement screen is easy to drop in and there are many choices. If you can find them the low power IPS displays used in the T490 X1C 6/7 series are drop in replacements provided they have the four mounting tabs needed to secure the display to the lid two on the top two on the bottom . Here are your paths to consider If you want the best color but a severe hit to battery life theres some very nice 4k screens out there. If you want better res great color and brightness the 1440p hdr screens are nice. what I have my T480 went from 10 to 8hr max typical iirc. If you want to conserve battery and get the best colocontrast ratio possible a low power screen like the B140han05.7 would be the best choice imo. Screen Suggestions 4k - BOE NV140QUM-N53 16.7m colors 1500 1 contrast ratio 500 nits brightness not sure on install 1440p - JDI LPM140M420 what I have in my T480 and X1Y3 or AUO B140QAN2.0 16.7m colors 1500 1 contrast ratio 500 nits brightness. The JDI Requires WQHD cable brackets and WQHD lid to fit. Swapped all these over works great needed some spacers to keep this slightly smaller screen in place. Good double sided tape would likely have worked as well. Not sure about the AUO screen. 1080p - B140HAN05.7 16.7m colors 1700 1 contrast ratio 400 nits brightness in my X1C7 can confirm nice display Great display cannot confirm if versions are available with the mounting tabs or not. Alternative option B140HAN01.2 or B140HAN 01.3 16.7m colors 800 1 contrast ratio 300 nits brightness. A truly drop in replacement no modding required has mounting tabs better than the N140HCE everyone seems to reccomend as it has a more shades of color think larger crayon box vs smaller Where to get them? Ebay just make sure you have an explicit understanding from the seller that you are getting that exact screen. Return policies are nice as well. Encompass Authorized lenovo parts store needed likely for the lid/brackets/cable. Might be able to source these on ebay but voldermort will likely have hurt the supply lines for this. Expect slow shipping for most of these as they seem to come factory direct from china. my parts took about 30 days to the US incl customs .

Like you said you could always upgrade to SSD later but be prepared that Windows 10 will be slow before you upgrade. I played around with an E490s we bought for one of our employees and was impressed with the overall look and feel. It still won't be a great screen but it looks like a pretty cheap upgrade and will be much better. The X2xx series are small and light not too bad to work on either in my opinion. For example I have an X240 which I fitted with -240GB SSD -Backlit keyboard -X250 Trackpad -8GB RAM -FHD 1920x1080 IPS panel All of those parts were under 40/ 40/ €40 and all add up to a big difference. I then happened across an X260 i5-6300 motherboard and fitted that and it runs much cooler and efficient. I have tried a few Debian/Ubuntu distros and they all run great. Pop! OS seems to have the best battery life for me with the System76 Power Extension probably because its developed with their own range of laptops in mind Overall I would recommend the newest/powerful model CPU combo you can afford while leaving enough money for upgrades. If you use the standard slim 68 24Wh battery then they weigh under three pounds! The only thing I would warn against is the keyboards are a little small and I can see why people feel they are too cramped but its my daily driver now and i am always getting 6-7 hours out of mine with the stock batteries they have the option of an internal battery for hot-swapping the external ones and I usually have a second battery in my bag as well. Best of luck in your search for the right Laptop if you have any questions I am happy to pm.

I would focus on resolution and panel technology so an 14 1080p IPS panel would be on my spec. list I have an older X1 Carbon 4th gen with 16GB of RAM and replaced the standard M.2 with a nice 500GB Samsung one all I need and great machine bought it for €300 330 on our eBay equivalent.

For reliability and portability reasons I'd go with an x230 with i7 16gb/RAM if you can and an SSD. Faster than the x240/x250 and technically faster in lots of respects than the x260 and more reliable than all three.

I'm a comp sci student looking to buy a new laptop and I heard Thinkpads were pretty good. Yea they're pretty good though in the realm of Business Laptops they're not the undisputed king. Latitudes and Elitebooks should also be considered. Which is best comes down to personal preference I find that HPs have more vibrant displays Thinkpads have excellent color accuracy and decent keyboards for a laptop and Latitudes are well balanced. The issue I have right now is that there are so many options for Thinkpads that I feel kind of lost. T460s. It needs to have a good enough battery to last me through the day and it also needs to be sturdy enough to handle my daily abuse I tend to handle my laptops quite roughly T460s. Although you may be coming home with both batteries at 5% battery life is Good not Great . I plan on using this for many years to come and so having it be future proof is a must. Future proofing is a myth. By the time you have the latest CPU you've already been outpaced by another one. Buy used machines every three years you'll be a lot happier. I enjoy being able to rip things apart and tinker with them mostly cause I tend to break them a lot and so it'd be nice if that's possible as well. Good news Thinkpads can be taken apart. Business IT wouldn't have it any other way. Bad news modding eh not the most brilliant idea. It's usually better to leave things stock and just buy something newer or better equipped out of the box or at most swap display A for display B which was also available on your model year. Keyboard/Trackpad mods aren't a terrible idea not great but not terrible but anything more extreme is a no-no-no-no. Since I plan on carrying this around with me daily a lighter option would be nice. T460s. X-series is alright if you're okay with 12.5 screens OR soldered RAM depending on if you take the X1 or X2xx route. I don't know if this makes a difference but I also plan on throwing Linux on the device the minute I get it. Not really. Just get your drivers squared away bad drivers will cause you infinite pain with linux. SUGGESTIONS The market's not super great right now so these prices I give you might be a bit out of date. Welcome to Safer at Home pricing. Less than 200 T450/450s I guess. Cheap but you don't get NVMe or DDR4. From 200-300 T460s. The most underrated T-Series laptop ever. Gets you DDR4 RAM and NVMe on all four PCIe lanes. X260/270 Good if you like 12.5 displays and are alright with having your NVMe drives limited to 2 lanes. From 300-450 T470s Better battery than the T460s thanks to more efficient CPU. Said CPU isn't a major upgrade in any other regard. A485 Good if you need a bit of graphics horsepower on the go for your Minecraft addiction. No PCIe 3.0 x4 for NVMe. From 450-600 T480 The Intel version of the A485. Note you don't get four lanes on NVMe but you get a power efficient quad core making around 30% more power than the A485 and 200% power of the T460s. T480s Same CPUs as the T480 but you get NVMe x4 lanes. WHERE DO YOU BUY? eBay keep an eye out for IT departments tossing machines.

I own both a X270 and T480. If portability is a concern for you then I can say the X270 has a much smaller footprint. If battery life is a concern then the X270 is a much better option than the T490. The X270 is one of the last ThinkPads to offer a dual battery option. The X270 comes with an internal 23Wh battery and you can add up to a 72Wh removable battery for a total of 95 ! Wh while the T490 is stuck with the internal 50Wh battery with no removable option at all. If you want to have long battery life on a T series then I would opt for a T480 instead since it has the dual battery option like the X270.

I thought about a very similar project for the T460p/T470p to make a T480p of sorts. The BIOS would need to be modified with the right ME firmware version as newer versions with security fixes prevent this mod from working. My understanding is that Skylake ThinkPads use Bootguard to prevent a modified BIOS from booting but skyra1n works around that. I noticed these CPUs aren't configured to follow their TDP specifications at all in other notebooks so running them at higher power limits might be necessary for best performance. The anemic heatsink and power delivery of the T460p/T470p was what really killed the project on my end but the P50 should be able to better handle the heat of a hexcore Coffee Lake. I don't know if it is possible for the power stages to be upgraded to make them run cooler like on the T440p so you'll need to check out the VRM when you get your P50. I think this project is remotely viable if you can source working CPUs and have all the supporting mods alongside the BGA CPU replacement.

This is what I generally call A REALLY BAD IDEA . x200B Why? Why do you want to do this over just buying a P52 with an 8750H already inside? What justifies the jerry-rigging involved and a likely unstable laptop at the end of it all? This makes no sense I cannot fathom a single reason to do this. Coffee Lake CPU into a Skylake Motherboard Z370 to Z170.. etc That's an enthusiast-grade motherboard not a custom designed one designed around the power limitations and space constraints of laptops as well as only being on one CPU architecture Skylake. While it's true Skylake and Coffee Lake are fairly similar it's unreasonable to assume they use the same microcode. They don't. At all. What I am interested in and wondering about is if someone like klem would be able to update the BIOS UEFI microcode to accommodate for the additional CPU. 1. Unlikely. 2. If it were possible you'd be left with an unstable laptop. The P-Series is designed for stability from the factory this would undo all of that. The microcode that would be in your BIOS wouldn't be intended for the hardware you have leading to BSODs and other issues. 3. If you need a 8750H in your P50 wouldn't it be better to fabricate a bracket for a P52 Mobo and use that? That's a lot less failure points and simpler too. I would say it's a better idea to fab a mount for a new motherboard and find some smashed P52 or 53 with a thrashed exterior. Or just buy a P52.

Quadro Red Dead 2 That's your problem wrong workload. The T2000 is meant for Solidworks not shooters. They're designed to provide good stability to scenes with high part counts rather than maximum frames for comparatively low part counts. In other words you could play any game you wanted on a T2000 but you'll get better performance from a GPU designed for games like a 1060. Someone else suggested grabbing Nvidia's drivers for the T2000 so do that it will probably help performance somewhat. Cooling is likely not an issue unless you have a bad fan or bad paste.

You may also need tp smapi . Battery thresholds are configured by editing tlp's config file. In the most recent versions it's /etc/tlp.conf . The following are the relevant settings START CHARGE THRESH BAT0 STOP CHARGE THRESH BAT0 There's also another setting that's used for Ultrabay or slice batteries START CHARGE THRESH BAT1 STOP CHARGE THRESH BAT1

On linux you can manage battery thresholds with TLP t420 tested working both with vendor bios and with coreboot . Run sudo tlp-stat in the Battery Features Charge Thresholds and Recalibrate section you will see if you have all necessary modules installed. To set temporary thresholds run tlp setcharge BAT0 start/stop percentage to make them persistent after reboots edit /etc/tlp.conf file.

Yes but the problem is it will be expensive. Go to a lithium ion battery rebuilder and have them rebuild the battery with quality Panasonic 18650 cells. Or you can buy a new battery from Lenovo. When this happens it's best to replace all the cells with new fresh cells when rebuilding.

In my opinion if you don't bash it around and don't spill anything on the keyboard after many years you will find the battery won't hold much of a charge anymore. But that applies to all laptops. As extreme examples I have a 365XD that I bought in 2000 and won't power on any more. I have a 760EL that I bought in 2002 and works fine except the battery. I also have an X61s about 10 years old T420 about 7 years old that work and currently have a 25th anniversary about 2 years old and these all work fine.

For reliability laptops are pretty reliable and will usually last 8 years if you take care of them For replacement it entirely depends on what you're using the laptop for. It also depends on how fast future processors will be. If you're using it for office word processing then you could be looking at a very long time. For example the X230 and the T430 were released in 2012 and can still be used for basic office work and web browsing. Assuming you have upgraded the ram and moved to a SSD drive The T440P was released in late 2013 and will probably still be effective for another 3-4 years at least. The T540P was released at the same time and will probably be effective for 1-2 years longer than the T440P. However from 2012-2017 Intel was focused making CPU's more energy efficient vs increasing the speed. It wasn't until the T480 was released that the CPU's had a big jump in processing power over the previous year's laptops. Now AMD has come out with faster CPU's and this will encourage Intel to come out with faster CPU's. So in the next few years competition may drive CPU's to become noticeably faster than today's current CPU's. So the replacability is not easily predictable because it really depends on whether you want/need a faster CPU. Another example in 2008 Lenovo released the X61. By 2016 the X61 was dated and was not good enough to play some Youtube videos and some 2K or 4K content. In contrast in 2012 the X230 was released and it can still play YouTube 2K and 4K content.

ThinkPads have pretty long lifespans. Currently I'm using a 10-year-old T410 and the only thing that isn't doing good is the battery. Then again T410s plural and not slim of course weren't ever rewarded for having especially good batteries.

If you take care of it like anything else it will last. Don’t drop or spill things on it and you can probably get 8-10 years out of it stretching it? It’s totally worth it if you get an upgradeable model. My Thinkpad T61 that I bought brand new is in a sorry state but it was my consulting laptop and was thrown onto xray belts and in and out of shoulder bags for about 5 years before I replaced it. My T61p was my stay at home model and it’s pristine. I’ve since upgraded to SSDs and more RAM and changes the Operating Systems of course.

I use an 8 X230 Tablet and 9 X220 year old Thinkpad on a regular basis. There's some things that have changed with Thinkpads that might hit somebody that owns a new Thinkpad less than me and my older beaters Batteries- No longer easy peasy to replace have to open the case so I guess perhaps just easy ...ish...depending on one's savvy with computers . RAM- not all modern ThinkPads offer user replaceable SODIMMS anymore - the RAM can be soldered to the board Lenovo does make it transparent which models have soldered RAM or not. HDs- similar issue as the RAM but tends to only hit the lower end models and not X or T. And there are just some machines Lenovo occasionally drops the ball on looking at you my X1 Tablet which sometimes takes months to become apparent but is super annoying to see a bunch of users report failure issues/are sending their machines to the depot to be fixed. But that happens with other companies and 'new/founding adopters' so not a Lenovo exclusive issue.

USB-C power banks are for computers that can be powered from a USB-C or Thunderbolt port. You have to do your research before purchasing your computer. The Acer A515-51G series requires a 45w-65w power supply. You can always extend your battery power by changing your power settings to Balanced or Battery Saver. For normal workloads you can expect about 5 hours of power while in Balance power mode. Any sort of gaming or processor intensive applications will reduce that time significantly. Consider the weight size of the power bank. I look for something under 3 pounds that will fit in the laptop bag. Don't expect a power bank to provide a laptop with a full day of power. It is useful for squeezing out an hour or two when you really need to get work done. For traveling with other devices it is a fair reserve power source. You have to shop carefully because not all the models have a 100w port. These links are not recommendations. They are intended to give you an idea of what is available and what features to consider. You have to look carefully at the specs for portable power banks because they are mostly underpowered designed for smaller devices like phones tablets. P.S. Forget anything that has a solar panel or claims it can power your devices from a solar panel. Most portable solar panels only have an output of 10w in EXTREME DIRECT SUNLIGHT. You then lose some of the power in the conversion which can be a 40% loss in most cheaply made devices. Those devices won't even charge an attached power bank in less than 40 hours of direct sunlight.

I'd boot into a Linux LiveUSB like Lubuntu and try running some nvme format and blkdiscard commands on it. If the drive is really dead it'd either not show up at all or those commands would fail in interesting ways. This is the one-liner I use when I prep my NVMe drive for a fresh OS install boot into Ubuntu LiveUSB open Terminal and copy/paste sudo apt install 'nvme-cli' -y sync sudo blkdiscard --verbose '/dev/nvme0n1' sudo nvme format '/dev/nvme0n1' --reset --ses '1' --pil '0' --pi '0' --ms '0' sync

Undervolt numbers are different for different CPU GPU chips. Some does well beyond -80mV offset. But some will crash. You will have to try little by little and apply some CPU GPU stress testing to find out if it's stable for longer periods. Use Intel Extreme Tuning Utility for CPU MSI Afterburner for GPU Voltage - Frequency curve adjustment is really good in that software . Remember Little steps. Like -5mV Stress Check temps for 30 mins If it didn't crash -5mV more and so on. I was able to get -80mV on an i5 and 900mV and 1900MHz on GPU. So my CPU was limited but GPU is efficient. But may not be the case for every silicon. So don't try without testing for stability. OEMs set the Voltage that is stable for All chips. Some may do good some may do bad. That's why for Low end laptops they won't Undervolt. Though Laptops like Alienware and Razor Undervolt pretty good out of the box.

While both units have quad-core processors M.2 PCIe and 2.5 SATA ports. The Aspire 5 is the more advanced computer. It is also thinner and better designed. It also has upgradeable BlueTooth/WiFi in a M.2 port. Aspire 5 A515-54-51DJ As with any contemporary laptop expect half the advertised battery life with normal use Power setting set to High Performance. For the price it has a very decent 1080p IPS screen. It has a Gen 1 USB-C port that cannot be used to charge the laptop. A lot of people complain because they think USB-C means do anything a MacBook can do with Thunderbolt . Power Off Charging means you can plug-in your cell phone to charge on that ONE marked USB port when the laptop is turned off. I use it to charge my phone or Kindle while in my backpack. This unit has 4GB RAM soldered on the board with 1 available RAM slot. You can install a 16GB stick of RAM. The M.2 NVMe SSD can be upgraded to a much better SSD. Your best option is a 1TB since the larger SSD has vastly improved performance. I'm a fan of the ADATA XPG SX8200 Pro. It is near the performance of the Samsung NVMe at a much more affordable price. You can add additional storage by installing a 2.5 HDD or SSD drive. Aspire 3 A315-41-R14K The Aspire 3 has one RAM slot for a 16GB stick of RAM. The M.2 port is hidden under the mainboard and involves a LOT of extra disassembly work to install the M.2 SSD. P.S. Google did NOT give you a comparison of the processors you read that off a random website. Be careful of where you grab your research details.

I understand your thought process its definitely with merits where you are coming from. We've all been there if using computers for long enough. Its doable if you really want to but.. A common 2.5hdd in a laptop taking bumps and other things will actually be just as prone to failing been seeing it from a guy working with data recovery. A fucked up hdd is just as hit-or-miss to recover from. SSDs without encryption like a phone or using bitlocker or similar a pro would know whats up in the event should it crap out on you with important files on it We're not migrating hdds around as much as we used to. I still own harddrives from 2005 that runs to this day but modern hardware is in a much more expendable state and the laptop probably wont even last long enough for the ssd to hit the writing-wall and you're not gonna be able to migrate the hdd if you swap it out anyway since uefi guid partitions from windows 10 and so forth without extensive adminstrative IT experience. Installing the hdd as a second drive and saving everything you deem needs to be recoverable is a better solution objectively speaking. If you modify your thought process just a smidgen you can have your peace of mind and sanity saved much easier than what you will gain from the hassle of cloning the drive

They are setup as RAID0. So get a windows install usb ready. Go in the bios and change the drive interface and shutdown. Pull the ssd. Boot the usb and install windows. And no you don't always know that a hdd is going out. they have electronics on them too and sometimes they just die without any warning. You are living in an old age. But have fun. Trying to troubleshoot WiFi issues can be exhausting in public forums Reddit subs. We rarely get the details we need when we ask and the users don't always share the needless tinkering they have done. How is the current WiFi configured? Have you adjusted the card settings to match the available WiFi connection? Many people think the default settings are suppose to magically work in any environment. If the card is enabled for a/b/g/n/ac it is loading a lot of capability it doesn't need to connect to your local WiFi. Many times the card power setting is set too low or to power save mode. Assuming that you have both Intel Graphics and Nvidia GPU drivers installed from their website and the appropriate control panels GUI installed from Windows App Store. Dota is NOT LIGHT. Plug in your laptop make sure the fans can suck the air and push it out without anything in the way. Configure Nitro sense for fan speed. Put your Windows in High Performance mode. Okay listen i want you to try something Though this thing will require another monitor or tv supporting hdmi i am sure you may have it I know this may sound somewhat awkward but this may lead us to the cause 1st step go to Nvidia control panel And select manage 3d settings on left side Now on global settings select restore on bottom right this should reset anything to default values now select preferred graphics processor as Nvidia and hit apply don't click on restore again now now go to control panel and disable fast startup in power options now shutdown the laptop better yet hard shutdown it by holding power button now keep your laptop plugged in dont run it on battery power 2nd step startup the laptop immediately connect a 2nd display via hdmi only now click on the notification icon on bottom right in Taskbar click on the project icon and select second screen only if you don't see the project button then click on expand Now this thing will force the laptop to use the discrete graphics card entirely for everything Now download and run intel processor diagnostic tool Now use the laptop normally and check if it freezes again and report back. also post a video of the laptop connected to external display showing line just like you posted before This thing may take some time but it will lead us to component which is failing. Try this report back friend

Also now do one more little thing download and install intel xtu also keep your laptop connected to second screen while doing this now open xtu then on the left panel click on all controls and then click on graphics in the left panel now set the processor graphics voltage offset to 0.050 yes you read it right don't undervolt it but instead overvolt it now disconnect your laptop from 2nd display and keep using it as usual and definitely run a game or play video or do something for 1 hr at least and see if it crashes and shows the green lines again and report back to me also if ur pc restarts in the middle then do check in xtu if the overvolt is applied or not if u change the processor graphics voltage offset then the processor graphics media voltage will change automatically too so don't worry about it and don't touch any other settings in xtu and report back how your laptop performs now friend .

Never listen to any advice that tells you to force the laptop to always use the discrete GPU. You don't have the cooling capability of a desktop computer. You'll end up with overheating issues and all sorts of problems you won't be able to track down. Keep your NVIDIA and Intel drivers and software updated. Let the system automatically switch between video cards when it detects a need for higher performance. You don't need the discrete video card in full use all the time on a laptop. Notice I said update the drivers AND SOFTWARE. Don't just grab the video drivers and forget about the gpu management software. Check for a system BIOS update from the official support page for your computer. Once the simple updates are all done force a Windows update to make sure the rest of your system drivers are up-do-date. When you are all done don't forget to make a disk image backup for safekeeping.

Since the guy working on your computer did a half-assed job I seriously doubt you can fix the partitions on your own or with any third party advice. He deleted the recovery tools. If the disks you have are the full package of the Acer recovery then you could spend the time doing the process all over again. However this time around you need to avoid interrupting the process or overriding the automated settings. You'll need to select the delete everything option to get the original partitions recreated. This will wipe the entire drive and delete all the partitions. Then the recovery tools will recreate the proper partitions and restore the original Windows 7 and Acer software. After the mfg restore is finished I'd make a disk image of the entire drive for safekeeping. Then I'd run the free Windows 10 upgrade update all the Windows patches and then make another disk image so you won't have to spend hours doing this all over again if you swap hard drives or have a serious software problem in the future. Whatever you do keep those Windows 7 recovery disks in a secure place since you won't be able to create them again.

Don't even think about trying to repaste your computer when you lack the expertise to do it properly with a high-quality thermal paste or carbon pad. The risk is too high for potentially causing more damage during disassembly of the computer. The most common heat problem is from tinkering with the settings in an attempt to overclock the system without enough knowledge about computers in general. If anyone has been adjusting the performance settings reset everything to defaults. The second most common tends to be related to tinkering with the video card settings to force the NVIDIA card to always act as primary. This has the high-end GPU working harder all the time instead of the moments when it is really needed. Let the Intel onboard GPU handle the mundane tasks and keep the power draw heat to a minimum. The third most common issue is the CPU voltage running as if the computer is needed for high-end tasks. Modest undervolting has been extremely successful for a large number of reddit members. Other heat related issues have been simple things like not setting the laptop on a firm surface i.e. not nestled snuggly in a blanket on your bed or sofa or other items blocking the air vents.

Don't block the vents. Put it on a desk instead of your lap or bedding. Turn the fans up to max Don't change the video settings to always use the discrete video card. Laptops don't have the cooling capacity of a desktop case. The onboard video is designed to handle the smaller normal tasks. The discrete video only activates during high performance demands like some game aspects. There is ZERO benefit to modifying the video settings to force the discrete video to be the primary video.

Hey you gotta chill yourself first. Everyone stumbles on obstacles and giving up is not the answer. 1 Firstly the most important of all and I cannot stress this enough did you verify the ISO according to its checksum? Its GPG key? You can search articles on how to do this. 2 Have you first updated the BIOS to the latest version? Note when updating BIOS update it incrementally. Starting from the version number directly after the version in your BIOS then repeat until you reach the latest version. 3 Have you tried other linux distros? Ubuntu Linux Mint Manjaro Solus are great distros for newcomers. Note if your CPU and GPU is relatively new try distos that offer newer Linux kernels those that offer 5.x series kernels. You can look at the distro's changelog for more info. 4 Maybe the flash drive or the USB writing tool is the problem. Note Grab another spare flash drive preferably 4GB or more and flash the ISO using Rufus or Etcher. I like to flash using Etcher as it validates the files in the flash drive after flashing. OR Try the original drive in another computer this will tell you what the problem is either the computer or the flash drive. 5 If all else fails you can file a bug report to the distro dev tracker. They can most likely help you. Or post your problem in linux and the elementary os subreddit or similar subreddits.

First that Sandisk is kinda junky for a supposed data center grade SSD. For those of us who manage data centers seeing that tag on a drive tells us it won't be great for performance but it'll probably be the last drive in the rack that might fail. I wouldn't expect much performance from a 6th gen i3 dual-core processor. Since you didn't specify which model you have in that series. you might be lucky and have an M.2 NVMe port that will significantly improve performance over any SATA SSD. A few models in that series also take a max of 32GB RAM so you have an upgrade path that might be wasted on an i3 processor. I'm not advocating straining your budget I'm just making sure you are aware of the advantages and limits of that computer. You didn't mention if you cloned the original drive or ran a clean install of Windows on that SSD. If you ran a clean install you have some cleanup to do. You'll need to disable some of the Win10 resource chokes in the background. i.e. Privacy settings Microsoft account sync settings Cortana settings Game Bar Game DVR settings etc. Keep in mind that your total RAM will run at the speed of the slowest RAM you have installed. While different sized RAM will work in those slots you may end up with unexpected performance loss. DDR works best when it is balanced. The same number of chips same speed and latency. This is the real reason for the recommendation of matched sets of RAM. You did something we are all guilty of occasionally doing you had a spare stick of RAM stuck it in the empty slot. The performance dropped because the RAM controller is working harder to balance the different amount of RAM in each slot in addition to constantly adjusting for the differences in speed and latency.
Backup. Really.

Asking for a general opinion for a company that sells hundreds of different models will never return comments related to your needs. Each computer owner has different expectations and computing needs. Any major brand that sells millions of computers will receive praise and insults. I specifically like the Aspire line because of the upgrade potential. They all have a M.2 NVME port for a very fast SSD. Most models also have a 2.5 HDD bay for a second SSD. I prefer the ones with a max of 32GB RAM for the work I do. With easily upgradeable RAM storage a lower cost model can be upgraded to a great computer. You do have to be careful to select one with a FHD IPS 1080p display. I personally don't like the new keyboards for the Aspire 3/5/7 models. The quiet backlit ones I've encountered flex too much and the keys are oddly spaced. The models with a number pad have an awkwardly arranged keypad. They've completely ignored the 10-key standard layout to save space.

Normally I would tell you to simply use the pre-installed Acer Care Center software to check for updated drivers and Acer software. Then go to the official Acer support page for your computer. Check to see if any of the drivers are newer than what you have installed. If you don't see a newer driver it may not exist yet. Many of the drivers in Acer computers are synced with Windows updates to simplify the update process. The exceptions are usually the Intel Nvidia and AMD drivers/software utilities. If you are having a specific problem you should also check the Acer support page for a BIOS update. One easy method to see if a newer driver exists is to open Windows device manager expand each of the device sections and then right-click on each device to select Update Driver then Search Automatically for updated driver software . I do this once every few months so that I get individual downloads instead of a big stack of downloads all at once with Windows Update. x200B If you gives us more details about the problem you are experiencing we might be able to offer more specific suggestions.

You should start asking questions in the QubeOS forums where people have experimented with different hardware. The VT setting would be in the BIOS or UEFI options in computers with Intel i3 i5 i7 processors. For AMD processors the AMD-V option is also in the BIOS. You won't know if the BIOS is updated or the option is available until you get your hands on the computer. The majority of computers require boot intervention to force booting from USB. Some will autodetect a removable boot device but its an extremely minor issue to tap a key. If you are concerned enough to ask about booting you may not be ready for a non-Windows operating system. I'd also have to question your decision to try virtualization with a dual-core i3 processor. That 4GB RAM soldered to the motherboard may not be enough. I am confident you can stick a 16GB stick of RAM in the one slot rather than the 8GB suggested by Acer.

I'd try a Linux LiveUSB I believe that NVIDIA GPU should be supported well enough by the open-source graphics driver you may have to manually re-clock to the high-performance 3D clock though . Try running this under a Terminal window DRI PRIME 1 glxinfo grep renderer It should say something NVIDIA-related. From there run this wget -O '/tmp/GpuTest Linux x64.zip' ' unzip '/tmp/GpuTest Linux x64.zip' -d '/tmp' cd '/tmp/GpuTest Linux x64 ' DRI PRIME 1 ./GpuTest /test 'fur' /width '1280' /height '720' Which should run a stress test on the NVIDIA GPU. If it works then the GPU is likely fine and it's just Windows being odd.

Generally the entire E5-575 line in a distribution region has the exact same base components with different video hard drive RAM configurations. That means computers shipped to different countries can have different specs component manufacturers while using the same model series. If you don't mind paying a little more while getting a guaranteed Acer compatible part you can request a part quote by filling out the contact form at Make sure you include your SNID on the form. They are an official Acer parts supplier. You can also try the techsupport sub to see if someone will post a picture of their battery with the part number.

These instructions are from the Acer website for a different model. The steps have been modified to avoid confusion about downloading files for the wrong model. Download the BIOS update. Extract the contents. Extract the Windows executable its a zip archive to a flash drive. Start with the Acer powered completely off. Plug the Flash drive into the Acer Hold the Fn Esc keys down while you press the power button. The system will boot into the BIOS update utility. Use the file explorer to find the extracted files on the flash drive. Follow the instructions on the screen.

While you can try a battery reset the laptop might need the extra power for whatever you are doing will draw from the battery as needed. Battery issues are tricky to diagnose. It could be a BIOS issue system driver or software interference or one of Microsoft's known bugs that affect battery drain like the ACPI Controller. Start with the simple stuff check the official Acer support page for your computer verify you have the latest driver BIOS updates. Then force a Windows update check the Windows update status to make sure you don't have an update waiting to download or install. Some updates are too large or invasive to run automatically and will need approval.

This pad is called thermal conductive pad. You can search for it at any local electronics store or even on amazon. You should replace it because if there will be no pad part of your CPU called PCH will not be cooling and by this can be damaged.

Its actually not a big deal but if you want peace of mind replace the thermal pad and stick it back on the component it was protecting. The consumer versions of this will be in the form of larger sheets and can be cut to size and shape. They have a glue and is similar to using double sided tape.

You can check this topic about undervolt profiles. I am using the last one.

I. Set speed shift EPP to 0 on the main TP window II. Then go to FIVR A SET TURBO RATIO LIMITS 1-6 to 34 each. B Then set the offset voltage to - 145.5 or - 140 that'd be safe I guess 150 works out for me C Then go to CPU cache on the same page and set the same offset voltage Now on the bottom right hand side select OK-SAVE VOLTAGES IMMEDIATELY III. Now go to TPL A In the turbo boost power limits boxes ENTER - 24 in 1st and 2nd box and 3rd should be 28 B Below this you'll find miscellaneous. In the Max box enter 34 and press apply and ok. Save and minimize TP. Also don't forget to add it in task scheduler to autostart on logon. Now run any game and do let me know how this works out for you. Play some CPU intensive game like GTA or Warzone.

The Acer Aspire 3/5/7 line all have PCIe M.2 NVMe ports and 2.5 SATA ports. Since your laptop is from the Brazil distribution region you'll have to verify what storage came with the computer. The U.S. datasheets are not always accurate for models released in other regions. While I strongly recommend a 1TB M.2 SSD as your boot drive you have to decide based on your budget. The 1TB SSD will always have better performance than the smaller drives. If you are going with a 512GB SSD it will be a good economical and mid-range performance choice. Many times there are problems when trying to clone from a larger HDD to a smaller SSD. Especially when the target is a M.2 SSD. You might be better off creating the Acer recovery media so you can install a clean version of Windows to the M.2 SSD. By using the Acer media you'll have all the drivers and Acer pre-installed software. Make sure you disconnect the HDD before you start the install process on the M.2 SSD. Windows will occasionally attempt to use the second drive for storing some temp files and the installer has been known to wipe additional storage media.

You need to be extremely careful about just plugging in an A/C adapter that seems to fit . The wrong voltage lower or higher can destroy the device and start a fire. Acer adapter Output 19v 3.42a with a 5.5mm DC connector. Toshiba charger Output 19V 4.74A with a 5.5mm DC connector Since the voltage and barrel connector are a good match you have the option to look for a replacement adapter for the Toshiba since it can be used for the monitor. Try the Acer store accessory finder to see if you can get the correct model/part number. That will make it easier to search for adapters on the Best Buy website. I do see some aftermarket adapters on Amazon for 10- 15. Best Buy does have some universal chargers with different DC barrel connectors. They also carry the DENAQ line of aftermarket adapters that MIGHT have the correct size DC connector. If you can walk into one of the stores just ask a sales rep and keep a picture of the end of the DC connector on your phone.

Do anyone know a way to restore it after a Windows clean instal Sure you make sure you create the Acer MFG recovery media before you do anything to your computer. ok If you are recording your desktop then you need to match your main gpu which is used to display the desktop in your case it would be the Intel one with the gpu that is used by obs itself and this can be done like follows - open the Nvidia control panel and go to manage 3d settings -got to the program tap and search for the obs studio in the select a program if it's not there then you need to browse it and then add it -and then change the preferred GPU to integrated gpu and hit apply -now OBS should work perfectly -note that if you want to record a game that uses the external GPU in full screen you need to change the preferred gpu to Nvidia's gpu if your game is running on nvidia's gpu. I hope that helps you One last thing after I updated to the latest windows 10 1909 version I had this black screen problem and the above solution didn't work for me if that applies to you too then you need to do as follow go to windows settings and then go to system settings the go to display settings then go all the way down and select graphics settings then in choose an app to set a preference select obs and choose power saving mode to force it to work on the integrated GPU

How do I upgrade my HDD eithout losing warranty? Are you in the US? You can't legally lose your warranty by opening the laptop unless you actually cause provable damage by doing so. Simply opening the laptop or any electronic including game consoles and breaking any void if broken stickers or other indicators can't void the warranty regardless of what the manufacturer says. With that out of the way though all the Acer laptops I've had so far have a small doosection on the bottom that allows you to add/replace HDDs easily without having to open the entire laptop. I don't imagine there's too many things that could go wrong with putting the HDD into the laptop. You can definitely find many videos of other people doing this with other laptops for a general idea on the process. For someone new to this I imagine it would take about 5-15 minutes with being careful. Anyone experienced could likely do it in less than 5 minutes. Typically with a standard 2.5 HDD or even SSD it involves 1. Removing a screw 2. Lifting the panel off the laptop 3. Removing the HDD caddy if it's in the laptop still typically involves removing 4 screws 4. Put the HDD into the caddy typically via 4 separate screws 5. Carefully connect the HDD while in the caddy to the SATA/connection cable the hardest part but easy if you're careful and take your time 6. Reverse steps 1-3 put back the 4 caddy screws put the panel back put the screw back 7. Power on the laptop and do whatever with the HDD As to why they didn't include the HDD in the laptop to begin with no idea. In my case I would have preferred the HDD to be outside the laptop since I don't plan on using it at all and it would have saved me the effort of taking it out lol

You would never want to turn off the fans. The people who complain about the noise have the fans turned up to max speed and have overclocked the system which generates a lot of heat.
For everyday tasks the fans aren't loud. I don't play AAA games on mine just WoW Skyrim ESO my fans haven't kicked into MAX yet. Now saying this I've only had the laptop for about 5 days now.

On a Helios 300 the fans start running I believe when the CPU is at at least 45C. If the CPU temp is below that the fans don't run. Locking the CPU to a lower maximum frequency should in-theory be able to prevent it from being able to run that hot in normal ambient temperatures. I believe Windows power management has a way to limit the max frequency. In Linux you can force the governor to powersave.

The fans are quite noisy if you press the turbo button however that's not necessary. I got mine to run quite quietly by using throttle stop to further undervolt to -0.145 and using a thermaltake cooling pad off amazon. At full load my CPU and GPU never even hit 70C and the fans are very reasonable.

The fans arent loud. Why would you want to run the fans at full speed when you are at college anyway? When there isn't anything heavy lifting the GPU or CPU needs to do the fans are not loud. People complaining about the noise are either 1. coming from a mac book or other quiet laptop or 2. complaining about the noise when it is overclocked and/or in max fan speed.

First always refer to the manufacturer's support page for your computer. Retail stores publish incomplete info for marketing purposes. It doesn't matter if it is HDD or SSD. The SATA connector is the same. That is the whole point of the 2.5 SSD design to easily replace existing drives. You do need to look at the dimensions that laptop has room for a 7mm drive. You can install a second M.2 drive a 2.5 drive or both. Make sure you install any available BIOS updates first. This is also a good time for you to stop reading Reddit and create the system recovery media for your computer.
At quick glance if it really is dual m.2 1 HDD slot then you could have 3 SSDs 2 M.2 ones and one 2.5 SSD . I did this on an older Predator laptop and even did RAID0 with the drives fun times p

You can clone the existing HDD to a larger SSD to replace the HDD. Meanwhile you can run Disk Cleanup to free up space on your current drive. You can also empty the Recycle Bin and then adjust the Recycle Bin settings to reduce the amount of reserved space for deleted files. x200B EDIT disk cleanup
I didn't look at the specs for your laptop but if it's using a typical 2.5 SATA HDD currently you can easily replace it with a 2.5 SATA SSD no problem.

My personal preference is to use the larger drive as the boot drive. People tend to forget that Windows copies a lot of additional files to the boot drive when installing software. Plus not only is the 1TB much faster than the 256GB you won't have to keep deleting files to clear space as often. Macrium Reflect Free does a very nice job of cloning and it has a tool to fix boot problems when you are done. In this case a clean install of Windows is not necessary because the source drive is M.2. The simple way is to clone the 256GB drive to the 1TB. The fans making a whirring sound could be the result of dust in the fan bearings. Predator Sense if it is still installed will show you the fan speeds. Fans bearings cannot be cleaned when they start making a growling or excessive whirring noise its time to replace them. I've cleaned out replaced a lot of fans heat pipes. They will suck in everything from dust Cheetos pet fur and the occasional mass of girlfriend's hair. Slower fans don't move as much air which results in higher than normal temperatures. Based on what you've posted about what others have said you've been reading a lot of useless comments. You do want to keep your computer operating system drivers updated to fix performance software bugs security. Since cooler pads don't block the intake or exhaust they can't possibly damage the fans. Make sure you don't obstruct the vents around your laptop. If your ambient room temperature is warm the fans won't be cooling the computer as well as a moderately cool room. There are discussions about the Helios cooling system not earning the praise for its highly marketed improved cooling . Many have tried replacing fans cleaning repasting and undervolting to reduce performance and the associated heat.

I own a 2016 Acer predator so i can't answer the 1st question but since 2 and 3 are general i will help you avoid some of the mistakes I made. 2. Check and monitor your temps. After about a year of usage suddenly my FPS for gaming tanked. I used Speccy and realised the motherboard was overheating. I opened up the laptop chassis and found that one of the fan connectors for the mobo was loose. Then the same thing happened but for the CPU and GPU. I changed the horrible gunk Acer calls thermal paste and voila-temperatures in high 60's to low 70's with a gaming load. My only regret is I over-tightened the screws and stripped some of them. Also clean the exhaust fans from time to time to avoid build up of dust which will increase your temperatures. Get a good waterproof backpack to carry it with extra padding. If you use it for work and home gaming invest in an extra power adapter don't need it to be the original one . That way all you have to do is plug it in and won't risk damaging the power adapter like I did. Plus its a real hassle to cable manage and carry the extra brick and cord. 3.I do recommend getting a good laptop cooler. I ordered this one but it hasn't been delivered yet. Again a mistake not to use one from the start as it actually will boost performance since the CPU and GPU boost frequencies will be maintained if thermal throttling doesn't occur. Let me know if you have any other doubts and congrats on your new laptop.

Yes you can upgrade the version of Windows. The license keys aren't as accessible as they used to be. This is Microsoft's way to fight back against software piracy. It also solves the problem of losing license keys original media after having the computer for a few years. Make sure you get a minimum 16GB USB Flash drive to create your recovery media. Any significant changes are recorded in your Microsoft account so you don't have to keep track of so much information. Once you login to the computer with your Microsoft account the hardware profile and license keys are saved. The nice part is that if you ever have to wipe reinstall on that computer you simply login with your Microsoft account when you are done and the activation will be automatic. Fortunately cleaning the computer software and physical dust is a lot easier. You'll notice temperature changes as you put it to use over time if dust builds up inside you'll notice the constant higher temperatures. Don't be too alarmed about the idea of dust buildup. it happens to anything that has force air flow in an enclosure. It simply took a long time for the general public to be aware of the dust in their computers. Don't make adjustments to how your computer operates until items like heat performance affect your use. While there are a lot of suggestions for overclocking undervolting and general gaming those changes can also damage your computer if done incorrectly.

ruslan-fortnite is correct. You can verify the amount being reserved which sometimes can be an indicator of a problem with the RAM by looking at the Performance tab in Task Manager. Open Task Manager click the Performance tab at the top then click Memory on the left side. On the right side you will now see how memory is being used. On the bottom right you'll see Hardware Reserved When it is a large amount of Reserved Memory Gigabytes there is nearly always a problem in the BIOS. A BIOS update and reset to default settings can clear some problems verifying the correct RAM has been installed during an upgrade resolves most other problems. In some of the other Acer product lines users can adjust the amount of reserved video RAM for the onboard chips that share system memory.

You should also read the undervolting threads which will have a much more significant impact on heat performance. Unless you are really looking for a poorly made step-by-step amateur tech video using the exact same model you can use any of the flood of YouTube videos for similar models as a reference. Essentially you are going to remove the screws for the case remove the cover remove the screws for the heat pipes fans. Clean the fans. Even though you should replace them if they are really packed with dust because you can't clean the fan bearings where the dust causes the problems. Removing the heat pipe s will reveal the heatsinks and then the thermal compound locations. Then put everything back together. You will should see some little squares of squishy material. That material is cut pieces of a thermal pad. It helps distribute heat so don't remove them. For you the trick will be to just find a similar Nitro model so you can see the thermal paste locations.

That sounds like a configuration issue. I'm guessing you meant to say you reboot unplug the power your router rather than reset erase all the settings . Without knowing the router channels being used local frequency interference and how your WiFi is configured this can turn into a lengthy discussion which mostly involves trying to squeeze details out of you so we can troubleshoot the problem. Which Router MFG model Are you broadcasting 802.11a/b/g/n/ac ? Do you have a preferred band selected in the tablet WiFi adapter settings? Have you updated the drivers on the tablet? Your E5 laptop will use 16GB max of DDR3 PC3-12800 -BUT- It specifically needs low voltage so-dimms labeled DDR3L-1600. Many people ignore that L which indicates low voltage and they find out the hard way that higher voltage RAM will not work at all in their computer. You definitely want to splurge add more RAM. Another 4GB stick of RAM will help with day-to-day regular work. If you are debating the 16GB upgrade it really depends on how you use your computer most people are surprised that they don't need to strain their budget and max out on RAM because they don't really stress their computer enough to make use of it. Yeah I'll admit I maxxed mine to 32GB just because I could and not because 20% of my work actually needs it. If your budget can stretch a bit consider getting an SSD drive for your primary boot drive and then move your current drive to the CD-Rom caddy. You can easily clone the current drive to the new SSD with the free version of Macrium. It performs very close to Samsung Intel and Crucial at half the cost. It is frequently on sale at Amazon for under 100. Remember that with all SSDs the larger the capacity the better performance you'll get. Those CD-Rom replacement HDD caddies are pretty darn cool. I've used them on a couple ASUS laptops and they worked great. Adding more storage is a much better use of that CD-Rom bay. It depends on your budget. I've researched tested SSD for my ACERs and was surprised at how flexible manufacturers are when posting specs. If you want to spend the money the higher-end Samsung and Intel lines are peak performers at a premium price. If you want within 95% of the same performance for a drastically lower price sometimes 50% lower the ADATA product line is really impressive. I personally went with the ADATA SX8200 Pro M.2 1TB 150US at Amazon and the ADATA SU800 2.5 2TB SSD. There are a lot of complaints but none of them are about the 1TB or 2TB SSD products which are faster than the lower capacity products. I've worked with Wake on LAN/Magic Packet utilities for years and have never heard of having to enable power to PCIe . Considering that PCIe is tied to the system bus I think it would be harder to find a way to disable it. What you should be looking for is the setting to permit PCIe devices to wake the computer.Boot to the BIOS navigate to Power Management Setup DISABLE Deep Power Off Mode ENABLE Power On by PCIE Devices Press F10 to save the changes. For anyone else reading this your BIOS probably has one simple entry to Enable Wake on LAN . Now boot into Windows and check your Wireless and LAN adapter properties in Device Manager. View the Power Management tab check the box allow this device to wake the computer .You might need to experiment with the Magic Packet option.

That isn't an actual product page. It is what is considered part of the line card . It lists the base model and options that are controlled by the regional distributor. You'll need to search for Aspire 5 A515-54G which should produce a few more retail distributors. Once you find the regional distributor i.e. Amazon.com Walmart.com NewEgg.com etc you'll see what options they have to choose from. Some specific units also have export or distribution limitations so you might have to get creative when ordering from Ottawa. ACER ASUS and MSI are very popular because of the flexibility for user installable upgrades. Most purchasers with some tech experience will buy a moderately priced base unit with the best CPU they can afford and then upgrade the RAM and hard drive for larger capacity or better quality components. The ACER Aspire 5 line ships with a rather low-end M.2 SATA B M key SSD installed. The M.2 port is a 2280 PCIe NVMe port which is easily compatible with nearly any M.2 2280 NVMe M key SSD Samsung ADATA Intel etc . The Aspire line also has an opening for a 2.5 SATA drive. Although the mounting kit should be inside the computer case you might have to order the 2.5 SATA cable mounting bracket if it isn't provided with your purchase. Some distributors remove the kit so they can sell it separately. Here is a really good ACER Support video that shows how to install a 2.5 drive and at the 3 43 point shows a great view of the motherboard. The M.2 drive is in the top left corner. Just below the M.2 drive is the so-dimm slot. This unit has 4GB RAM soldered on the board and an available so-dimm slot that will take a 16GB stick of RAM.

My first thought is that you have a low-end HDMI cable that is only wired for video or the cable isn't plugged in tightly. I've been stuck with one of those really cheap cables and it gave me a raging headache trying to track down problems. The other possibility is that you are simply missing a couple drivers. If you ran a clean install from a Windows disc instead of from the manufacturer's partition you might be missing component drivers. Make sure you check Device Manager for any red or yellow flags indicating a problem with a component. Sometimes manually starting a Windows Update scan will catch any missing drivers. With Acer computers I always work my way down the list in Device Manage checking for updates with automatically search . Sometimes a component will update even when Acer Windows Update doesn't show a new driver is available. I've forgotten if that 1050Ti model has the MaxxAudio utility. You'll want to use the audio software instead of the Windows Sound Console to change any settings. You should also check for MaxxAudio updates. Don't forget to download the latest Nvidia GeForce software. Sometimes when updating drivers people forget about the additional software updates.

The best way to confirm a part number is to look at the component in your laptop. That power jack is awkward to remove once the cable is unplugged so don't try to force it or pull too hard to get it out.

Well if you needed it to switch on you should have bought the Acer Switch 5. This is your mistake. Have you tried holding the power button for like 15 seconds? Additionally most Acer have a little reset button at the bottom of the computer. Put a paper clip in there for 5 seconds.

Press and hold the Power button down for 15 seconds. This will perform a software battery reset that may resolve the issue. If your system has a battery pinhole reset on the bottom insert a small paperclip in the battery reset pinhole and hold the button down for 5 seconds.

Ringgit to U.S. dollar conversion puts your budget around 1200 U.S. for a video editing rig. I think you might be limited to specific models permitted to be distributed in Malaysia. With video editing you'll definitely want to select a model that has a dedicated video card. The Nitro or Helios series are pushed toward gamers but they have high performance GPU video that will fit your needs. You should spend time reading the Reddit subs discussing Nitro 5 and Helios 300 With quad core processing PCIe SSD and an upgrade to 32GB RAM you'll enjoy the ease of editing and the response of the occasional game. If you were only occasionally editing video I'd look at the mid-range laptops for about half the price. They won't have the discrete video or higher resolution screens but the rest of the components will be nearly the same. I have the most experience with the Aspire 3 5 models. I personally prefer the Aspire 5 A515-52-526C. It has a max of 32GB RAM PCIe and SATA SSD ports 15.6 screen with 1080P resolution and a quad-core i5-8265U Another lower budget option is the Acer Aspire 5 A515-51-523X 15.6 Full HD 1920 x 1080 Intel i5-8250U 8GB DDR4 256GB SSD Windows 10 Home The Aspire 5 has a decent resolution screen already boots from a M.2 SSD. The M.2 will most likely be a SATA SSD in the PCIe slot. Every one I have opened has been a SATA SSD. Its an easy clone replace with PCIe SSD to boost speed. It comes with 4GB Ram soldered and 4GB in the slot. It runs surprisingly well on 8GB but I'd recommend replacing the 4GB stick with 8GB or 16GB depending on your budget and whatever is on sale. It is a bit of a hassle to get the SATA cable so you can install a 2.5 SATA HDD or SSD for additional storage. You may not need it right away but it is nice to know the upgrade is available. For the price hardware upgrade options the Aspire 5 would be a great purchase. Someone might point you to the Swift series as a more viable option. The 2.5 drive IS the second drive. You would install a m.2 SSD as the boot primary and use the 2.5 SATA for additional data. The latest Nitro laptops have 2 m.2 PCIe ports. My view is that Optane boost while great to improve platter drive performance is a waste of a PCIe port unless you don't have the budget to upgrade. rant Why use a small Optane SSD to cache a copy of Windows when you can run your entire installation from the m.2 SSD and get even better performance? /rant At least you ended up with the good Optane SSD. Before anything else you need to know WHY the system is crashing. It could be as simple as a driver conflict. Start by looking at the event logs. If you don't get enough details like which driver or software conflict caused the crash you can always examine the dump file to find out what happen at the exact time of the crash. This is when it is handy to run a full disk image of your system so you can experiment with drivers and revert back to the original backup if the changes didn't resolve the problem. Reinstalling Windows all the drivers and your software is just a hassle you shouldn't have to deal with after finding the source of the problem.

Although you could have provided more details about your router 802.11a/g/n/ac mfg model firmware version WiFi frequency 2.4GHz or 5GHz channels in use adapter driver version etc. I'll make a few suggestions. If your friend had played games there previously without any problems and it was only your machine disconnecting the troubleshooting list is a little shorter. I almost lost my mind one year when every day around 5 30pm my 2.4GHz WiFi would die. The short version of the story is that I happened to look out the window and saw my neighbor pull up just before the WiFi died. His freaking garage door opener was flooding the same frequency. Many cordless phones and some mice use the 2.4GHz frequency range too. Start with the simple stuff the router might have a bug in the firmware specific to your environment check to see if there is an update available. Install an app on your phone to scan for local WiFi access points. I like the free Farproc WiFi Analyzer because it shows the channels in use around you. You might have to change the channel you are using to the least used channel being broadcast around you. If your WiFi access point or all-in-one router has multi-frequency options try switching from G to N. That is after you run the scan to see what is being broadcast around you. If you have the Intel WiFi adapter go to the Intel site to check for an update instead of the older driver on the Acer website.

A few years ago several manufacturers installed a batch of really poor quality power connectors that became loose or simply unreliable. The only fix was to break out the soldering iron replace the connector. I'm guessing your Swift is out of warranty. I've seen a few folks wrap a small piece of tin foil around the plug to make it fit tighter in the connector port. You might have the Swift series that uses a DC Power Jack Cable Harness you'll have to look closely at yours to get the correct part number which is fairly easy to replace if you aren't timid about opening up the case. Its a power connector attached with a cable rather than being soldered onto the motherboard.

The plate is connected to the display and will move with it due to friction. Open the display and then unscrew both the left and right plate and the display will come right off allowing the charging port to be replaced.

Happened to my Helios 300 too. it's exactly like you said a trick the system uses because it can't pull enough power from the AC cord. In my case I didn't had the best configuration and for the top one it uses a different power supply cord with greater power. I assume it's the same for you?

I've seen a lot of similar complaints about the Helios draining the battery while plugged in. At peak usage it wants to draw more power than it is getting from the AC adapter so it drains the battery. Look at the specs on your AC adapter to check the wattage specs. Acer does offer a 330w adapter in their store so you could probably find a less expensive OEM adapter on Amazon or Ebay. I did find a couple anecdotes about GPU undervolting to lower performance a bit and reduce the power draw from the GPU. Those owners seemed to find a balance that kept the battery fully charged.
Try downloading and install the driver from their product page instead.

Since you'll have to open the case to replace the battery why don't you open it now for the practice so you can get the part number from the battery in your laptop? Then you can check with the ACER online store to compare their price with many of the other legit online retailers. With the correct part number you can also accurately search Amazon NewEgg Provantage Ebay etc. I have yet to experience any Aspire 3/5/7 battery that lasted longer than 2 hours with normal non-gaming use even when brand new.

Depending on how you are using it the short battery life may not be a big deal. These days you can find a power outlet nearly anywhere on a campus or coffee shop if you need a quick charge. If you tweak the power settings turn down screen brightness reduce CPU power etc you can probably easily make it through the day if you aren't constantly using it. Keep in mind that manufacturers test battery life with the strictest low power options to make the test results look better. I've been thinking about getting one of those external batteries to carry in my backpack in case my battery gets too low when I need it. I have a small one for my phone when I travel. Meanwhile I keep searching the wholesale websites to see if I can find the same size internal battery with a higher capacity. This is just one of those things we don't focus on when buying a reasonably powerful laptop. We want the nice screen and performance but none of us really research the battery until we need it to stay charged longer. For manufacturers the smaller battery helps reduce the overall weight of the laptop.

There might also be another explanation - in lot of laptop they use same type of SSDs but from different manufacturers and with a slightly different specifications. Perhaps originally there was faster SSD in your laptop but service had only same type but slower ones on stock so they used them. Then it might be ok. There is also a third possibility there is problem with this new SSD. But only service can get you an answer and eventually a solution. Regarding warranty - in my country warranty is extended for the time laptop is in service center maybe it is the same at your country. But in this case if you contact service without any delay after the repair I do not think it is relevant.
